tva-s gained for the people in the matter
of electric lights. The opposing forces
consisted of the Mutual Electric Light
Company, with Supervisors Clinton.
Dodge and Larkinann, on one side, and
the San Francisco Gas and Electric Cotn
pany, with Supervisors Haskins, Delany,
Bheehan, Morton, Britt, Smith and Riv
ers, on the other.
The principal matter before them was
the proposition of the Mutual Electric
lApht Company to furnish the city elec
tric Lights at a saving of $40.^00 per an
num on the present cost, and to save the
people of the city 1100,000 a year, provided
they were allowed to erect - oles for the
stringing of their wires outside the fire
limits. In this connection there was also
considered the plan of the Merchants'
Association for a new system of lighting
the streets by districts and for the sub
stitution of electric lights for gas lamps.
The great issue was the erection of ad
ditional poles by the Mutual Electric
Light Company. Had this privilege boon
granted that company would have been
placed in a position to compete with the
01..]o 1 ..] company everywhere within the city
limits, to the great benefit of every con
sumer of light, and particularly those
who reside outside of the lire limits. But
overy move In the struggle showed Liiat !
the Mutual Company and the people i
were doomed to defeat. But the defeat
appears to be only partial.
While the privilege of erecting addi
tional poles was not mranted, it was de
cided to advertise for bids for lighting
the city by districts, and this will give
the competing company an opportunity
to bid for the lighting within the flre
limits.
it is believed that this Is not the end
of the battle, so far as the Mutual Com
pany Is concerned. It is understood that
they will ask for a writ of mandamus
compelling the board to grant them the
privilege of erecting poles wherever they
THE SAX FRAXCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1898.
want within the city limits, on the
ground that not to do so would be dis
criminating against them In favor or the
San Francisco Gas and Electric Light
Supervisor Clinton was called to the
chair. Besides him there were present
Supervisors Raskin?. Delany. Sheehan,
Dodge. Lackmann, Morton, Britt, Smith
and Rivers
P. B. Cornwall, president of the Mutual
Electric Light Company, was granted the
privilege of the floor. After referring to
the proposition his company had made to
the city, he declared that all they asked
to be able to make good their promise
was the privilege of erecting electric
light poles for stringing wires outside the
In reply to the question as to how many
poles his company desired to put up, he
said they wanted to erect as many as
would be needed to fill all applicantions
for lights that might be made to the
company. He further declared that the
San Francisco Gas and Electric Company
was paying license s on a few more than
6000 poles, but that a careful count showed
they had nearer 10,000 poles up in this
city. It was not his company alone which
was asking the privilege from the board
of erecting poles In the outside districts,
he remarked, but every man. woman and
child who lived in those districts and also
those who paid taxes. These people ask
to be furnished light at the same rate
paid by those who live within the fire
limits. "One-third of the month there
i neither gas nor electric light in these
itions," he said, "and I believe that
electric lights on the streets would do
re good in the way of protection to
>ple and property out that way than
many policemen. You have no right
deny them light at the same rate that
ler people enjoy."
upervisor Smith interrupted to say that
â¢ present conditions were not the fault
this board, and that with the asslst
*e of the Merchants' Annotation it ex
ited to provide plenty of light during
the coming year.
Mr. Cornwall, continuing, said that the
people are now paying $19 50 per month
lor incandescent lights, such as the
Mutual Electric Light Company would
furnish for about $12. The average dif
ference, he added, is even greater than
this in some kinds of lights, rie assured
the board that his company would be
glad to be allowed to erect one-third the
number of poles the Gas and Electric
Company has outside the nre limits. In
conclusion he said: "We are prepared to
give the citizens and the city better ac
commodations, better lights and lower
rates than they now enjoy."
Chairman Clinton suggested that Mr.
Cornwall give the number of poles and
their location.
Mr. Cornwall stated that these matters
would be determined as the people made
application for lights. He wanted the
contracts for street lighting let in such
a waj- and at such time as would give
his company time to put up the necessary
poles.
At this point Supervisor Britt, who
throughout the session made wonderful
and frequent exhibitions of his ignorance
of parliamentary usages, sprang what he
evidently thought was a trump card in
the game of freezing out the Mutual
Electric Company for the benelit of its
rival. He called attention to the act
passed by tho last legislature, which
prohibited franchises being granted to
any corporation lor more than two years
without lirst advertising for bids for the
sale of such franchises. If this law ap
plied it would prevent the Mutual from
entering into competition for the con
tract tor lighting the street*, which must
bi- awarded before the Ist of August uf
this your. The franchise would first have
to be sold, and this would take consider
able time. In order that the Mutual may
be able to come into competition with the
Gas and Electric Company it must have
at least three months' time for the erec
tion of its poles and wires outside the
tire limits.
Mr. Cornwall declared that no other
corporation had been limited to two or
even ten years, and added that no other
corporation had experienced the same
ai,.:culty in securing a franchise that his
company had.
Clerk Russell read the act referred to |
by Britt. This provided that all fran
chises lor the use of public streets or
h.ghways must be sold to the highest
biuder, and that bids must be advertised
for.
M. M. Estee, the attorney for the Mu
tual Electric Company, stated that he
did not think the act constitutional, as it
violated section 19, article 11, and section
21, article 1, of the State constitution. He
read these and also a recent decision of
the State Supreme Court, declaring that
the Board of Supervisors had no right to
refuse to grant to one corporation a priv
ilege which it had granted to some other.
He then stated that if the Mutual was
allowed to erect poles outside of the lire
limits it would be in a position to save
the city the sum of $40,00u and to the cit
izens of San Francisco the sum of $100,000
annually.
We are furnishing to-day," he said,
"electric lights at a reduction of 25 per
cent from the price that was charged by
the other companies before we came into
the market."
Supervisor Dodge called attention to
the lact that tho Merchants' Association,
which represented the best business men
in the city, had made a formal request
to the board to see that competition was
made possibl* when the next contract
was let for lighting the <ity. At the
in . sent time, he said, Alamoda was pay
ing $S per month lor what the residents
of this city were paying $16.
He declared that all technicalities of a
minor character should be swept aside.
â¢â¢1 don't think this board can afford to ;
ignore this proposition," he added. it
comes I. .;ure us In too solid a form, me
gentlemen connected with it are all well
known in this community. 1 have yet to ;
hear any legitimate reason advanced
against it. v\ o have u> save time.
Delay means defoat. I move that It is the
sense of this board that in the considera
tion of this question the object shall be
to advertise lor proposals at such a date
that competition may be possible.'
Supervisor Lackmann seconded the mo-
Supervtsor Smith remarked that it was ,
a matter of erecting poles and not a. I
Question of furnishing light, and declared
that he would vote against any plan to i
allow the erection of poles, but would
vote for any measure compelling corpora
tions to put their wires underground.
Chairman Clinton said that the general ,
matter of electric lighting might be dis- \
cussed and that the debate need not be
eonnned only to poles. ....
Hero. Supervisor Podge explained that
the object of his motion was simply to
get at tho intention of the board in rela
tion to competition. "I think the bills for
lighting tho. City Hall are exorbitant,
was his concluding shot.
A rollcall was demanded on Dodge s mo
tion, and it was carried by a unanimous
\V H Hewitt, superintendent of the i
police and fire alarm system, attempted j
to mak" an argument against the erec- i
tion of additional poles; but Dodge spiked
his gun by calling attention to the fact
that the Bell Telephonl Company was !
putting up a large number of poles on
Bush street. In the crossfire that fol
lowed between Dodge and Howitt it de
veloped that Hewitt had ordered these
poles put up on the understanding that
he was to be allowed to string such wires i
as he wanted on them.
Dodpe claimed that the city would i
string no more than two or three wires on
these polos, while the telephone company
would place 200 or 300 on them. He
charged that favoritism was being shown
to the telephone company, while the Mu
tual was being discriminated against.
J M McDonald, of the City Improve
ment Company, asked permission to erect
polos for electric lighting on Haight. De
visadero California and Fillmore streets,
and was instructed to make his applica
tion in writing.
Dodge moved that the committee or the
whole report in favor of the adoption of
the resolution before them, th**. is, to ad
vertise for bids immediately, and that
the bids be so prepared as to allow of
C Â°A S. Baldwin, vice-president of the
Merchants' Association, said that his as
sociation was opposed to poles in the
streets, hut that tho erection of addi
tional polos were necessary In this case
to permit of competition.
Notwithstanding that Dodge's motion
had not boon disposed of. Smith moved
that it 1.0 the sense of the board that, as
requested by tho Merchants' Association,
tho buainess streets, Golden Gate avenue,
Folsom street and Van Ness avenue be
lighted by electric light instead of by gas,
and that the lights be burned every night
In the yoar.
This was carried' without a dissenting
Dodge moved that proposals be asked
for by the board for lighting the city by
districts, as outlined by the Merchants
Association, and that the Street Light
Committoe be instructed to immediately
prepare specifications.
Smith offered an amendment providing
that no additional poles should be erected
in this connection. Dodge accepted the
amendment , saying that he would con
sider the vote taken on the amended mo
tion as a test of how the Supervisors
stood on this important question.
Considerable discussion followed, and
resuUed in Smith withdrawing his
amendment. Then an effort was made to
have action postponed, but without suc
cess.
Smith again offered his amendment, and
it was adopted by the following vote:
Ayesâ Haskins, Delany, Sheehan, Mor
ton. Britt, Smith, Rivers. Total. 7.
Noesâ Dodge, Lackmann, Clinton. Total,
Dodge's motion, thus amended, was
carried.
The committee of the whole resolved
itself into tho Board of Supervisors. Su
pervisor Haskins taking the chair. Chair
man Clinton of the committee of tho
whole reported the two motions made by
Dodge and which had been adopted in
committee, and his report was adopted.
By an oversight the motion made by
Smith, and which had also been adopted
in committee, was not reported to the
board.
Adjournment was taken until Monday
at 2 p. m.
FAIRLY GOOD WORK AT
INGLESIDE.
The coursing at Ingleside Park yester
day was fairly good, and when the short
enders won in many instances those who
had overlooked form were in pocket. A
few good, strong short enders carried
away the money, and it is predicted that
to-morrow the long enders will be in
clover. In one or two courses the judg
ing was found fault with, but as a rule
the decisions wore not objected to. The
hares ran well and the do^s which were
slipped proved to be unusually fast.
Van Knapp was the surprise of the day
when ho fasily downed Alma in a hard,
long, well-fought course, and in conse
quence some money poured into the long
odds book for the final on the surprise.
The betting is strong in the final book.
and Firenza, Gladiator, Pet Kirby. Moun
tain Beauty and Little Dell will get the
bulk of the money on the play.
It Is thought by many that a rank out
sider may carry away the money, but the
knowirg ones say that there are but
two or three In the final race. A large
Saturday crowd had gathered, and it was
regretted by the management that more
pool boxes were not in running order, as
those which were in operation could
hardly carry the money played into them.
Ned Harrigan, the well-known actor, and
Frank McComb of Mountain View were
among those present. A strong play will
possibly be made on Koo Lawn to win
the purse, but the old timers say there
is but one thing in the run, and that is
named Gladiator, owned by the well
known coursing man and judge, J. Dean.
The run-down was as follows:
D. L. Deslmone's Buckwa beat Batt &
Franks Count of Monte Cristo; P. Brophv's
Benlcia Boy beat E. J. Heeney's Moore's Pre
scription; D. Roche's Gold Dust beat S E
lortal's Our Boy; J. MeCormick's White Wings
beat J. Anthony's Tullormore; W. Ryan's Sig
nal beat G. Heuer's Blue Jay; M. Mlchallk'a
Fireball beat I>. China's Happy Day; Larkey
â R'Jck s Hercules beat F. G. Fentiman's Blue
Bell; 1. McHukli's Sprlnpfleld beat P. O'Don
nell s Counterfeit; J. ,<hea's Firenza beat E. C.
Jones Gaslight; J. Dean's Gladiator beat G
Smart s Silk wood; D. Hooper's Koo Lawn beat

League of the Cross Rally.
A district rally and essay contest of the
League of the Cross will be held on Sun
day, April 24. in Native Sons' Hall, Mason
street. Members of the league from the
following parishes will attend the rally
in a body: St. Mary's Cathedral, Sacred
Heart, Holy Cross, St. Brigld's and St.
Francis. Companies A, D, G and M,
League of the Cross Cadets, will be pres
ent in full uniform.
The principal feature of the rally will
be the essay contest for the silver medal
of the league. The winner of the medal
Will have the privilege of competing for
the Archbishop's diamond medal next
August at the grand rally in the Mechan
ics' Pavilion.
The contestants on next Sunday will
be: Private James O'Brien. Company A,
representing St. Mary's Cathedral; Color
Sergeant George Shaw of Sacred Heart;

OF ROBBERY
AND DEATH
Conrad Masemann Is
Decoyed by a
Woman.
She Disappeared and Left
Him Dead in the
Room.
Poison Found in the Pocket of
the Vest by the Deputy
Coroner.
WORDS TO SHOW SUICIDE.
Another Terrible Lesson That the
Wages of Sin la Deathâ The
Police Investigation.
There came to the Morgue yesterday
| another of those mysterious cases hint
ing: at murder and robbery which have
been of such frequent occurrence within
the last year. Bodies of unknown men
â¢with their pockets turned inside out
have been picked up in the bay, the
features unrecognizable through de
composition, and they have been bur
led in the potters' field and forgotten
for all time. Others, strangers from
the country, have been found dead in
bed in cheap lodging houses with the
gas turned on to give color to the easy-
DECOYED INTO A LODGING HOUSE AND ROBBED.
Some of the Effects of the Man Supposed to Be Conrad Masemann,
the Victim of an Unknown Woman Suspected of Having
Poisoned and Robbed Him in the White House Lodgings,
] on Jackson Street.
going theory of suicide or accident, and
with no money among their effects, al
thoiigh they were known on the day
before to have had In their possession
largo sums.
The case of yesterday hints at a mur
der -coupled with robbery. There are
no witnesses to the crime, and there
1b n?> clew to the perpetrator except
the slight one to be found in the story
told â â  by the manager of the lodging
house.
Yesterday afternoon J. A. Rudell,
inan-iger of the White House, a cheap
resort at 414 Jackson street, informed
Deputy Coroner McCormick that one
of hVs guests had been found dead in
bed. ; Mr. McCormlck found in one of
the rooms a large, fine looking man,
apparently a German, lying dead on
his tfed dressed in his shirt and trous
ers. ; The limbs were very rigid and
froth had issued from the mouth, show
ing that poison had been used. Poked

in his vest pocket were found two
white powders, exidently morphine, or
strychnine, wrapped in a piece of news
paper.
On the rules and regulations card
posted on the wall were scrawled in
lead pencil the following: "Friday,
April 15, IS9B, 7 o'clock. She has taken
all nnd not a cent left. Good-by. My
name is no good."
On a torn sheet of note paper lying
on the tab'c were the words, also in
lead pencil: "She has Rob me of all;
not one cent laft. Good biy." On an
other sheet of paper, an advertising
dodger Cor Klondike supplies, were the
words in pencil: "I am rob of all I
had, so good biy. She not even left me
one cent. April IT. IS9S."
Mr. Rudell told the following story:
"I was dozing in a chair in the read
ing-room at about half-past 1 o'clock
yesterday (Friday) morning when this I
man came in with a woman and asked
for a room. He had been drinking and
he held a 50 cent piece in his hand,
which he gave me for the rent of the
room. The woman was about medium
hHsHt, about as tall as I am, and I did
nol take notice of her. We don't take
notice of such people, anyhow. That ;
was the first and the last I saw of
cither of them till I saw the man dead.
The bedmaker yesterday morning tried
the door and found it locked. He
thought that the landlord had made !
the bed, so he went away and said |
nothing about it. This morning he
could not get in and there was no an
swer to his knock. I knocked a whole
lot of times and then broke In the |
door and found that the man was;
dead."
On the person of the dead man were
I found a bunch of three large brass
keys, one of them resembling a pass or
skeleton key. There was also another
key with a brass check attached to it
and the number G3, evidently a room
number, engraved upon it. It did not
belong to the White House. There was
an open-faced silver watch with the
initials C. H. M. scratched on the
back of the case and a brass match
box representing the profile of Colum
bus, with the name "Conrad Mase
mann" engraved upon it. This is prob
ably the name of the dead man.
Coroner Hawkins at once reported
the case to the police, as it was clear
that robbery had been committed and
I possibly murder. If the dead man
should be identified a comparison of the
j writing found in the room with a sam
ple of his known writing will deter
mine w r hether the robber added murder
to the crime.
Several addresses in pencil on the
backs of hotel and other cards were
' found in his pockets. They were 234
O'Farrell, rooms 4 and 5; 111 Grove
street, room 2; 123 Powell street, room
' 71; 35 New Montgomery street; Miss
; Coraline Donnadieu, 617V6 Post street.
The deceased wore as a watch charm
an acorn cut in purple glass.
The facts gleaned from an interview
with Miss Donnadieu at her home last
evening indicate that the notes sup
posed to have been written by the
dead man were probably the work of
some one else. Miss Donnadieu knows
a man named Conrad Masemann and
from a description of the body at the
Morgue is convinced that he is the
one she knew. He came to this city
about three weeks ago with a letter . f
introduction to Miss Donnadieu from
her father, who is in Panama. The
two had gone there from New York
some time ago. and when Donnadieu
learned that Masemann was going to
San Francisco he wrote a letter to his
daughter to notify her of the fact that
he was sick. Miss Donnadieu says
that Mnsemann was probably a Ger
man, but that he spoke with very lit
tle accent and used excellent English
When told of the notes found upon him
she gave it as her opinion that a man
who used as good language as Mase
mann would be able to write better
English than that in the notes
Impersonated an Officer.
Thomas Tlernev a stevedore living at
609 Union Street, was arrested by Officer
Neal Carmirhael and charged with im
personating an officer. Tierney went to
the Vallejo lodging house, owned by
Louis Mattieu, and showing a police
man's star demanded possession of the
house. Mattieu saw the star was not one
belonging to a regular officer, so refused
to recognize the man and had him arrest
ed. Mattieu has bet-n sued for divorce by
his wife, who Is rooming witn Tierney's
family, and it is supposed that the latter
was trying to get possession of the house
for Mrs. Mattieu.
Fears Assassination.
Frank Purdy, an insane man, was re
moved to the insanity ward of the Re
ceiving Hospital last evening n aw.iit
examination. Purdy fell off a roof a year
ngo and was injured about tno head.
Since then he has boon laboring under
the delusion that some one will take hu
life.

THE SAN FJRANCISCO CALL, SI'NDAY, APRIL 17, 1898.
MAY NOW STOP
THE EXPORTS
Naval Men Anxious That
Supplies for Cuba and
Porto Rico Cease.
Once the War Starts the Block
ading Vessels Will Shut
Out All Transports.
President McKinley Will Not Act
However, Until Duly Author
ized by Congress.
Special Dispatch to The Call.
NEW YORK, April 16.â A Washing
ton special to the Herald says: Presi
dent McKinley is serious considering
the advisability of taking action which
will prevent vessels carrying supplies
to Cuba and Porto Rico. Information
which has been officially received at
the State Department shows that Spain
is purchasing large quantities of pro
visions and coal and is shipping them
into Havana and San Juan Porto Rico,
which will be blockaded by the Ameri
can squadrons in the event of war.
Furthermore, the authorities have
been advised that the Spanish author
ities in Havana and Porto Rico are
working night and day on the harbor
fortifications, and mounting new bat
teries, composed of modern guns. In
addition submarine mines are being
planted and every effort is being made
to give the American fleet a warm re
ception upon its arrival on a hostile
mission in Cuban and Porto Rican
waters.
Recognizing that the most effective
way of reducing Havana and San Juan
will be by means of blockading and by
starvation which will follow among the
soldiers of Spain, I understand that an
effort is being made by the Navy De
partment to have the President take
steps which will result in putting a
stop to the dispatch of supplies from
the United States to the Spanish West
Indies.
It is appreciated that It will be im
possible for Spain to send food or
other supplies from Spain to her col
onies, for the reason that transports
would almost certainly be captured by
blockade vessels which will surround
Cuba, even if they failed to meet an
American cruiser on the high seas.
The department's plan of campaign
against Havana will depend much upon
the condition of the climate in the is
land when hostilities commence. If
the rainy season is at its height and
yellow fever is rampant, it is proba
ble that work, for some time at least,
will be confined to a blockade. The
army will be rushed into the island as
soon as conditions are suitable to make
an attack. So far as Porto Rico is
concerned, it is recognized that there
will have to be army and navy co
operation there, for the reason that
Spain has quite a large military force
on that island.
There is considerable doubt as to
whether the President can, under the
law, as it now stands, forbid the ex
portation of supplies to Cuba and Porto
Rico. When war commences, of course,
an embargo will follow, but whether
he can take such action in time of
peace is a question which the law of
ficials of the Government will serious
ly study before taking action.
That there may be no delay whatever
about the matter Senator Hawley in
troduced in the Senate the resolution
authorizing the President to stop the
exportation of coal. This is only a
step, however, in the direction which
the naval authorities would like to go.
Besides coal it is desired to stop ship
ment of all kinds of provisions and
munitions of war. It is said that the
President considers that the wisest
plan is to secure legislation on the sub
ject. When this has been done, then
he will take such action as Congress
authorizes.
WOMAN'S CONGRESS IN SESSION.
The Fifth Annual Meeting, Which
Will Soon Be Followed by an
Entertainment.
The fifth annual session of the Woman's
Congress Association was held yesterday
afternoon in the Occidental Hotel. The
association is progressing in usual good
order and arrangements have been made
for a programme to be rendered in the
N. S. G. W. hall on the evenings of May
2. 3, 4 and 5. An interesting programme
will be given. â¢
Following arc the subjects to be dis
cussed: "Social Trends in a Democracy,"
Dr. E. A. Ross; "Money Measurements of
Men." Miss M. E. Connor; "Anglo-
Mania, Its Cause, Its Justification and
Its Cure," David Starr Jordan; "Influ
ence of Woman's Cluhs on Social Life "
Mrs. E. A. Orr; "The Church as a Source
of Fellowship," Mrs. Sidney Yarrow
"The Sway of Fashion," Mrs. M. R
Smith; "Social Functions and the News
paper." Prof. C. A. Duniway; "Disinte
gniting Forces of City Life," Mrs. Sarah
Pratt Carr; "The Mission of the Social
Settlement," K. C. Babcock; "Equality
How Far Is It an American Idea 9 " Dr'
Jordan; "Can We Escape the Growth of
Social Distinctions?" Dr. E. A. Ross
The members of the executive board in
sure all a pleasant evening who attend
the exercises. They are as follows- Mrs
J. F. Swift, Mrs. M. W. Kinkaid. Mrs Q
T. Gadea, Mrs. Ada "Van Pelt, Madame
L. A. Sorbier, Mrs. Jordan, Mrs A
Bperry, Mrs. G. W. Bunne-U. Mrs. Lloyd
Baldwin, Mrs. Henry Krebs Jr., and Mrs.
C. O. Smith.
Booked on Two Charges.
Andrew Tychsen of 7% Madison avenue
was arrested by Officer John Lynch yos
terday on a warrant sworn to by H H
Hcrrin of Lake County, charging him
with misdemeanor and obtaining money
on false pretenses. He will be removed
to Lake County to-day for trial.
ELECTION AT STOCKTON.
Proposed Annexation of Two School
Districts Defeated.
STOCKTON, April 16.â The election
held In Stockton and the Fair Oaks and
North school districts to-day on the
question of the annexation of the two
outside districts to the city resulted in a
decisive majority against annexation.
Stockton cast a majority of 112 against
annexing the eastern or Fair Oaks addi
tion out of a total of 998 votes, while that
district cast but one majority for it in a
total of 139. The Stockton vote against
the annexation of the north district was
542 out of a total of 1002 votes, making
the majority against the proposition 91
The voters of the north district cast 4i
votes and gave a majority of 8 against
annexation.
The movement in both cases grew out
of the public school money distribution
between the city and the outside dis
tricts, wnich were tormerly granted
school privileges in tÂ«.e city.
Death* of a Pioneer Woman.
VENTURA. April 16.â Mrs. Martinla H.
Camarallio died to-day at her home in
this city at the age of 72. She was the
widow of Juan Camarallio, and was born
in Santa Barbara. Juan Camarallio
came to San Buenaventura in 1854, and
at one time owned 20,000 acres of land in
Ojai Valley. Mrs. Camarallio will be
buried at the old mission on Monday.
First Cherries of the Season.
VACAVILLE, April IC-The first box
of cherries to go East this year was
shipped yesterday by Maury Robinson to
Chicago. He shipped another box to-day.
Yesterday's shipment was eleven days
earlier than the first of last season, which
was shipped on April 26.
FRAOTIOUS HORSES
CAUSE HIS DEATH.
Burlingame Coachman Killed by
Being Hurled From a
Carriage.
REDWOOD CITY, April ""^.âCoroner
James Crowe was called t<> I an Mateo
this morning to hold an Inquest over the
body of a young man named Walter Ab
lett, who was killed by being thrown
from a carriage yesterday morning near
Burlingame. Ablett was coachman for
Frank Carolan of Burlingame, but not
withstanding his position was evidently
highly cultured and well connected. That
he had traveled extensively is shown by
the great number of curios which he had
in his possession. Among them were
some gathered in Egypt, with pictures of
himself taken at Cairo in Egyptian cos
tume. A number of letters and pictures
I from friends and relatives in various
j parts of the world were found in his
trunk. 'Upon his person was found a card
bearing the address of bis father, "J. Ab
lett, Friday Bridge, near Wlsbeck, Cam
bridge, England." Ablett wan a native
of Scotland, and about 30 years old.
Yesterday afternoon Ablett started
from the Carolan place with a double
team to take a friend named Smythe to
San Mateo. The horses became unman
ageable and Smythe jumped outofthecar
riage. The team ran away, and at a
; bridge about 20*) yards from the Carolan
place the carriage was upset, throwing
the driver out. He struck upon his head
i and was rendered unconscious. His skull
i was fractured, and he died about 8 o'clock
yesterday evening.
ON THE TRAIL OF
BOXCAI THIEVES.
Northern Pacific Railroad Detectives
Recover a Quantity of Stolen
Merchandise.
TACOMA. April 16.â 1t develops to-night
that Northern Pacific Railroad detectives
are hot on the track of a gang of thieves
which has been systematically robbing
freight cars along the western end of the
road. Goods for which the railroad has
paid thousands of dollars in settling
claims for losses have mysteriously dis
appeared, until detectives unearthed the
fact that regular hauls were being made
on the Pacific division, east and south of
Tacoma.
Officers here were notified to-day that
the men whom the detectives are after
were in Astoria. Sheriff Mills wired to
Olympia for requisition papers and In
tended going to Astoria via Salem to
night-, when telegrams announced that
the men were no longer in Astoria. The
Northern Pacific is <sald to have ordered
its detectives to spare no expense in cap
! Turing the gang, which apparently learn
ed last week that it was being shadowed.
Several hundred dollars' worth of stolen
cigars, tobacco and shoes have been cap
tured at the gang's cache, twenty-five
miles east of Tacoma.
HEAVY DAMAGES FOR
A FRESNO RANCHER.
Wins a Suit Against the San Joa
quin-Kings River Canal Irriga
*tiori Company.
FRESNO. April 16.â The suit brought by
William Lowry against the San Joaquin-
I Kings River Canal Irrigation Company,
â  which has been on trial before a Jury
| in Judge Rlsley'a court all week, ended
I late this afternoon in a verdict of $20,000
i for the plaintiff. The award of such
heavy damages r;inip as a surprise
I to those who had been following the case.
j It was thought the plaintiff would get a
verdict, but few thought it would be for
so large an amount.
The amount sued for was $25,000, for in
; jury sustained by the flooding of a large
acreage which Lowry was farming. The
damage was alleged to have been caused
by the backing up of water owing to a
dam which the Irrigation Company main
tained across San Joacjuin River.
The defendant asked for twenty days'
! .stay, which was consented to. The case
I will be appealed to the Supreme Court.
It is understood that Miller & Lux are
the real defendants in the action.
PERMITS FOR CUT-OFFS
ON THE SAN JOAQUIN.
Work on the Improvement of the
Stream Will Soon Be Under
Way.
SACRAMENTO. April 16.â Ed E. Leake,
Commissioner of Public Works, to-day re
ceived the following telegram from Con
gressman De Vries:
"Permit from War Department for cut
offs 6 and 7 on the San Joaquln goes
forth to-day. Please rush Sacramento
plan."
This long delayed permit means much
to the property owners along the Sacra
mento and San Joaquin rivers. It is very
probable that tho same action will be
taken in regard to work on the New Town
shoals, and as the plans were forwarded
to-day word will be no doubt received in
a very short time.
STANFORD'S ACQUISITION.
Alexis V. Babine Appointed Asso-
ciate Librarian.
PALO ALTO, April IG.-Alexis V. Ba
bine, librarian of the university of Indi
ana, has been appointed associate li
brarian at Stanford University. Mr Ba
bine is a native of Russia, where he re
ceived a thorough education, especially
along the lines of the modern languages
and history. On coming to this country
he entered Cornell University, where he
took his bachelor's degree, afterward be
coming assistant librarian. From thiÂ«
position he was called to the University
of Indiana.
Mr. Babine has a high standing among
librarians. He has a thorough knowledge
of the technique of the profession, as well
as a broad acquaintance with hooks. He
will be a valuable acquisition to the fac
ulty of Stanford University.
Funeral of Miss Wilson.
SANTA CRUZ, April 16.-The body of
Miss M. Rey Wilson arrived yesterday
afternoon from New York City. Her
funeral will take place to-morrow from
the homo of her sister, Mrs. Genobedo
Epifanls Arano, in East Santa Cruz. The
Interment will be at the Odd Fellows'
Cemetery.

RAZORS IN THE
ATMOSPHERE
J. Baltimore, a Barber,
Carved His Sweet-
heart's Husband.
A Dealer in Coal Oil Who Re
grets That He Thought He
Was Infatuated.
Sent to the Hospitnl After Attempting
to Show a Rival the Error
of His Way.
James Baltimore, colored, and a
barber by profession, is in all kinds of
difficulty because of a love affair in
which the wife of a local coal-oil
dealer is intermingled. For weeks past
the clandestine meeting's have taken
place, but a few nights ago the hus
band became aware ot the visits of his
wife and went to the barber shop of his
rival, and in an attempt to assassinate
his competitor received a deep gash
in the calf of the right leg, which
necessitated a visit to the Receiving
Hospital, where the wound was dressed.
The case, or rather love affair, shows
how easily a man of good looks may
win the affections of a lady of trusting
disposition, be she what nationality or
'me nature ha* made her, but in this
case the lady was white, and in conse
quence the husband was made the
mere jealous thereby. Nature fre
quently plays peculiar tricks, and the
coal -oil dealer thinks razors are even
more tricky, but he is willing to leave
things as they are, since his better half
has decided that she will no longer
leave the fireside of the man she has
chosen, and in consequence Baltimore
is shaving his customers in a quiet
way while his brain is whirling in a
mist of plans and determination.
It is not at all probable that the case
will find its way into the courts, but
there are rumors which flit here and
there that a body may find its way
into the Morgue, but neither husband,
nor rival seems to worry, as it is prob
able that the center of attraction has
given solemn promises in both direc
tions. "I don't blame him for cutting
me," says one, and the other dreams
of a second chance to repeat the
operation.
Meanwhile the lady in the case won
ders just where the peculiar situation
will end, and it is rumored that she
will fly v.- distant parts to escape the
anger of her husband and the honeyed
words of James Baltimore, the barber.
GOVERNOR OF A PROVINCE
PLACED UNDER ARREST
Accused of Being in League With
Revolutionists to Overthrow the
President of Ecuador.
PANAMA, April 16.â Telegraphic ad
vices from the Herald's correspondent in
Guayaquil, Ecuador, say: The Governor
of this province was to-day placed under
arrest by the commander in chief of the
army here. The cause is not generally
known, but it is supposed he is accused
of being in league with the revolutionary
movement to overthrow President Al
faro. All is quiet now.
Death of W. E. Parrott.
PHOENIX, April 16.â W. E. Parrott
died at the Sisters Hospital last night.
He came to Phoenix five months ago suf
fering from lung trouble. He was one
of the noted baseball players of the
union.

The State Medical Institute Discovers a
Remarkable Remedy for Lost
Vigor.
ARE SENDING FREE A TRIAL PACKAGE
TO ALL WHO WRITE.
Free samples of a most remarkable
: remedy are being distributed by the State
Medical Institute, Fort Wayne, Ind. It
cured so many men who had battled for
years against the mental and physical
suffering of lost manhood that the insti-
tute has decided to distribute free trial
packages to all who write. It Is a home
treatment and all men who suffer with
any. form of sexual weakness resulting
from youthful folly, premature loss of
strength and memory, weak back, varico-
cele, or emaciation of parts can now cure
themselves at home.
The remedy has a peculiarly grateful
effect of warmth and seems to act direct
to the desired location giving strength
and development just where it is needed.
It cures all the ills and troubles that
come from years of misuse of the natural
functions and has been an absolute suc-
cess in all cases. A request to the State
Medical Institute. 193 First National Bank
Building, Fort Wayne, Ind., stating that
you desire one of their free trial pack-
ages will bo complied with. The institute
is desirous of reaching that great class
of men who are unable to leave home to
be treated and the free sample will en-
able them to see how easy it is to be
cured of sexual weakness when the
proper remedies are employed. The in-
stitute makes no restrictions. Any man
who writes will be sent a free sample,
" carefully sealed in a plain package so
that Its recipient need have no fear of
embarrassment or publicity. Readers ara
requested to write without delay.

PROPOS VLS.
OFFICE C. Q. M.. Vancouver Barracks, Wash.,
April 14. IS9B. Sealed proposals, in triplicate,
will be received here until 11 o'clock, a. m..
May 14, 1898, and then opened for furnishing
and delivery at Vancouver Barracks, Wash.,
Portland, Or., Sun Francisco, Cal., or else-
where, stationery required in Department of
the Columbia. information furnished on ap-
plication. U. S. reserves right to reject or
accept any or nil proposals, or any part
thereof. Preference given to articles -f do-
mestic production or manufacture, condi-
tions of quality and price (Including In
the price of articles of foreign produc-
tion or manufacture the duty thereon)
being equal, and such preference given
to articles of American production or !
manufacture produced on the Pacific Coast
to the extent of the consumption required by i
the public service there. Envelopes contain- i
Ing proposals should be marked: "Proposals !
for Stationery," and addressed J. W.
JACOBS. Q. m

KILLED IN A FIGHT.
Samuel Boody Irelan the Victim of a
Drunken Brawl on the Notori
ous Hinckley Alley.
Samuel Boody Irelnn died in the City
| and County Hospital last Friday after
j noon of hemorrlniKo and compression of
'the brain. The deceased *as a calker,
t',4 years old, and resided at 21 Hinckley
' alley.
He had been drinking heavily all day
I Saturday, the 9th iast., and was found
j lying unconscious on the floor of his
room on Sunday morning. John Ol?.>n.
who lives at the same address, told'
Policeman John Duane that Irelan had
a tight with an unknown man Saturday
evening and had been knocked senseless
i with a bottle.
The body was taken to the Morgue and
the police are working on the case.
The Liebseher Robbery.
Joe Theron. alias James Thorn, John
Winrow and George Harker, the three
men arrested for the robbery and assault
upon E. Liebseher. grocer. Mason and
Pacific streets, early Thursday morning
were arraigned in Judge Low's court yes
terday morning. By consent the cases
were continued for a week.
Insurance companks claim that cycling
Is more dangerous than travel- g "either
by railway or ship.
FAIR ART FOR CHARITY
IT Is a triumph of femininity. It was
arranged by women for the benefit
of women, and if there weren't
women's, pictures to be painted, who'd
be a portrait painter? The portrait
loan exhibition for the benefit of the
California Women's Hospital was
opened last night. All San Francisco was
there; that is. the part of San Francisco
that attends first nights, whose nature is
such that society considers them proper
functions. The portrait loan is evidently
quite the thing. Beautiful women In
Easter bonnets and spring toilettes gaze
admiringly through their gold-rimmed
lorgnettes at the beautiful painted women
upon the wall who gaz^ admiringly hack
again. And both are worth going to see,
and seem equally conscious of being part
of the show.
As to the men, they're merely adjuncts,
shadows that serve to bring out the deli
cate hues and graceful draperies of the
more gorgeous sex. And for one spec
tator who lingers before a man's portrait
there are twenty before his feminine ri
val's. Joseph Strong's portraitsâ even
though the subject be a manâ attract
much attention. Matthews' portrait of B.
C. Samuels, Cadenasso's spirited, artistic
Piazzoni, Voss' portrait of Rudolph Neu
man are the exceptions. The exquisite
Boldini portrait of litttle Ethel Crocker,
a butterfly in gauzy blue, just lighted
upon the rose satin couch, and J. W.
Clawson's charming pastel of Miss Mary
Bell Gwin in her grandmother's pink
satin gown are the favorites.
This pastel is a beautiful bit of work
and the serious dark eyes, the slender
brows and the white forehead with the
pale pink background, framed in simple,
miniature-like fashion, make this one of
the most beautiful faces on the wallsâ
or off it, for that matter. Yates 1 portrait
of Miss Sullivan is an example of blonde
loveliness, an entirely different type from
Clawson's picture.
The collection of miniatures is a very
interesting one. The one loaned by Mag
a Heu ,7Tnann o f Miss Congreve, daugh-
V^nJt! v " a , mllton Fish of London is
a < osuj half dozen square inches. Tha
face is a beautiful ono. the poise of the
head and the delicate work make this
one of the gems of the collection in the
ibrary. that includes the miniature dono
in Munich In 1574 of Latham M'-Mullin and
UNCLE SAM
CHECKS MONITORS
But They Ars the Hydraulic
Ones in the Moun
tains.
Far Reaching Decision by Federal
Engineers Defining "Hydraulic
Minng "
Uncle Sam has told Californians what
"hydraulic mining" is. As hydraulic
mining was Invented in California and
here achieved Us vast development, this
may sound odd to some, but in fact the
hydraulic miners, mining engineers and
lawyers of this State have not known un
til now what the definition of the term is.
This refers mainly to the legal sense of
the term, of course, and the great im
portance of the exact legal sense of the
term. and the conflict over It that has long
raged make Uncle Sam's decision of the
')>i<-stion the most important ruling af
fecting mining interests that has come
forth for a lung time.
The ruling is announced by the Federal
engineers composing the California Debris
Commissionâ Colonel Suter, Major Heuer
and Lieutenant Deakyn. After months
of consideration, the commission has just
communicated to Attorney John M.
Wright, chairman of the committee on
dredging of the California Miners' Asso
ciation, the brief announcement that the
commission defines hydraulic mining to
l>e "mining by means of water delivered
under pressure through a nozzle."
.Lhis simple looking definition means
that the Federal engineers who regulate
hydraulic mining on the watersheds of
the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers,
under the Caminetti law. will assume
that that law and their jurisdiction cov
ers the washing of old tailings, of piles of
gravel tunneled out of drift mines, etc.,
li water is applied nirough a nozzle,
under pressure." This is an application
of the law against which there has been
much -opposition among the miners.
Until the Caminetti law was passed in
IW3 the term "hydraulic mining" had
never been written in a statute unless in
cidentally, and had never been fully de
iin< d by a court. The Caminetti law pro
vided that for its purposes the term
should have "the meaning and applica
tion given to said terms in said State."
This left a fine iield for study and dis
pute. A monitor playing on the side of
8 mountain was hydraulic mining plainly
enough, but between this and ordinary
siuicing In other placer mines, which the
law let alone, puzzles quickly appeared,
march 21. 1SO:{. the State Legislature de
fined hydraulic mining to be mining by
the application of water under pressure
"against a natural bank." But this defi
nition was not in existence when the
Caminetti law was approved three weeks
Im I'm !â .
Under this State definition if a miner
turned ;i gi:mt on a pilo Of Old iniliiiÃK
or 'Hi gravel drifted out from under lava
beds ur even on a gravel bank broken ;
down with dynamite he would nut bft
working a "natural bank." and so would
!.'â¢! be ci gaged In "hydraulic mining" and :
subject to tli" Caminetti law. The detini- 'â 
tions given by many mining authorities
have been compiled, but they vary and:
wcr<- not framed for legal use or with
the prtsÂ«-nt situation fn view. At the last
State miners' convention in Octrtber there
was a warm discussion for several hours,
over a resolution to have presented to
Congress ;>. Mil defining "hydraulic min
ing" as it has been defined by the State
Legislature, but the matter was dropped.
Uast fall the Anti-Debris Association
brought the issue up by beginning pro- j
ceedings fur the first time against drift
mines hi Nevada County using water j
under pressure on gravel taken out, but
the suits were dropped.
SOUTH OF THE CHANNEL.
Increased Activity Noticeable in the
Manufacturing District.
The coming war cry with other local
Improvements has givpn an impetus to
all branches of manufacturing on the
south sidr of the channel.
The Potrero district, with its varied in
dustrial branches, has assumed an active
phase during the past few weeks. The
Rolling Mills, whose work was almost at
a .standstill, has received some weighty
contracts for work. Among these is one
order from the San lLateo and San Fran
cisco Kailroad Company for rails for its
read from Thirtieth street to Baden, over
which a double track will be laid. This
improvement is only a continuation of
what the company has already done in
the betterment of its road within the
city limits, where the heaviest steel rails
known on street railroads have been sub
stituted for the light ones formerly laid.
Following this, the Southern Pacific
Company has ordered rails for its road
at South San Francisco, where a short
cut is being made between this city and
San Jose. To get the rails out on time
that of Marie Gordon, and a graciously
lovely Recamier loaned by Mrs. M. H. de
Young.
The ohlna and sliver have their share of
worshipers. There are beautiful pieces
of each; wonderful old Nurnberg wed
ding cups, chastely simple pieces of Span
ish sliver, historical bits from famous
European collections; among them that
of Selliere, and a delicately pink Le Boeuf
whose mate adorns le petit Trianon.
The exhibition is well arranged and
worthy of the setting, the Hopkins In
stitute affords. It is not so large that
one tires of beautiful things, and It con
tains so much that Is interesting and such
a variety of works of artâ and of nature,
for both these contracts, a force of 200
men has been set to work during the
week.
At the Union Iron Works additional
hands have been put on to fit out the
Spreckels tugboats recently purchased by
the Government for use in this harbor.
This brings the working force of the yard
up to 3500 men all told.
Kniglits in Drill.
The drill corpsâ fifty strong, the officers
of commandery and drill corps being Immi
nent Commander J. M. Peel, Generalis
simo C. L. Patton, Captain General J. C.
Campbell, William Edwards, commandant
drill corps; J. H. Aiken. senior warden;
R. McMillan, junior wardenâ gave a pre
paratory -drill at the Mechanics' Pavilion
last night. Since the commandery was
organized in 1883 It has been the custom
to give an annual review and drill to the
Grand Commandery of California. This
review and drill will be given at the Me
; chanics' Pavilion on Saturday evening,
April 22. Two companies of full strength
under the command of Colonel William
j Edwards and Colonel C. H. Murphy will
pass in review and give fancy exercises
before Flight Eminent Grand Commander
of the State George D. Metcalf of Oak
land. The evolutions will be witnessed
! by Major General J. H. Dickinson, Briga
dier General R. H. Warfield, Colonel
James F. Smith, First Regiment. N. G. C.
j and will be followed by a receptidon and
i dance. By reason of the prestige of the
Golden Gate Commandery it will be an
event in social and military circles of this
city.
Stationary Engineers Entertain.
The National Association of Stationary-
Engineers held its annual entertainment
and ball lust evening in California Hall.
and, as usual, met with success. The
little hall was well crowded, and the pro
gramme for the entertainment contained
many excellent and no poor features. It
was as follows:
Vocal solo, Miss Ruth Gordon; song and
dance. "Rastus," Little Miss Zela Cook;
vocal duet. "1 Live and Love Thee," Mr.
and Mrs. W. Epperly; banjo solo. Miss
Ruth Bockius; vocal solo, "Fleeting
Days." Mrs. Helen Parrlsh; clarionet solo,
"Crocus," George. X. Parrish; specialties,
Miss Victoria Orr; violin solo. Miss Ruth
Gordon; piano trio. Professor L.. Mrs C
and Miss Violet Reynaurd; vocal solo.
Mrs. F. Bolio. Quartet, mandolin and
zither; mandolins, Misses E. Konrad and
R. Dore; zithers. Misses L. and H. Korn
meyer; recitation. M;.-=s L. Trautner.
The entertainment committee consisted
of the following members: W. T. Bonney,
H. K. Malech, George R. Parrish. Owen
Peggy, Hermann Conrad and William
Roberts.

inst., left an estati valued nt $6000.
Wont to Disincorporate.
The directors of tho Co-operative Im
provement Company have petitioned the
Superior Court for permission to diss
the corporation. All of the debts of the
company have been settled.

GREAT THEATRICAL
TRIPLE ALLIANCE
Frederick Warde, Louis James
and Mme. Rhea to
Join Forces.
They Will Tour the West in Shake
spearean and Classic
Drama.
Arthur Warde, the son of Frederick
Warde, the tragedian, who was for many
years associated with Louis James, is the
authority for the confirmation of the re
port that has been in circulation for
some time past that his father, Louis
James and Madame Rhea will next season
tour the South and West as a great triple
star combination. Mr. Warde is at pres
ent in the city in advance of Marie Jan
sen.
When interviewed relative to the ru
mor of the alliance between the two act
ors and actress, Mr. Warde said:
"Yes, it is true. Wagrenhals and Kem
per, the present managers of James, are
the promoters of the enterprise. I an.
authorized by my father to announce thin
as a fact. The company will organize
in New York next season and will tour
the West and South. The alliance is
only for one season."
When asked why the combination
would not appear in the East, Mr. Wards
replied:
"The East does not support tragedy and
melodrama, and the West does."
Warde and James are admitted to be
able representatives of the old and new
schools of Shakespearean and classic
drama, and their alliance with Mme.
Rhea v.ill be the strongest of its kind
since the days of Booth, Barrett and Mod

Memorial Day.
At a preliminary meeting- held in the
hall of Lincoln Post, G. A. R., it was
decided to call a convention of delegates
from all the local Grand Army posts for
Eva: Every afternoon about 5 o'clock I begin to gape and
yawn and I yawn and gape and yawn till bed-time. If
I nip one yawn in the bud the next follows almost im-
mediately and is bound to be a regular jaw-breaker.
r.-AY: I had such an experience myself one time, and I re-
member asking the doctor whether one should try
to keep from yawning, and he said no, that the act of
gaping gives to the blood more oxygen and acts by
mechanical pressure on the heart and lungs. If one
has chronic gaping it is a symptom which should cause
the affected one to look 'after her general health, for
it is a sure sign that something is wrong.
MRS. Moore s It is pretty well understood that yawning is an
ailment that comes from indigestion or lack of tone in
the system and may be cured by taking a Ripans
Tabule before retiring. After a few days of this treat-
ment the tendency will disappear.
the purpose of making arranprrments for
the proper observance <*f Memorial Day
this year The representation in thÂ«

While trying to drive across the railÂ«

William JVicLaughli'i were thrown on
their heads by the collision of a switch
engine and the rear of thÂ«- -'agon. Sex

Mclaughlin suffered bodily bruises and
an abrasion of the forehead. Ho was re

ter being treated was able to go to bis
home at 27 Geneva street.

TO SEEK FAME

Believes In the Statement of
Joaquin Miller Made
Years Ago.
TelU Why She Thinks It Is Best
to Gain a Reputation in
Europe.
Oakland Office Fan Francisco Call,
Broadway, April 16.
Miss Ray Frank is to leave Oakland in
a few days to take up a permanent resl
h. London, and In that great city
<>w a literary career. Probably no
!i speaker and writer in California
r< r known than Miss Frank, who
la r cltve' Mt of the principles
of thfl Hebraic faith, and who has had
conferred u;.<>n her by her church honors
I by no other woman.
The distinction awarded Miss Frank at
go three years ago was equivalent
i<> tin rank of an ordained rabbi.
< >n being asked for the reason for her
pieference for London over any of the
cities of thr New World in which to en
llterary carver Mrs. Frank gave the
fol}owii - . tion:
II Is n ' so much n matter of prefer
13 London is the een
lettera for the English speaklnsr
. j. sslbly â¢ -â  i.-s as well
-â¢â  literature in its highest meaning
Is univi
It is reported that years a^o Joaquln
Miller, then beginning his career aa a
poet, said he would work for recognition
In London; if hr> attained It there,
America would give it to him. Since
that time America's valuation of the
stamp of foreign recognition has greatl}'
Increased, a fact evidenced by the exo
dus Europeward of all Americans de
sirous of winning something more than
compliments for their efforts in art and
letters.
Institutionally we are democratic;
esthetlcally we defer to the Ider cul
ture.
A half century ago the number of
aspirants was smaller; furthermore, na
tional youthfulness prevented us from
seeing with unprejudiced e>vs the wis
dom of comparing ourselves with an
older â¢. ;ikure: therefore In he past,
home recognition was more easily won.
To-day, In addition to the facts that cur
writers are multitudinous, our oomparl
sons broader, is another, peculiarly
American and altogether detriment ii to
the interests of true artâ literary neu
rastheniaâ verbal sensationalism. Thli

California it might be said, i lentially

LYNN INSANE
A LONG TIME
Six Men From Agnews
Testify of Former
Madness.
Evidence That May Bear on the
Story Related by
Griffiths.
Judge Ogden Orders the Prisoner to
Be Taken to Uklah
Asylum.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
90S Broadway, April 16.
John W. Lynn la insane. This fact was
decided to-day by half a dozen of the at
tendants at Agnews Asylum, who knew
, Lynn while ho was at work at that insti
tution, and who stated that in their
opinion he has been a crazy man for a
lonp time.
This vexed insanity cn.Â«e was brought
up before Judge Ogden This morning, be
ing the fourth day during which ex
'â  perts and others have been contradicting
: each other over the symptoms of the
' would-be wife murderer.
Drs. Rucker and Dunn maintained that
i Lynn was shamming, and In support of
' their views they laid before the court
' some detailed accounts of their scientific
| tests. On the other hand. Drs. Barber and
Rabe, who recommended Lynn's commit
ment declared that their finding was
..met. Dr. L. F. Herrick of Stockton
Indorsed the hitters' views.
When court opened this morning five
attendants from the Agnews Asylum
staff appeared before Judge Ogden, and
their evidence was regarded as conclu
sive They all agreed that Lynn was on
the verge of insanity when he Berved at
the asylum, and they gave many interest
ing incidents in his career at that msti-
C. E. Wilson said that he was the con
fidential agent of Lynn in the asylum,
and that wnile there he wrote not less
than twenty letters to Lynn's relatives
at his dictation. The letters were so in
coherent mat Wilson knew uiev were
not the product of a sane mind. On one
occasion Lynn asked Wilson to kill him.
Lynn said:' "You are my friend. Wilson.
I "want you to kill me." 'You are
crazy," replied Wilson. "No one knows
it better than I do." replied Lynn.
.h.s.-ph Dawd said that Lynn believed
he had been frequently assaulted by his
wife with a knife in the presence <<f their
child. Lynn confided to Dawd that he
had choked his wife severely and that
he thought the best thing to do to end
his misery would be to kill the woman.
!1. W. McCabe, E. Ingraham and H. A.
Braden of Agnews all asserted that they
thought Lynn unbalanced mentally.
In ordering Lynn's commitment. Judge
Ogden said: "I confess I have grave
doubts as to the mental condition of this
man Lynn, but I am bound to place much
confidence in the testimony of these last
witnesses, who are in daily contact with
insane patients and who unanimously be
lieve this patient insane. As a general
rule, I give little, credence to a plea of'
insanity which is so suddenly made and
which is simultaneous with the commis
sion of an awful crime. Had it not been
for the testimony of these last witnesses.
I should hesitate to commit him, but
would hastily send him to the Police
Court, where trial is awaiting him. The
testimony of Drs. Dunn and Rucker had
great weight, but it is not sufficient to
overcome the preponderance of evidence
adduced this morning. Nothing remains
for me to do but to order him into the
custody of the State Hospital, and ac
cordingly I will send him to Ukiah."
GETTING AFTER
THE UNIVERSITY
Eastern Prohibitionists Fight
ing the Liquor Trade
in Berkeley.
Make Sweeping Charges Against
Faculty, "Frat-a" and the Viti
cultural Department.
BERKELEY, April 16.â New York \
Voice, which has recently been conduct-
Ing a vigorous campaign against liquor- j
drinking at Yale, has turned its guns on
the University of California. . It makes >
sweeping charges against members of the
faculty for having wagons of liquor-sell
ers stop regularly at their doors, against
student clubs and fraternities, in many of
which, the Voice asserts, liquor is used
without stint, and against the viticultural
department of the university ' *or serving
the wine and brandy business."
Berkeleyans do not deny the statement
of the Voice that liquor is delivered at
the homes of university professors. Near
ly all of the liquor business of Berkeley
la done through Oakland, and the deliv
ery of liquor in Berkeley has never been
held to be in contravention of the mile
limit law. "The whole question of pro- |
hibition is involved," declared a member
of the faculty, In regard to the Voice's ;
attack. "It is the professors' own busi
ness whether they want liquor at their j
homes or not, and the university is In no
wise involved."
The university people do not take very j
kindly to the Voice's attack. Several
weeks ago the Voice requested President i
Martin Kellogg to arrange for the distri- !
bution of its prohibition literature at
Berkeley; but President Kellogg, who is I
a Yale man and heartily disapproved the
Voice's method of attack on his alma !
mater, curtly refused. Another member j
of the faculty at Berkeley particularly i
resents the Voice's attack upon the viti- I
cultural department of the university. ,
Thp paper's criticism Is as follows: " I
M.-anwhtle the university viticultural .com
mission was allowed fisoo per year from the
pneral fundâ money that would otherwise ro ;
to instruction in the art* and sciences, library, ;
labratory. eacâ which to serve the wine
and brandy business.
It is confidently expected that the next I>k- !
islature will apportion at leaÃt BSQO a year to
carry on the work for Bacchus that was done
Wil* y y HH e vltiru ltural Commission for
HS.OOO a year-the latter having cost the State
$221,000 in the fourteen years of Its existence. i
According to a member of the faculty !
the attack of the Voice is an attack upon
the wine Industry of California. "Viti
culture, he says, "as one of the largest
industries of the State, receives attention '
from our Agricultural Department, and
vineyardtsts as well as other agricultur
ists, receive assistance."

WHITE WINGS
FOR SUMMER
| The California Yacht Club
Formally Opens Its
Season.
Many Gayly Decked Craft Are
Placed on Exhibition
for Guests.
All the Fleet Will Follow the Com
" modore's Flag This
Afternoon.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call, i
908 Broadway, April 10.
The California Yacht Club is the first i
:of the yachting organizations to begin
work for the season of 1898. Last night
the members of the club were present in !
i force at the clubhouse on Oakland Creek,
near the Webster-street bridge. The hos
pitalitles of the club were generously ex- j
; tended to all the. visiting yachtsmen and j
i a pleasant evening was enjoyed.
The San Francisco Yacht Club was rep-
I resented by Commodore Dr. T. L.
: Hill's Cygnus (flagship), Vice-Commodore
; George T. S. White's sloop Will-o'-the-
Wisp and Louis Sutherland's Catherine, j
Sappho, formerly flagship of the Pacific '
Yacht Club, but now owned by Lewis Q. |
Haven, who was elected a member of the i
San Francisco Yacht Club at the last ;
meeting of the directors, is lying at an- i
chor in the creek.
The jinks was under the management of
Mi ssrs. Homer. E. N. Walter and S. S.
Marshall. After opening remarks by !
: Commodore J. Lancaster and Yon
; Schmidt the following programme was i
â  rendered: Solo, E. N. Johnston; trom- !
bone solo, J. Laughland; tenor solo, Jules
Simonsen; Mist Quartet; recitation. Harry '
Gray, and banjo solo, Mr. Simonsen. I

and a piano solo by Thomas Bennett !

Master's Troubles." A vocal solo by Mr.
: Brooks, specialties by George Ryan, solos 'â¢
by K. 8. Dowdle, Arthur Beeman and' Mr.
Armstrong, banjo selections by Messrs.
Black and S. P. BalÂ»cock brought an en

A MAN DIED
IN HIS ARMS
Bishop Rowe Sends News of
the Hardships Existing
in Skaguay.
Union Hospital Started That Needs
Funds to Carry on Its
Wfcrk.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April 16.
Bishop Rowe of the Episcopal Church, j
who is at present in Alaska, has writ-
ten to Rev. F. J. Mynard, rector of St.
John's Church, a letter making an appeal
for help which will be read to the congre
gation to-morrow. The letter says in
part:
The people of Skaguay have been forced to
start an emcrgenry hospital, railed a union.
The need of it beggars description. It has
j aided and relieved many cases of the greatest
distress. The people have responded to the j
: cries and appeals to their humanity nobly.
Impressed with the importance of the lnsti
; tutiun the representatives of the public have
i asked me to take charge of it. and I have done
I It. They have transferred it all Into our hands.
! The emergency hospital is a simple ln B cabin
I thirty feet long and eighteen feet wide. One
room on the ground floor answers for kitchen
and cots; one room above, which is but the
half story or attic. In this room 1 found twelve
cots, and ten of them were occupied by men
in all stages of pneumonia and meningitis
Yesterday, while visiting it, a young man was
I brought in from the summit, eighteen miles
S on a sled, tied on to keep him from rolling off
; draggt*! over rocks and through mud ail the
j distance.
Last night I was with a man, who died in
my arms, from New Hrunswick, telling me
what to say to his father and mother and sls
. ters. It was a most sad, most pitiful sight
If the sickness li going to increase the a'n
i peal to our humanity cannot be ignored The
sick are absolutely friendless, helpless and
without a hospital would simply die by the
j way. We have one woman nurse, two men
and a cook in charge. The Skaguav doctors
! are attending for little or nothing, as' expenses
permit.
We must build an additionâ only of an In
expensive and temporary character. I am *o
lng to begin this immediately. The present ac
commodation is totally inadequate and unsuit
able.
We have assumed a great responsibility but
it Is an opportunity most Important. What I
want is this: Telegraph those facts to head
quarters, church papers, to any of our rirh
, church people and to Miss Emery, and say
we need money at once to carry on this work.

Catholic Truth Society.
OAKLAND, April 16.-Rev. P. F Yorke
will deliver an address before the as
sembly to-morrow afternoon at St Fran
cis Hall, at 3 o'clock. The meeting Is for
the purpose of organizing a brancu of the
Catholic Truth Society in this city The
aim of the organization is to disseminate
correct views regarding Catholic doctrine
and the duties of Catholics both with re
spect to their fellow citizens and to the
nation. This will be accomplished by
means of public lectures, writings and
conventions at stated Intervals, which
will be carried out by Catholic laymen
and women, as well as by the pastors of
the various churches of that denomina
tion.

OAKLAND, April 16.â Leonard Merrill
1 president of the California Christian En
deavor Union, arrived in the city to
nijsht and will address two rallies to
i morrow. The first will be held at the
; First Congregational Church at 3 o'clock
where there will be a ~athering of th<>
I Endeavorers in the central portion of the
city. At 5 o'clock a gathering will be
i held in the Brooklyn Presbyterian
Church, for the East Oakland young peo
ple. The coming State Convention will be
the theme, with definite announcement
as to entertainment, rates, programme
! and other matters of interest.

OAKLAND, April 16.â A. L. Stone, sec

Annexation Again in Question.
OAKLAND. April 16.â The suspense
over the validity of the recent annexa
tion is to be prolonged indefinitely. To
day Attorney General Fitzgerald filed a
motion for a new trial in the case set
tled by Judge Hall, giving a decision in
favor of the city. The insufficiency of
evidence to justify the decision; errors
in law occurring at the trial and except
ed to by the plaintiff, and because the
decision'of the court Is against the law.
are the grounds given for this move. If
a hearing is refused on the bill of excep
tions it will be appealed to the Supreme
Court.
JUDGE ALLEN ' EXPLAINS.
His Decision Only Partially Kills the
the Pool Ordinance.
OAKLAND, April 16.â Judge Allen says
that his decision dismissing the pool sell
ers from custody yesterday does not in
validate the whole ordinance, but only
the portion prohibiting persons from re
ceiving money to bet on the races. He
holds that the cigar men only act as
stakeholders for the race track gamblers
when placing their money on the races.
The judge says that the dismissals were
made with the consent of Deputy Dis
trict Attorney Moore. Mr. Moore is of
the opinion that the ordinance is entirely
knocked out. Its main purpose was to
prohibit the existence of pool rooms
where money was received by the agent
to place on races at the track, and a3
this is the section declared invalid, the
whole ordinance practically falls to the
ground.
Stricken Blind in the Night.
OAKLAND. April 16.â The case of a
woman in the East who was reported
this week as having gone to bed at night
with good eyesight and woke in the
morning to find herself blind, has a par
allel in East Oakland in F. Schimmel
pfennig, a well-known capitalist. He
aw >kt* Tuesday morning about 4 o'clock,
and not seeing the light that usually
burns all night he roused his wife to
learn why the light was out. When told
that it was burning he realized that his
sight was gone. He lives on Shuey ave
nue, Frultvale.
Refused to Appoint Mrs. Price.
OAKLAND, April 16.â Judge Ellsworth
refused to appoint Mrs. Louisa E. Price as
executrix of the will of her late husband.
Elijah Price, who died in Berkeley Oc
tober 5, IW, but appointed C. P. Gibbon,
the sole executor. In doing this the court
stated that there was no doubt in his
mind that Mrs. Price had attempted to
commit fraud by hiding the will which
favored the others at her" expense, and
she was not a proper person to handle
the estate.
The Child Pianiste.
OAKLAND, April 16.â Little Paloma
Schramm, the wonderful child pianiste
and composer, who has created such a
great impression wherever she has been
heard, will give two recitals in the Uni
tarian Church, Fourteenth and Castro
streets, in this city, one on Tuesday oven
ing and the other at a matinee Wednes
day at 3:30 o'clock. She will be assisted
by Florence Scarborough, contralto, of
Los Angeles.
VAURAKY'S CAPTURE.
Learned Officer Arrests Two School-
boys for "Assaulting" Him.
Officer P. G. Vauraky. the gifted lin
guist of the Police Department, won new
laurels tor himself last night by captur
ing two 15-year-old school boys who im
pugned his nationality. The brave police
man guards the property of citizens in
the Western Addition, and while patrol
ing his beat, memorizing a new language,
he came upon Willie K. Morris and Solo
mon Rubin playing about the street.
He ordered them to quit their rollick
ing:, and upon their refusal made a rush
and caught them both. He dragged the
youngsters to a patrol box and informed
Lieutenant Birdsell that he "vanted de
patroolawagen." "With a sigh Driver
Murphy drove for many blocks into the
fog district, blessing the policeman for
the hill climbing he encountered.
Vauraky told the officer who accom
panied the wagon that the boys had in
sulted him and to place a charge of com
mitting a nuisance and assaulting an offi
cer against them. With these serious
crimes against thorn the youngsters were
removed to the City Prison. Desk Ser
geant Bidwell had to bend over his desk
t'> Bee them, and was surprised to he;w"
that they had assaulted a minion nf the
law. Thinking there was some mistake.
he Informed Lieutenaiit Birdsell, and tho
latter detailed Sergeant Blank to find
Vauraky and see how badly injured he
was. Instead at me^tiner a dilapidated
officer, Blank found Vauraky nursing his
wounded feelings. In three or four lciii
guages he tried to explain to his superior
how he was insulted. After admonish
ing him not to be over-sensitive in future,
Blank returned to headquarters just in
time to see the school boys being released
for their grave offense.
A PIONEER GOES TO REST.
Last Sad Rites Over the Body of
Arthur B. Stout.
The gray-haired members of the Society
of California Pioneers assembled in their
hall yesterday afternoon to participate
in the last solemn rites over the body of
Dr. Arthur Breese Stout, one of the old
est members, and a man who, in his
long residence here, endeared himself to
all with whom he came in contact.
The impressive services were read by
Rev. S. H. Willey, who, with Dr. Stout,
embarked on the steamer California at
Panama on February 1, 1549. Cholera was
raging on the isthmus at that time, and
shortly after the vessel cleared away it
broke out among the passengers. With
scarcely an hour's rest and no reward
â aye that from the knowledge of doing
good to his fellow men. Dr. Stout worked
night and day among the plague stricken
pasengers, and so succesful was he in his
efforts that not one life was lost on the
trip.
Arriving in this city he at once opened
up the practice of medicine and for years
was one of the leading physicians in the
<ity. About ten years ago, however, he
lost his sight as the result of a surgical
operation, and being thus deprived of the
means of earning a livelihood he became
In very straitened circumstances, until
his friends, learning jf migfortunf,
had him removed to St. Luke's Hospital!
where he remained until the time of his
death.
The remains were taken to the Odd
Fellows' Cemetery, where they were
cremated in pursuance with the last
wishes of the deceased.
Fought Over a Woman.
Joe Marshall and Alex Spear became
involved in a row with Martin Smovich
early last night, and in the course of a
rather heated argument Smovich was
struck in the face by one of the men.
This settled matters for the time being',
and the injured man went home. The
other two, however, continued making
the rounds, and after having imbibed a
sufficient quantity from the cup that
Cheen felt in the humor of totally an
nihilating Smoylch. They called on him
at his boarding-house and again assault
ed him. He then picked up a soda water
bottle and struck Spear in the head with
it, inflicting an ugly wound on the fore
head. The three men were taken to the
California-street station and locked up
An Editor Married.
E. E. Curtis, night editor of the Asso
ciated Press, who is well known in Jour
nalistic circles, was quietly married on
last Tuesday evening to Miss Laura Mc-
Donough, an attractive brunette The
ceremony was performed at the home of
the bride's sister, Mrs. C. R. Trapo by
Rev. J. N. Beard, pastor of Grace Meth
odist Episcopal Church. The wedding was
private, only a few friends, besides rela
lives, being present. The bride was
handsomely attired in cream-colored silk
and carried a bouquet of white ro^es
After the ceremony a dinner was served
and later on the newly wedded couple de
parted to their own home.
Suicide of a Porter.
Otto Schwarke, a porter at the Del
Monte Hotel until a short time ago, com
mitted suicide at his room. 114 Fourth
street, yesterday afternoon, by taking
strychnine. He had roomed at the place
three days, and his dead body was found
by Justin Carroul, the proprietor of the
house. Schwarke was seen at the saloon
of Jacob Rumetsch yesterday morninK
and a barkeeper who waited upon him
said that he was under the Influence of
liquor. He was about 32 years old and
was a brother of William Schwarke of
the firm of Kuhls & Schwarke.
A Child Run Over.
About 3:30 yesterday afternoon the
two-year-old daughter of Mrs. Critten
den, residing at 236 Hickory avenue was
run over by a vegetable wagon driven by
a careless boy, and had her skuil irac
tured. The little one was conveyed Into
the house, and the physician attending
her fears for her recovery.

CAUGHT THE

lAlss Ellen Duane, a Plucky
Domestic, Captures a

Beat Him in His Desperate Fight
for Liberty and Held Him
Until the Police
Arrived.

terday. It involved special daring
on the part of the lady captress; a
mystery finally solved as to the iden
tity of the captive, and. last, the suc
cessful running down of an insidious
ly dangerous kind of a burglar â no
less than the bogus "gas inspector,''
who has been preying for weeks upon
unsuspecting householders on both
sides of the bay.

ineptly in tho employ of E. S. Rothchild.
at 2108 Jacks. m street, caught a burglar
yesterday. It was a burglar the police
have been hunting for several weeks with
their most skilled detectives, and it was
n great satisfaction to them to have the
man in custody, even though a woman
handed him over t<> them a prisoner. Miss
Dnane had a lively tussle with her cap
tive- before he surrendered, and she held

arrived. In the fight with the burglar for
Bupremacy Miss Duane nearly choked the
life out of the mini, who struggled with
her for freedom, and when she gave her
prisoner over to the police the burglar
was without a collar or tie. His shirt

was a physical wreck. "When the police
man arrived he had given in to the supe

sprawled on the door, tearful to move.
