she told of the capture. She la a sistrr
ol Policeman Morris Imam?, and she said
she was simply holding up the family
reputation for capturing offenders of the
law.
"There was a shoe peddler at the back
door trying to sell Katie McGivney, the
housemaid, a pair of sinus." she said. "I
h;i<l bought .i p.iir from him a few days
previously, and the kind he was trying to
sell her were n<>i the same nor as pood as
he had given me. To convince him of
that I went to my room to get them and
show him the difference. When I opened
the door I noticed a rocking chair near
the foot of the bÂ»-d moving. I thought it
strange, and looked to see what caused it.
and close to the rocker and just under
the fftf < â < >t of the bed was a man's tan-col
ored shoe.
"I looked under the bed and saw a man
there, and asked him what he was doing.
He replied that he was in the house to
examine the gas meter. I thought he was
in a strange place t"r that, and I ordered
him out. He refused to come, and I
caught hold of his foot and pulled him
half way from his hiding place, when he
promised that he would come out himself.
A.- soon as he was dear of the bed and on
his feet I caught him by the throat and
I held on. I called to Katie, hut she did
: not hear me until we had ncutlled out of
the. room and Into the hall. Then the
burglar threatened that if I did not let
him go he would throw me over the ban
ister. Katie heard us fighting in the hall,
: and she came and helped me.
"Then the Bhoe peddler came and of
j fered to help, but we were afraid he might
! have been an accomplice of the burglar,
and we would not let him near us or the
man. By that time Katie and I and the
burglar were down on the main floor.
The shoe peddler, to show his good faith,
went and got a young man to go for the
â  police, and about half an hour later the
â  patrol wagon arriveu and took the robber
away. H.> took $20 GO from a drawer in
my room, but he threw It out of his
pocket in the scuttle. I was afraid he had
got Mrs. Kothchlld's jewelry, and if it
was gone it might have been hard to
keep suspicion from either Miss McGivney
; or myself, and ] took good care that the
burglar did not get away. As luck would
, have it. he only got the little money we
had saved and which we kept in our
room."
The burglar is the one who has been
gaining admittance to the residences of
his victims under the pretext of being an
inspector of gas meters and gas regulators
in the employ of the Electric Gas Kegu
lator Company. During the past six
weeks numerous complaints have reached
tin: police of the operations of the bold
I burglar, and every effort was being made
i to capture him.
The prisoner is only a boy. He claims
he Is only 16 years of age and asks that
he be sent to the reform school Instead
of to a long term in State prison, fie
gives his nnme as Charles Grant, but
i hints that It 1b not correct. Cnarles Gar-
I land is believed by the police to be his
I true name, and they think that Mlnneap-
I oils Is his home. The prisoner, however.
â¢ says he is from Grand Rapids, and that
j previous to his coming to San Francisco
]he worked on a farm near that city. He
; claims he <;iin>' to this city early in Jan
j vary, and that he had 1160 when he ar
i rived. He claims he trl.d to get work,
! but was not successful, but the police say
j he was for a time employed in a Post
street restaurant. The prisoner Bays his
money dwindled down rapidly, and one
day. seeing the attractive posters an
nouncing the races across the bay, he
went to the race track and risked a few
dollars. He won and that started his
downfall. He kept on playing the races.
, Sometimes he won '.it oftener he lost,
I and he was 8008 Without money.
"I had to live," he mHL 1 could not
I get work, and I studied out a plan of
[burglary. I went to the gas company's
I office one day and got in conversation
With one of the clerk.-; about the gas reg
| ulators and managed to steal some of
1 their blank stationery. Armed with that
; I had no difficulty in getting into the
j houses of people and helping myself. I
' pawned the stuff I .stole for about $350
and put it all on the races. Of course I
j lost it all, and here I am. I was too suc
| cessful as a burglar and kept at It. I
did not intend to rob so many places
when I started out, hut when it came so
easy I kept on. and it was all for me ex-
I cltement of the race track.
"1 robbed a good many places In this
city In the disguise of a gas Inspector.
! I do not know the names of the people
who lived in the houses. 1 only picked
out the places that had the appearance
j of being the homes of wealthy persons
and I always got enough to pay me for
my trouble at each of them. I robbed
two places in Oakland and one In Ala
meda. The same gas certificates I carried
here admitted me across the : my t 0 ie
houses I tried.
"I walked into the house in which I was
caught by the side door, and there was
no one to stop me. if i im<l been ques
tioned I depended on my bogus creden
tials to carry me through. The servants
whom J expected to meet were engaged
with a peddler at the front of the house
when I entered, and when I heard the
girl come up the stairway I hid under the
bed, but she found me and gave me a
hard fight. As soon as she took hold of
mo I knew I was no match for her in a
fight, and she had the best of it from the
etart. I was fairly caught and I will
THE SAX FRAKCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1898,
take my medicine, though I wish to go
t<> the reformatory instead of the State
Prison for the sake of my relatives."
Among the residences robbed by Grant,
alias Garland, is that of H. F. A. Schuss
ler, 1905 Van Ness avenue, where about
â $1000 worth of jewelry was taken. That
was on March 25. On March 28 the resi
dence of Mrs. Hecht was entered by the
bogus gas inspector and about $300 worth
of goods taken. The same robber gained
entrances Into the residences of B. S.
Heller, 1501 California street, and J.
Koshland, ISOS Pine street.
W. E. H. Williams, the general mana
ger of the Electric Gas Regulator Com
pany, characterizes the certificate used
by Grant to obtain an entrance into the
houses that he has burglarized as a for
gery. It la the custom of the company to
issue cards of identification to its inspec
tors, and Grant had one of these, but he
managed to destroy it. The Inspectors
are also required to wear a badge, as this
ensures a double protection to the com
pany's patrons.
When arrested Gr*ant had upon him
one of the company's agreement blanks,
which is signed with the address of the
person making application for a regu
lator to be attached to their gas fixtures.
This agreement had upon it the name
of H. Lydan Sr., and upon the part of
the company was signed by R. F. Will*
iams.
Mr. Williams said: "Besides the card
of identification and the badge worn by
our employes, they are required to pre
sent the agreement blank which is
signed at our office by the person desir
ing the regulators attached. Any one
would know their own signature, and this
we do to prevent fakirs from passing
themselves off a.s our employes. I do
not know how the boy secured the agree
ment blank. We are continually -warn
ing our patrons to look out for these
fakirs, and we take every precaution that
we can to guard against them. Grant has
worked the same scheme at every house
that he has entered, and we have boon
trying for some time to catch him. We
were aware that he had a forged card
and had warned people against him."
PRECITA VALLEY CLUB.
A General Line of Improvements
Needed Along the Old
Creek Bed.
Nothing less than a general line of im
provement along the bed of the old Mis
sion creek will be acceptable to the resi
dents of the Precita Valley. The prop
erty owners through the improvement
club of that section, ask that the low
lying land and swamp be filled in to the
grade and proper sewers put into the
streets. This, with the extending of the
1 streets running north and south from
Twenty-ninth to the base of Bernal
Heights, will be acceptable. They want
Brewster, Joy, Hope, Wolf and Potrero
streets extended, graded and fixed in
such condition that the people living
thereon can get to and from their resi
dences into the streets that have rail
road accommodation. Families living on
these streets are compelled to place pipes
en the street for a water supply whloh
is obtained from private wells in the
vicinity, as the water company refuses
'to lay mains until such time as the
streets are graded.
Another complaint goes forth that the
children who live on the side of the hill
are compelled to walk a mile to the near
, est school building. A primary classroom
Is asked for at Potrero and Costa streets,
where these children could attend, but so
; far the Directors have turned a deaf ear
to the entreaties of the parents in this re
gard.
Somo of the streets are being paved
pi< c -i meal and are in a worse condition
than they were before they were com
menced. Bryant street Is instanced as
being one of those. Here the wooden
sever that answered a purpose has been
torn out and the sipage from the City
and County Hospital aft also from the
private residences is permitted to drain
; into a vacant lot, endangering the health
of the entire community. As a result of
this several suits are about to be com
menced against the city by residents of
the infected section. Scarcely a week
passes but a delegation from either the
I Supervisors or the Health Department
! from the City Hall visits the place In rÂ«
; sponse to a petition, but the visits are
; barren of any good that the people can
see so far.
Smarting under what they deem z.
wrong toward them as citizens and tax
payers, they are becoming terribly In
earnest In their protests for a general
line of Improvement right through the
entire valley.
JANITOR JORDAN PLEADS.
Guilty of Embezzling Money From
Letters, but Bore a Good Repu
tation Before That.
John W. Jordan, tho colored porter of
the Postofflce In the Custom House build
ing, was taken before United States Dis
trict Judge de Haven yesterday morning
to plead to the charge of embezzling a
valuable Jotter from the general delivery
department. He pleaded guilty, and in
troduced Rev. Dr. Andrews and several
others to testify to his previous good
reputation In mitigation of sentence.
Judge de Haven announced that he
would pronounce sentence next Wednes
day, and the prisoner was committed to
Jail until that time. Jordan Is only 29
years old and has a wife and two chil
dren. He had been in the employment of
the Postoffice for several years, but he
began stealing money out of letters only
two months ago. The letters he destroy
ed by burning them In the stove.
For the Orphanage.
The histrionic society of Trinity School
â will render Augustin Daly"s charming
comedy, "7-20-8," for the benefit of the
Maria Kip Orphanage, at the Bush Street
Theater, on Thursday evening. April 21,
and a matinee on Saturday, April 23. The
proceeds of the benefit will be devoted
to the liquidation of the debt on the new
homo at Lake street and Seventh avenue.
The little comedy which will be presented
is so well known as to need but little
comment, and the excellent cast which
ha.s been secured guarantees those who
attend will not only help along a worthy
cause, but will have an evening of un
ailoyed pleasure.
Injured by a Runaway.
Jacob Jacobs commenced suit yesterday
against Peter Tautphaus to recover $10,000
damages for personal Injuries received on
February 17 last. Jacobs was driving
along Pine street, when a runaway team
owned by the defendant collided with his
wagon and threw him from his seat.
Jacobs now claims damages for the In
juries he received, alleging that it was
due to the carelessness of one of Taut
phaus employes, who left the team un
hitched-
DEMOCRATS
MUST BOW
TO BUDD
Yesterday's Fight in
the State Central
Committee.
Harney Faction Wins the
Battle for Local
Supremacy.
Meeting Place of the Conven
tion Has Not Yet Been
Determined.
FUSION IS NOW FAVORED
A Committee for tho Good of the
Party Appointed to Adjust All
Differences.
Several disputed political questions
were definitely settled yesterday at the
meeting of the Democratic State Central
Commit te. It was demonstrated to the
entire satisfaction of a number of the
members of the local Democratic suicide
club that Governor Budd is still a factor
in the affairs of the party and that it
takes something more than a declaration
of intention to make a political boss.
For several days past the leaders of the
Sullivan wing of the local Democracy
have let it be known that they would
bring about a test vote at yesterday's
meeting for the purpose of settling once
for all the strength of the Harney Dem
ocrats in the Stato Committee. They
were as good as their word. The test
vote was taken and the Harneyitos won
out In the easiest kind of fashion and
with enough to spare to leave no doubt
in the minds of their opponents as to
what the future holds in store. It was a
Ralney day for the Sulllvanites.
To sum up the situation in a few words
it Is only necessary to say that all dis
puted questions have been turned over to
a committee of nine members of the State
Committee for adjudication. This sub
committee Is to be known as the Com
mittee for the Good of the- Tarty, and Is
composed of Chairman Alford. H. M.
Fitzgerald. Frank H. Gould, James^ H.
Budd Eugene N. Deuprey. Gavin McNab,
Ben M. Maddox, Charlea M. Cassia and
one member from south of the lehachapl
Hn.- not yet named. Into the hands of
this committee have been given not only
such manors as pertain to the good ol
the party " but also the very distressing
differences that are the rocks upon whidi
the local Democracy uaa split. Sn far
as results are concerned, the committee
Is to be considered as merely a necessary
formality No matter what Its report on
the various questions submitted to it
may be the result will be the same. The
forces Of Ralney and Harney. which are
the forces of Budd, will accept what suits
them when the report is presented to the
State Committee. TneM things being so
the shrewd ones anticipate an early
stampede of the Sullivan forces to the
slaXrds of their more forceful oppo-
n The" question of selecting a meeting
place for the State convention was not
settled Delegations from Santa Cruz,
Sacramento and San Jose were on hand
to urge the respective merits of their
towns There were also a number of cit
izens present to present the claims of ban
Francisco as a meeting place for the con
vention. It is the general impression that
when final action ta taken Santa Cruz
or Sacramento will be the place selected.
Boon after the committee convened
Chairman Alford announced the names
of the members of the Committee for the
Good of the Party, the appointment of
which was provided for at the last meet-
Ing of the State committee. The real
business of the day was begun by Bro
beck of San Francisco, who moved that
the six members who had been dropped
for the non-payment of assessments be
given until the next meeting to show
cause why they had not paid up in cash
or, in lieu of money, rendered the party
valuable service. This was opposed by
McNab. who was in favor of making
their dismissal final. Sammy Braunhart
arrayed himself on the side of McNab,
and "it at once became evident that here
was the first of the questions selected as
the excuse for a trial of strength be
tween the warring factions. The issue
was not left long in doubt. Governor
liudil and Major Harney came to the
support of Brobeck, with the result that
the whole matter was referred to the
Committee for the Good of the Party.
This was victory- No. 1.
John W. Mitchell then offered the fol
lowing resolution:
Resolved, That the time and place for holding
the State Convention be determined at a spe
cial meeting for this purpose, to be called by
tho chair; that the call for the said meeting
riMttry the members of the committee that at
this said rm-etlng of the committee this action
will be takr-n; that all localities desiring the
convention be and are hereby invited to send
representatives to this meeting to present the
claims and proposals of their localities.
Resolved further. That a special committee
of five members of this committee be author
ized to cnfer with representatives of the Pop
ulist and Silver Republican parties, with the
view of obtaining a concert of action as to
the time and place of holding the State con
ventions of the said parties.
Cassin, Ostrom and Deuprey opposed
tho resolution or. the ground that the part
that related to the Populist and Silver Re
publican parties appeared to be a fusion
proposition. Governor Budd wanted to
know if the Democratic party had ever
been able to carry the State without the
aid of the Populists and the Independent
Republicans. Chairman Alford surren
dered the gavel in order to take the floor
in support of the resolution. When the
question was finally put the resolution
was adopted. Here was victory No. 2.
Frank H. Gould called attention to the
fact that many county conventions would
be held before the State convention. In
order to settle all doubts a-s to the basis
of representation he offered the follow
ing resolution, which was adopted:
Resolved, That the basis of representation
in the next Democratic State Convention be
llxed at one for each county and one for each
200 votes cast for William J. Bryan at the
last general election.
McGee then offered the following:
Whereas, At the meeting of the Democratic
State Central Committee held two years ago
for the purpose of Issuing the call for the
State Convention, the time of the committee
was consumed in the consideration of the dis
agreements of the San Francisco Democracy,
then in a disorganized and disrupted condi
tion, and In determining which of rival claim
ants should receive the recognition of the State
Committee, and
Whereas, It is claimed that the same con
ditions which confronted the State Committee
two years ago again prevail in San Francisco,
and the same Issues will have to be determined
by the committee; therefore, be it
Resolved, That the chairman of the Demo
cratic State Central Committee Is hereby au
thorized and Instructed to appoint a commit
tee of seven members of the committee who
are therehv authorized. Instructed and em
powered to investigate the conditions of the
San Francisco Democracy, and to report to the
Btata Committee at Kb next meeting with a
recommendation as to what should be the
action of the committee.
As this was conceded to be the real fight
of the day as far as the local factions
were concerned. It was deckled to take
a recess until 2:30 o'clock, in order to give
both sides time to bring up their reserves
and arrange the order of battle. When the
committee reconvened there was some
preliminary skirmishing, and then the
first big gun was fired by the Governor,
who announced that he could not see the
necessity of the appointment of another
committee when It would be the simplest
matter In the world to refer the matter
to the Committee for the Good of the
Party A motion to lay the resolution on
the table was lost. A motion was then
made to refer the subject matter of the
resolution to the Committee for the Good
of the Party. This was ably seconded by
Major Harney. who confessed to a feeiing
of modest pride because of the fact that
he is the chairman of the local committee
representing the "true and only Demo
cratic party of San Francisco."" McNab
and Braunhart threw themselves Into the
breach, but the tide of battle was too
strong for them, and after an exchange
of personalities the question was put and
the motion was carried by an overwhelm
ing majority. This ended the fun. and
the committee adjourned to meet on the
last Saturday in May.
RACING SEASON SIXTY DAYS.
Supervisors' Committee Decide Upon
a Report to That Effect.
After being under consideration for
more than two months the period of the
racing season within the city and county
of San Francisco was decided yesterday
by the special committee of the Board
of Supervisors, to whom the matter nad
been referred.
There was under consideration the res
olution offered by Supervisor Clinton fix
ing tho neriod at forty-eight days. H. j.
Crocker appeared before the committee
on behalf of the Pacific Jockey Club and
argued for an extension of the season.
He declared that the club was in favor
of the abolition of the poolrooms, but
did not think that a short season of rac
ing in this city would have the effect of
closing them, aa races could be run at
Oakland, San Rafael and other points.
After some further discussion between
the members of the committtee, which
consisted of Supervisors Clinton, Smith
and Rivers, it was decided by a vote of
two to one to extend the racing season
to sixty consecutive days in each year,
exclusive of Sundays. Smith voted
against the resolution, which will be re
ported to the Supervisors on Monday.
NO KLONDIKE FOR HIM.
Thomas J. Murphy, Driver of a
Brewery Wagon, Meets With
a Misfortune.
Thomas J. Murphy, the driver of a
wagon for the Jackson Brewery, met with
a serious accident yesterday morning. He
had driven his team to a saloon at Eighth
and Market streets, and after delivering
his beer .lumped on the wagon. His whip
fell to the ground, and in doing so struck
one of the horses, and the team started
off. Murphy, in attempting to jump on
his seat, slipped and fell, his right leg
extending under the wheels, which passed
over It.
The team ran as far as Market and Mc-
Allister streets, where it was stopped.
Murphy was taken to the Receiving Hos
pital, where Dr. Well found that he had
sustained a compound comminuted frac
ture of the leg. Murphy had made prepa
rations to leave soon for the Klondike, as
he was the winner of the first prize in thu
Post's contest.
ALL CONTRIBUTE
TO THE FESTIVAL
Eastern Stars Will Hold Fairs
in All Parts of the
State.
Sin Jose Gives Liberally to the
Widows' and Orphans'
Home.
From all directions come flattering
reports of the efforts being made to raise
funds for the proposed Masonic Home for
Widows and Orphans at Decoto. The
chapters of the Eastern Stars will hold
fairs In their respective localities and
have appointed of the or
der in the various jjlaces selected: Liv
ermore. Mrs. Laura J. Barker; Clover
dale, Mrs. Sarah A. Baer; Redding, Mrs.
Nellie I,e Febvre; Colusa, Mrs. Lillian
Jackson; Lakeport, Mrs. J. S. Emerson-
Healdsburg, Mrs. Clara I. Gray; Pacific
Grove, Mrs. Sylvia O. Hamilton; Ne
vada City, Mrs. Mary E. Parker,; Fresno,
Mrs. Margaret Games; San Diego, Mrs!
Georgiana Polhamus; Gait. Mrs. Amanda
A. Latourette; Pomona, Mrs. Nora 11.
Hlnman; Lincoln, Mrs. Lottie Allen.
The ladies of Durant Lodge No. 268,
Berkeley, met last Thursday afternoon
and selected the following ladies to op
erate a photograph booth and sell pic
tures of local interest: Chairman, Mrs.
Â«'. M. Hunt; vice chairman, Mrs. F. M.
Berryman; secretary, Miss Hunt.
The sale of flowers, which will begin
next Wednesday, is expected to aid mate
rially in swelling the funds for the home.
Twenty lambs, decorated with Masonic
emblems, have been promised by Phillip
Selbel of the Clay street market.
The members of the local committee
are meeting with continued success. P.
C. Hale and C. L. Pat ton went among
the merchants on upper Market street
yesterday and secured about $400. The
Emporium headed the list with $10#. This
was followed by Hale Bros, with the
same amount. Will <fc Finck, Mr. Lubin
of Welnstock. Lubin & Co.. M. Johnson
of Johnson's restaurant, Mr. Strauss of
Kohlberg, Strauss & Frohman, all do
nated liberally.
The executive committee has decided to
allow any one to use the season tickets.
The tickets were intended to be used only
by the individual purchasing the same.
Under the decision of the committee sea
son tickets are now transferable and will
be accepted at the door.
From San Jose comes the report, which
is headed by Colonel A. K. Whitton, that
the friends of the order are responding
liberally both in the making of donations
and taking of tickets. The following is

SOCIETY AND THE STAGE.
Both Well Represented at the Benefit
for the Eye and Ear Hospital.
Society and the Stape joined hands last
evening at thf residence of Mrs. R. Jen
ning for the purpose of devoting their
talent towards increasing the fund for
the erection of a new ward at the Cali
fornia Eye and Ear Hospital on Sutter
street.
If numbers count the object in view is
to be shortly realized, as the entertain
ment was a success in this particular, as
in many others. The exact amount real
ized on the venture ia not as yet definite
ly known, but it is calculated that many
v. golden eagle passed into the hands of
the doorkeeper.
The programme consisted of a little of
everything .from a theatrical standpoint.
and way of amusement, and many pro
fessional actors were seen to good advan
tage in original sketches. The Tivoli
Opera House was well represented in
Edwin Stevens and Miss Edith Hall, and
others who endeavored to keep up their
reputations as fun makers off as well us
on the stage. . .
The programme was as follows: btring
solo, by Chinese dressed in native cos
tume; a Shakespearean sketch, E.
Pauhung; Japanese folk song, Miss
Anna Shepherd; Scotch song, "From
Under My Pladie," W. Balnavus; Rus
sian recitation. Mrs. Rennebone; Indian
song Mrs. John Loffley; national and
patriotic airs, Alfred Wilkic accompa
nist Miss May Moroney; Hawaiian na
tive' solo, Mrs. Turner; Spanish Sere
nade M. Y. Ferrer; original sketch, Ed
win Stevens, assisted oy Madame Mon
tague- Scotch songs, Mrs. Van Brunt,
assisted by Miss Henry; German spe
cialties Miss Edith Hall; Irish folk
song. Miss Ella McCluskey.
The parlors were beautifully decorated
with llags representative of all nations,
evergreens, flowers and exotic growths.
Over the stairway, midway between the
first and second floors, was erected a
magnificent arch composed of a combina
tion of flowers and ferns forming the
letters and spelling the name of the Cal
ifornia Eye and Ear Hospital.
The principal interest in the entertain
ment seemed to center in the Chinese
performers, who received loud and ap
preciative applause for their donations to
the general fund of merriment.
A Small Landslide.
A small landslide occurred yesterday at
Emigrant Gap, which destroyed about
forty feet of snow sheds, but did no fur
ther damage. No 2 of the westbound o\Â«r
land was delayed about an hour in con
sequence. *

The Managers of the Omaha Exposition Are Gathering the Pictures of Forty-five Typical Beauties From AH Over the Western States to Get a Composite Photograph That May Be
FORTY-FIVE nf thÂ« most heauti
fttl women of the West are to mn
tribute a share of their liveliness
to a composite photograph, from
which is to be made the picture of
a woman's fate that is to appear
in bas-relief on the obverse side of the
gold, silver and bronze medals by
which the Omaha Trans- Mississippi and
International Exposition will reward its
exhibitors ;;r,<t commemorate its own
successful existence.
Not one Eastern face will lend tin
grace of its pr< sence to this galaxy of
feminine charms, for the idea la to have
the type pr sent* i of a distinctively
Western character, which, while it will
detract nothing from its beauty, will
add greatly to its value from a strictly
scientific point <â !" view.
The plan of t liÂ« - directors of the ex
position has h>- ( -n to call upon the vice
[denta of the exposition of those
Stairs and Territories which have Riven
their enterprise official recognition for
â  â  photographs of two of the most
Mful women "f their section <>f the
â¢ "untry. Some of the gentlemen upon
whom this demand has been made have
shifted the burden of responsibility
from their own shoulders to those of a
board of judges, thus opening a beauty
competition which lias overwhelmed
each unfortunate present day Paris
â with tidal waves of photographs
and troubles innumerable. Others
have risen to the occasion and,
without fear or favor, have
themselves selected the specimens
of fr-minine loveliness which they
thought best Btted to 1i!l the require
ments of the unique Id* a. ..
To this latter class belongs R. Hall
BfcCormiek of Chicago, who assumed
bis portion of the responsibility
THE CALL Sunday Edition
â¢without the slightest, fear of
belrlg either gainsaid or criti
i ized. His selections were Mrs. J.
Ogden Armour and Mrs. H. C. Chat
field Taylor, of his own city, each rec
ognized as a representative of a very
high type of beauty, and each holding
rank as a social leader, and identified â¢
with one of the most -prominent fami
lies of the place.
Judge Neville of North Platte, Nebr.,
is also self-poised and courageous, and
has decided without any o.utside assist
ance that the charming Miss Maye
O'Shea of Lincoln and the equally fas
cinating .Miss Nettie Harmer of "Syra
cuse are Nebraska's two loveliest
young women. L. Bradford Prince of
Santa Fe, N. Mr-x.. has sent in the pho
tographs of Miss Adeline O'Luna of Al
buquerque and Miss Cynthia Bra'dshaw
of Paradise Valley; John Doniphan of
St. Joseph, Mo., has selected Miss
Josephine Stanacker of his own city
and Miss Lillian Duncan; W. H. Suth
erlin of Helena, Mont., has forwarded
photographs of Miss Harriet Wal
dorf of Dillon and Miss Leo
nora Robinson of Bozeman; S.
J. T. Johnson of Corsiana, Tex.,
has given 'the beauty prize to
Miss Florence Tucker and Miss Ida
May Archer; Edward F. Bishop of Den
ver, Colo., has picked out Miss Alice
Richards of Red Band and Miss Maggie
E. Blakeslee of Denver; Frank H. Pea
vey of Minnesota has given the palm to
Miss Alice Adrian of Minneapolis and
Miss Elizabeth Dibble of Marshall, and
George W. Parsons . of Los Angeles,
Cal., has partly finished his extremely
difficult taskâ difficult, since there is an
embarrassment of riches in the Golden
State) in the way of ; - really beautiful
girlsâ by dispatching to Omaha the
portrait of Miss Anna J. Reuler of Po
mona, a lovely girl who. well merits
the distinction which is hers.
Those of the Commissioners who have
been unwise enough , to .take the public
into their confidence have plunged
themselves 1n.t0.-a ge,a of troubles. which
Used on a Medallion to Commemorate Nebraska's Great Celebration.
SAN FRANCISCO, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1898
has come near to drowning them. Pho
tographs of every imaginable type of
feminine loveliness and unloveliness
have poured in upon them, accompa
nied, in many cases, by letters from
male relatives or friends which were
either wheedling, or threatening, or
both.
One State Commissioner sent in a
picture by the next mail after he re
ceived the directors' request. It proved
to be that of a decidedly ugly and ma
ture person, with no claims whatever
to Consideration from the noint of view
of a "beauty contest," and the direc
tors felt sure that " mistake had been
made by the sender, who had doubt
less inclosed the wrong photograph in
the hurry of sending off his mail.
A letter embodying this idea was
written him by the secretary, and
brought a response that no mistake
whatever had occurred, but that in the
Commissioner's estimation the lady
was by all odds the handsomest woman
in the State. So remarkable did this
seem that a little pains was taken to
find out additional particulars in snch
a peculiar case of "beauty blindness,"
and the whole matter was satisfactor
ily explained by the discovery that the
lady was the affianced wife of the loy
ally prejudiced gentleman.
Over in Nevada, where . pretty girls
are delightfully numerous. Colonel H.
B. Maxson has originated a plan which
gives to each county a proportionate
chance of supplying the ultimate com
posite of the medal with some portion
of its loveliness. In all Navada will
send forty-seven photographs of her
beauties to Omaha, and the choice of
the most beautiful two will be left to
an impartial individual who lives at a
safe distance from the defeated candi
dates.
One may judge of the interest taken
in the Sagebrush State in this matter
by the fact that in Humboldt County,
â¢where only 823 votes were cast at the
last electioi^ 1351 votes turned, out to
express their very decided opinions on
the important question of wno are the
pettiest two women among the many,
pretty women of that favored county.
In Washoe County the voting was
confined exclusively to the ladies them
selves, and they covered themselves
with glory by their sensible and busi
ness-like way of going about the mat
ter, and the fairness in every sense
of the word of their choice. Miss Ne
vada Ryland, -Miss Sadie and Miss Ada
Phillips of Keno are now publicly pro
claimed by the vote of their generous
sisters the most beautiful girls of
Washoe. and there will be groat dis
appointment if at least one of them is
not selected by the judge to represent
the State in the composite design.
Among the other fascinating daugh
ters of Nevada whose photographs
have been ?Â«>nt in for consideration are
Miss lidith Hunter of Elko, Mifes Anna
Fellows of rniunville and Miss Lillian
Stanton of Winnemucca, each of whom
exemplifies a different type of femin
ine perfection in the way of form,
feature and chevelure, and each of
whom is the admiration of her own
especial part of the State.
As in the case of the first beauty
contest where Venus and Minerva and
Juno appeared before Paris for his de
c:s;on, the pleasant little plan of tho
Exposition directors will undoubtedly
lerve behind it an aftermath of dis
satisfaction and heart-burning, for
every beautiful woman in the Western
States cannot hope to be even men
tioned in the grave deliberations of the
commissioners, and those who are not
will consider or at least iheir friends
will consider that they have good
cause to feel aggrieved.
One thing" is, however, certain and
this is that those who are selected
will be truly representative of the
finest looking women in the trans-Mis
sissippi region, and in every way ex
cellent types of the women of the great
West.18
MAKING GIANT WAR GUNS
Thousands of Men in the Red Glare of the Fur
naces Turning Out Steel Tubes That
Will Shoot Fifteen .Miles.
IN those days of preparation for war
the Washington navy-yard is one
of the most interesting spots to be
found anywhere. Strictly speak
ing, it is not a navy-yard at all, but
a gun factory. Here it is that all
the heavy guns and most of the light
landing and boat guns for the navy art.
built. The amount of work done in this
great national factory is enormous,
even in times of peace, but now that
the lathes, engines and tools are run
ning at full speed twenty-four hours
out of twenty-four, the number of guns
and gun carriages turned out is near
ly trebled.
Passing through the gate with its
trim marine sentry pacing to and fro,
the visitor sees uniformed officers has
tening this way and that, busy with
their duties, and hears on every side
the dull rumble of machinery, the
heavy thud of the triphammer, and the
snorting of the steam cranes. A small
army of draftsmen in the offices are
busily preparing plans and drawings
for the use of the gun builders, and
the civilian bosses and foremen of the
shops are everywhere keeping watch
with eagle eyes. Theirs is a most re
sponsible duty, for any careless and in
competent workman with a single slip
of his tool might spoil a gun or car
riage which had cost the Government
thousands of dollars to put together.
The putting together or "assembling"
of a modern gun is apparently a simple
matter. P.ut it is really one of the most
delicate operations in the world. The
greatest care and precision are neces
cary to make the different parts exactly
fit, and on 1 re/plution too many of a
plane or boring tool would injure the
part beyond repair. Hence comes much
of the fascinati n in watching the con
struction of one of the big guns as it
grows in massive and polished beauty
ready to take its place on one of our
men-of-war.
First of all the tube of the piece
comes to the factory from one of the
big steel companies, the Bethlehem or
the Mldvale, which have the contracts
to furnish forgings. The tube comes In
the rough with only a core bored out.
and looks like a heavy piece of steel
pipe. For the four-inch guns it is 13
feet 7 Inches long, while for the 13-inch
guns it attains a length of 40 feet. This
tube forms a basis for all "uture opera
tions.
A modern gun is built up by slip
ping upon it a number of jackets and
hoops, and shrinking them t<> a perfect
adjustment. A 13-inch gun when fin
ished, has thirteen separate and dis
tinct parts which have been assembled
and fitted to the minutest fraction of an
inch. As the caliber and size of the
gun diminishes the number of parts Is
reduced, and the four-inch piece is
composed of <>nly five.
In building up the gun the rough tube
and the bands are first placed in lathes
and car. fully planed down to the di
mensions required. The diameter of
the interior of the jacket which is to
slip over th^ tube half way its length
must correspond with mathematical ex
actness to the diameter ' the tube's
exterior; while the hoops, which in turn
fit over this jacket, must be treated
with a like precision.
This work of planing is clone *in the
gnat north gun shop, as it is known at
the navy yard, and when it is com
pleted, the tube and the bands have to
be carried to the "shrinking pit" at the
north end of the shop, where the next
process is to be undergone. There are
three heavy traveling cranes in the
shop, of 110, 40 and 15 tons lifting
power, respectively, and they pick
up the huge pieces of iron and carry
them to their destination as easily and
lightly as if they weighed nothing at
all.
The "shrinking pit" is a deep hole
sunk in the floor of the shop, and fitted
at each end with an oven. These ovens,
in which the bands are to be expanded
until they can slip over the gun tube,
are heated by an air and oil blast to a
temperature of TOO degrees Fahrenheit,
for this degree of heat Is necessary to
expand the heavy jacket for the 12 and
13-inch guns. At the pit the tube is
planted carefully on end close to the
oven, in which is being heated the
jacket that it is to receive. Pipes aro
so arranged that a stream of water can
be run continuously through the cnr<Â»
of the tube, to keep it conl and prevent
expansion by the heat, as the hot jacket
slips over it.
"When all is ready, the men who are
to perform the delicate task stand at
attention. Each one of them has his
own particular duty, and they cure
trainer! t>> act in concert, like a com
pany of soldiers. The jacket has been
placed In the oven and sealed up. to
await expansion by the heat. The f'>r<'
man gives the word, the traveling crane
comes up and lifts off the hot lid of the
oven, exposing the jacket within, the
hooks are made fast to a clamp pre
viously attached to the jacket, and th^
heated mass is lifted carefully from its
fiery bed.
The engineer of the crane watches,
â with hawlc-like eyes, the signals of the
foreman below, and when a sufficient
heipht has been reached the jacket is
swung over the tube and lowered. Men
with immense canvas mitten guide it
as it comes down and adjust it in place.
When it has been slipped /er the tube
streams of water are turned on to cool
it. As it cools it shrinks back to its
original size, and the delicate operation
is complete.
Strange as it may seem, after coming
through its fiery ordeal the jacket
hardly shows a sign of heat aB it is
lifted from the oven. There is a slight
bluish tinge, and that is the > nly thing
to distinguish it from the cold jacket
which went in. The exterior o; the tube
and the interior of the jacket being ex
actly the same size, only the slightest
expansion is r quired to make one slip
over the 'ier. From 3-100 to 5-100 of
an inch is all that is allowed, even in
the monster 13-iÂ»- h guns. So the speed
iest and most accurate work is neces
sary after the jacket leaves tv> oven,
for if the iron should cool off before it
was in nlace it would clamp at once
upon the tube, and the gun would be
ruined. A similar process is gone
through with in slipping the smaller
hoops over the jacket.
The shrinking of one part on another
makes an absolutely perfect weld, and
after once the band is in place nothing
short of chipping it off piece by piece
would remove it. The shrinking of the
different bands of the piece having been
finished, it is again put in the lathe and
turned down to the required size, ana
the edges of the bands are beveled oft
to give it a neat appearance. It is then
ready for the delicate operation of ri-
fling.
Only the most experienced mechanics
in the shops are in charge of the rifling
machines, for on the perfection with
which they perform their work the
whole utility of the gun depends. The
auger which cuts the grooves is care
fully adjusted and lubricated, and the
little hard steel chisels fitted on a long
beam which runs through the bore of
the gun commence their work. Only the
smallest fraction of an inch is taken off
at a time, and the greatest care is re
quired in adjusting the auger exactly.
When once put in position the lathe
Coo- the rest of the work by slowly
turning the gun as the tool eats its way
through.
After being rifled the gun is placed
on a car and carried to the breech rua
chanism shop, where the interrupted
screw breech block, in use in early all
the navies of the world, is fitted. The
carriage with its recoil cylinders for
taking up the "kick" of the piece when
fired, having been finished in the navaJ
carriage shop with as conscientious
care as the gun itself, the gun is put
together and shipped on the barge
down the Potomac River to Indian
Head, to be tested.
The guns built at the Washington
navy. yard are recognized- as the
perfect and powerful specimens of na
val ordnance in the world, and the
weight of their powder charge and pro
jectile, their length arl thei penetra
tion would have been considered out
side the bounds reason thirty years
ago. The length of a 13-inch breech
loadii.g rifle is forty feet; its weight
sixty and one-half tons; it carries a
projectile weighing 1100 pounds â more
than half a ton â which can penetrate
steel 23.42 inches thick at a distance of
1500 yards. It has a velocity at the
muzzle of 2100 feet a second, and a ve
locity of 1805 U" â  at a distance of 2500
yards, w'.iich is produced by the explo
sion of 550 pounds of brown prismatic
uowder, each grain of which is oc
tagonal in shL^e and molded to an ex
act size.
The cost of each discharge is about
$1500. The range of a gun of thirteen
inches caliber is about thirteen miles,
or a mile to.each inch, which is the ap
proximate ran^e of all guns. A 13-inch
gun is built to fire 250 shots before it
loses its temper and becoi-.es useless,
except for old iron; but in most cases
many more could probably be fired.
The 1100-pound projectile is almost as
carefully made as the gun. It is of hard
steel, with an armor piercing point and
is fitted with copper bandi which take
against the rilling, and being of soft
metal do not injure the delicate
.groo% - es df which there are fifty-two.
Besides these monster cannon the
Washington navy yard produces small
rapid fire ordnance of the Fletcher,
Maxim, Driggs-Schroeder and Hotch
kiss tj'pps, which are used aboard ship
as a protection against torpedo boats,
for landii.g parties and for boat service.
These weapons are much simpler in
their construction than the heavy ord
nance, but the same great care and
thoroughness of workmanship charac
terize their building as the heavy ord
nance.
Six weeks is practically the minimum
of time for the making of a modern
gun, and to finish one within that space
everything would have to go on mar
velously well. The "treatment" of the
steel would have to be a success at j
the very first attempt â something that
does not often happen â and the first
tests would have to show that the Gov
ernment standard had been reached.
Oftener than otherwise these results
can only be obtained through much try
ing and the expenditure of time. A
batch of guns may thus take months in
the making, while good luck may bring
it down to weeks.
It is in the casting shop, of course,
that the process of gun making h?.s its
very beginning, in the furnace where
steel is made from a medley of pieces
of old iron, pig iron lengths, broken
bits and odds and ends of castings, long
since relegated to the scrap yards.
Here is the first stage of the modern
gun â ragged and rusty metal that is
carted in wheelbarrows up to the fur
nace doors. The maws of blazing heat,
several thousand degrees in intensity,
stands open to receive it. So over
whelming is this heat that even the
master melter has to put on blue
glasses to peer into the flames rising
over the bubbling sea of metal when
the doors are open. When the doors
are dropped down â that is, shut â there
is only revealed a single spot of bright
ness, an eye that Jooks into the fur
nace's flame, and even this cannot be
approached too closely with the naked
eye.
The gun is under way. Ten tons of
metal are already in the furnace â a
lake of molten, seething metal held in
by banks of sand. Other things of
steel are to be made of this mass, the
gun works being only a portion of the
plant. Whether used for peace or war,
steel is steel, differing only in qual
ity. It is all "boiled down" in the
same way.
In shadow is the casting shop, except
when the doors are raised, when a flood
of light, a wave of extreme heat, is
thrown out. In the dusk of the
shadows grimy men raise the sea of
metal with long bars. The master mel
ter, never still, steps now and then to
his wheels, set at one side of the fur
nace and looking like the brake wheels
on a freight car, and gives one or the
other a sharp twist. By this he regu
lates his fire â five hundred degrees at
a twist. The silica bricks with which
the furnace is lined can stand four
THE SAN FEAXCISCO CALL,. SUXDAY, APRIL 17, 1898.
thousand degrees of heat and more be
fore they commence to melt. The mas
ter melter runs up the heat to the ex
treme point and then lets it down.
There are three "heats" a day in the
casting shop. Three times metal is
heated, three times it is let go with a
mighty rush into the casting pot. The
last few moments of each heat are the
dramatic instants. It is then, at the
judgment of the master melter, that
the furnace is fed with "medicine,"
FORGING BIG GUNS FOR THE ARMY AND NAVY.
shovelfuls and blocks of metal being
tossed in. On this depends the qual
ity, the strength, the elasticity of the
steel, essentials of the most vast Im
portance of the gun of to-day.
Two hours is usually sufficient for the
boiling of this steel In its cradle of
sand. At last the one moment ar
rives. The bar at the furnace's back
is worked through the sand to make
an opening. An instant, and into the
casting pot below the mass runs, scat
i tering millions of sparks, a glowing,
I golden torrent that foams and hisses
I as it plunges down.
The picture of the gun's second stage
!is superb. On every hand fly these
S sparks, and the mass bubbles and
i seethes in the casting pot. On its top,
! through the glow, can be seen a dirty
I mass â the slag or the scum that is of
|no use or value. But the picturesque
! ness of the scene has not ended. The
j casting process is only half through.
| The liquid metal must get into its
molds, and that in short order.
On a track the casting pot rests. It
I is pushed along this track until a gi-
I gantic crane overhead seizes it, swing-
I ing it aloft. Over mounds of sand it
is swung, and the metal, by the move
ment of a bar, is allowed to drop down
jin a thin stream. Again shower upon
shower of sparks, surrounding the men
who, with chains and staves, control
the clumsy pot and pull along the
j crane. The grim old shop, with Its
floor of sand, its unrelenting dust and
; its dreariness, is made into a brilliant
! cavern for the moment, and the toil
; ing men are supernatural in the light.
A prosaic time follows, when the
I metal in the molds must cool. When
j the sand is finally knocked away the
I gun that is to be is only a rough mass
iof cast steel, indicating only to the
I expert its fine quality, and not even
to him in any degree, for the tests
must come to prove that. In the forg
ing shop this mass is hammered and
worked until it becomes an octagonal
ingot of just twice the weight it will
possess when it is finally turned and
bored into a "jacket" or "tube." The
hoc.ps. the third part of a gun, are
cast and forged hollow, not in solid
cylinders, as the jacket and tubes ara.
With the carrying away of the rough
ingot of steel from the forging shop
the special work of gun making comm
ences. The boring and turning fac
tory is the Bcene of the first step in
this process.
Completed suns, ready for mounting
and for fire, are not turned out in these,
gun shops. The finishing touches, the
actual puttinu together Of the parts of
the gun, the rilling itself, are done at
the ordnance works in Washington. It
is the business alone "f a gun shop to
make the steel and to hand over to the
army and the navy the three parts
of a great gun â the "tube," the "jacket
(which is slipped on over the tube and
then "shrunk on" by contraction) ana
the "hoops," two in number, which, for
the purpose of strengthening, are fitter!
on tightly over the muzzle end of the
tubes.
HOW NATIONS
DECLARE WAR.
NOTWITHSTANDING the fact
that most people consider a for
mal declaration of war necessa
ry before active measures can
be taken it is usually the case
in these go-ahead times that no
Warning whatever is given.
When Rome was mistress of the
world a declaration of war was a sol
emn function, attended with so much
ceremony that a special college of her
alds was always kept in readiness to
perform it when necessary. In me
dieval times letters of defiance served
to give warning of hostile intentions,
and still later heralds were sent to
throw down the gantlet and make a
verbal declaration of war*
In such times formal declarations
were necessary to differentiate between
the private br Is of a f^v barons and
a national war for which the commu
nity was responsiblf . but at the pres
ent day total concealment as long as
possible is the most universal rule. The
objects, says the writer in Tid-Bits,
of this are usual'" either to anticipate
the designs of some other power, to
avoid the onus of admitting a state of
war as long as possible, or to gain time
by swiftness of attack.
The latest instances of formal decla
ration by herald were in 1635. when
Louis 3^,111 sent a herald to declare
war against Spain, and in 1657 when
Sweden declared â  r against Denmark
by herald sent to Copenhagen; while as
late as 1671 war between England and
Holland was declared by solemn proc
lamation.
As the most recent cases are those
likely to intluence the conduct of na
tions in the immediate future, the wars
of the present century are of the great
est interest at the present crisis.
In the quarrel between Russia and
Turkey which immediately preceded
the Crimean War, a formal declaration
was issued at Moscow by proclamation
of the Czar, and three days later, after
the Turks were well aware of the state
of affairs^ operations were commenced
in earnest.
In the cases of Britain and France
less consideration was shown. War
was formally declared by Britain on
March 22, 1854, and on the 31st it was
proclaimed by the High Sheriff of Lon
don from the steps of the Exchange.
But these declarations were made
merely to justify the step to the peo
ple and to ask for their approval and
help. Before that- time active opera
tions had commenced by the entry of
the British and French fleets into the
Dardanelles, contrary to treaty, and
the forced retreat of the Russian fleet,
to Sebastopol when the allies reached
the Black Sea.
On February 8 the Russian Minister
was withdrawn from London, and the
British and French Ministers from St.
Petersburg. Although such a step us
ually precedes war, and is often regard
ed as equivalent to a declaration.it only
signifies that all hope of successful dip
lomatic negotiation has been abandoned
and that war is likely to ensue. It does
not necessarily imply a st^ate of war,
such a state requiring some definite act
of hostility.
In the opium war of 1840, the Italian
wars of 1847 and 1849. the Anglo-Persian
war of 1856, the wars between Austria
and France in 1859, Prussia and Schles
wig-Holstein in 1863 and Brazil and
Uruguay in 1864, various hostile acts
were committed before any declaration
of war was made, although in some
cases manifestoes were issued to neu
tral powers. In the Austro-Italian war
of 1859, the Austro-Prussian war of 1566
and the Russo-Turkish war of 1877 the
declaration and active operations were
practically synonymous. In the last
mentioned case, for example, the Porte
received a co*"'of the declaration on the
evening of April 24, the very day on
which 50,000 Russian troops crossed the
Roumanian frontier.
The most notable instance in the pres
ent century of a formal declaration of
war being made before actual opera
A BIG GUN AFTER IT IS CAST AND MOUNTED
tio-ns were begun was that of >*Â»c
Franco-Prussian war in 1870. In KulZ
case the declaration was ai:".^.
forced, as the French, who wore UUs
aggressors, voted large war credits <
July 15, and on the following day th
French Minister returned to Paris. A
formal intimation of hostile intentions
was then sent to Berlin and laid before
the Parliament of the North German
Confederation on July 20.
On November 12, 1885, Britain was
honored by a declaration of war from
King Theebaw of Burmah, but it was
a needless formality o-n the part of his
dusky Majesty, for the British troops
were already on the way to his capital,
and the only reply to his challenge was
his deposition, which immediately en
sued.
THE ORLOFF DIAMOND.
At the beginning of the eighteenth
century a soldier belonging to one of
the French garrisons in India became
enamored of the eyes of Brahma in
the Temple of the Serringham. These
eyes were diamonds, more brilliant
than ever shone under the eyebrows of
Crapaud'a European divinities. Their
luster captivated his soul. He haunt
ed the temple and yielding to the might
of the god became a convert to his
worship. At least so he persuaded the
priests, who went so far as to admit
him to some care of the temple, doubt
less trusting Brahma to protect his
own. But on a stormy night the con
vert disappeared and with him one of
the idol's eyes, the other having resist
ed all his "efforts to dislodge it. So
Brahma was left squinting, and the
perfidious Frenchman sold his prize to
a captain in the English navy for about
$10,000.
Later it was bought by the Armenian
merchant Schaffras for more than five
times this sum. and was shown by him
to Catharine of Rups:;i. who offered for
it about $400,000, a life pension of $18,000
and a patent of nobility. Schaffras re
fused this offer and subsequently sold
the diamond to Gregory Orloff for the
same sum, without the patent of nobil
ity. Orloff, part author of Catharine's
greatness, and raised by her to the
steps of the throne.DISGUISED HERSELF IN MAN'S CLOTHING TO EARN HER LIVING.

HERE is the story of a young woman who laid aside her skirts,
disguised herself in men's clothes and worked among men daily
for months without any one suspecting her sex.
She adopted the disguise because she thought she could
earn a living easier and live cheaper. Now she thinks different
For months, under the name of John Warden. Miss Warren lived
just as a man among men in the ordinary duties of business life
Everybody in Fowzer's photograph gallery, where she worked as a re
toucher, treated Miss Warren as a "good fellow"; she was very popu
lar with all her acquaintances outside of the gallery.
; the boys got up a theater party and invited John Warden.

two of beer, and she disliked liquor of any kind. It so hap

stronger protest, drank what she could of the schooner of beer.

skirt- out of her trunk. and determined to stick to them henceforth
because M gave her the privilege of refusing beer when she hated it.
Lrutside ol this reason was another. She had adopted male attire
' >n Eor herself, < She had succeeded, and she thought
that m her woman's dress she could continue to hold what she had
When next day John Warden appeared in woman's attire in Fow
zers photograph gallery there was the wildest kind of amazement all
md. In the hubbub Miss Warren managed to explain why she had
imed the disguise, and now she is working away there as calmly
and as successiully as when she wore breeches and drew the salary of
John Warden, retoucher.

there was another, a man, who fancied
that women were not fit to do that sort
of thing, and wanted me to marry him
and settle down and be comfortable.
Unfortunately we did not agree on that
point. He vowed that he would fol
low me, and so, to throw him off the
track, I decided to do what I had so
long planned; that is, to disappear as
a woman and appear as a plain, every
day working man, trying to 'earn a
living.
"When I reached the city I stopped
at a good hotel, and I tell you it eat
into my slim little purse, too. I then
went to a clothiers and ordered a suit
of clothes sent to my rooms for my
young cousin, Mr. John Warren.
"I then went to a lodging-house
cheap, but clean, and secured rooms for
the same young- man.
"The next night I packed my satchel
and left the hotel, and next morning I
hopped out of my room and into the
world as Mr. John Warren.
"How did it feel? Oh, it was awful
"I fancied every one was staring at
me and I felt like bolting into the first
friendly doorway that offered its shel
ter.
"My heart beat like a trip-hammer
every time I came near a policeman
and I finally hit upon the plan of cross
ing in the middle of the streets to evacU
them.
"At last I mustered up courage to go
to Mr. Fowzer.
" 'Jt/hn, brace up and be a man,' I
said to myself. "But in spite of my
best efforts it was only after two or
three attempts that I pulled myself to
gether and ventured into his office.
"Lord heavens, how I quaked and
trembled in my shoes when I had to
face a real man, and what was worse,
talk to him.
"However, after a few inward quakes
I managed to tell him what I wanted
and he kindly said that he would let
me come.
"For a long time after that every
thing was quiet. No one seemed to
suspect me and I began to feel com
fortable. I liked my suit of clothes
best on rainy days, no skirts to pick
ud and to eet draereled In the mud.
"Ah, yes, I was supremely happy in
those days. I felt immensely superior
to the rest of my sex.
"My <me source of annoyance was the
fact that my hair would grow too fast,
and finally it got so bad that the hor
rible fear began to dawn on me that I
i would have to go to a barber and have
it cut.
"Well, I went. Of course the barber
asked me if I wanted a shave. It's a
regulation question with them.
"I said no rather too emphatically, I
thought, for the barber stared hard at
me for a second and then set to work
on my hair.
" 'Why, what soft hair you have,' he
said, 'it's just like a woman's.'
"I nearly fainted, but managed to
mutter that I had often been told so.
"When I got out of his shop, like the
man on the Bowery, I resolved 'To
never go there anymore.'
"Mr. Fowzer has no doubt told you

easily, and soon after I came here the
| folks round here asked me to go out
with them. I escaped whenever I could,
but one time they caught me. Mr.
Fowzer had asked me to come to the

thought that it would be all right, so I

you will know that the feeling was
anything but a jolly one.
"Between one of the acts one of the
party suggested something to refresh
the inner man, as he expressed it,
though 1 was thinking of the woman all
the while.

vitation, but only succeeded in making

i Finally I saw that the easiest way to
get out of it was to go to the bar with
them and make a show of drinking.

me. We filed into the bar and they
: called for beer.
"I was too wretched to do anything
! but nod my head when the> asked me
if I'd have the same!
"Have you ever seen one of the
dreadful things they call 'schooners of
steam beer?'
"It looked as large as a house to me.
If the earth could only have opened

I it. and still I stood desnaJrinerlv look
ing at the mountain of foam.

much time; we don't wish to miss the
next act,' said Mr. Fowzer, and I
started in on that dreadful tower of
beer.
"Well. I got it down, and I can tell
you right here that it was the first and
last one I shall ever touch or anything !
that looks like it.

solved that my disguise would have to !
be dropped. I wouldn't take the risk

beer again. I felt, too, that I had won

HOW TO SUCCEED AS AN ORATOR.
WHAT advice would I give to
a young man ambitious to
become a successful public
speaker or orator?
In the first place I would
advise him to have some
thing to say â something worth saying
â something that people would be glad
to hear. This is the important thing.
Back of the art of speaking must be
the power to think. Without thoughts
i words are empty purses. Most people
i imagine that almost any words, uttered
in a loud voice and accompanied by ap
propriate gesture, constitute an ora
tion. I would advise the young man
| to study his subject, to find what others
j had thought, to look at it from all
sides.
Then I would tell him to write out
his thoughts or to arrange them in his
mind, so that he would know exactly
what he was going to say. Waste no
time on the how, until you are satisfied
with the what.
After you know what you are to say,
then you can think of how it should
be said. Then you can think about
tone, emphasis and gesture: but if you
really understand what you say, em
phasis, tone and gesture will take care
of themselves. All these should come
from the inside. They should be In
perfect harmony ",-ith the feelings.
Voice and gesture should be governed
by the emotions. They should uncon
sciously be in perfect agreement with
the sentiments. The orator should be
true to his subject, should avoid any
reference to himself.
The great column of his argument
should bt> unbroken. He can adorn it
with vines and flowers, but they should
not be in such profusion as to hide the
column. He should give variety of epi
sode by illustrations, but they should be
used only for the purpose of adding
strength to the argument.
The man who wishes to become an
orator should study language. He
should know the deeper meaning or
words. He should understand the vigor
and velocity of verbs and the color of
adjectives. He should know how to
sketch a scene, to paint a picture, to
give life and action. He should be a
poet and a dramatist, a painter and an
actor. He should cultivate his imagi
nation. He should become familiar with
the great poetry and fiction, with splen
did and heroic deeds. He should be a
student of Shakespeare. He should read
and devour the great plays. From
Shakespeare he could learn the art of
expression, of compression, and all the
secrets of the head and heart.
The great orator is full of variety â
of surprises. Like a juggler he keeps
the colored balls in the, air. He ex
presses himself in pictures. His speech
is a panorama. By continued change
he holds the attention. The interest
does not flag. He does not allow him-
that I like my own clothes much better
than the ones I adopted.
"I didn't find much difference in the
treatment I received from either men
or women, but I like my own clothes
best, and I never will try to be a man
again.
"You see, I thought it would not only
be easier to get around, but I thought
it would be cheaper; that a man could
get lodging in cheap places where a
woman would not care to go.
"I discovered, however, that it did
not make so much difference.
"Altogether I find that you can get
along in the world, be you either man
or woman, and I think it best not to try
and be an imitation of the opposite sex,
for you are sure to wish that you
hadn't before you get through.
"I shall probably leave here before
long. My course is almost completed
and I shall want to set up for myself.
"No, I shall riot open a gallery here.
I will go into some small place.
"Will I go as a man? Never again.
Stick to your own sex, that's what my
experience has taught me."
By Robert G. Ingersoll.
self to be anticipated. He is always in
advance. He does not repeat himself.
A picture is shown but once. So, an
orator should avoid the commonplace.
There should be no stuffing, no filling.
He should put no cotton with his silk,
no common metals with his gold. He
should remember that "gilded dust is
not as good as dusted gold." The great
orator is honest, sincere. He does not
pretend. His brain and heart go to
gether. Every drop of his blood is con
vinced. Nothing is forced. He knows
exactly what he wishes to doâ knows
when he has finished it, and stops.
Only a great orator knows when and
how to close. Most speakers go on
after they are through. They are sat
isfied only with a "lame and impotent
conclusion." Most speakers lack va
riety. They travel a straight and dusty
road. The great orator is full of epi
sode. He convinces and charms by in
direction. He leaves the road, visits
the fields, wanders in the woods, listens
to the murmurs of springs, the songs
of birds. He gathers flowers, scales the
crags and comes back to the highway
refreshed, invigorated. He does not
move in a straight line. He wanders
and winds like a stream.
Of course no one can tell a man what
to do to become ~n orator. The great
orator has that wonderful thing called
presence. He has the strange some
thing known as magnetism. He must
have a flexible, musical voice, capable
of expressing the pathetic, the humor
ous, the heroic. His body must move in
unison with his thought. He must be
a reasoner, a logician. He must have
a keen sense of humor â of the laugh
able. He must have wit, sharp and
quick. He must have sympathy. His
smiles should be the neighbors of his
tears. He must have imagination. He
should give eagles to the air. and
painted moths should flutter In the sun
light.
While I cannot tell a man what to do
to become an orator, I can tell him a
fe-.' things not to do.
There should be no introduction to an
oration. The orator should commence
with his subject. There should be no
prelude, no flourish, no apology, no ex
planation. He should say nothing
about himself. Like a sculptor he
stands by his block of stone. Every
stroke is for a purpose.
As he works the form begins to ap
pear. When the statue is finished, the
workman stops. Nothing is more diffi
cult than a perfect close. Few poems,
few pieces of music, few novels end
well. A good story, a great speech, a
perfect poem should end just at the
proper point. The bud, the blossom,
the fruit. No delay. A great speech is
a crystallization in Its logic, an efflor
escence in its poetry.
To tell the truth, I have not
heard many speeches. Most of the
great speakers in our country were be
fore my time. I heard Beecher. and he
was an orator. He had imagination,
humor and intensity. His brain was
fertile as the valleys of the iropl-s.
He was too broad, too philosophic, too
poetic for the pulpit.
"Miss Warren carried out her part as
a young chap earning a living ex
tremely well," said Mr. Fowzer. "None
of us in the gallery here had the slight
est suspicion that John Warden was
anything but a real, up-to-date man,
entitled to wear men's clothes and
work among men as a man. That's
the reason we invited him. or rather
her, to the theater party. Warden was
somewhat shy, but we attributed that
to youth and natural diffidence.
"When we look back at what hap
pened at the theater party it all seems
funny enough now. Warden seemed ap
palled at the size of the schooner of
beer. We noticed it. but we men were
all thinking about the play and about
getting back to our seats, so outside of
'joshing' him, or rather her, a bit we
did not make anything out of it.
"Togged out in her man's clothes she
seemed just like any other young felc
low, only, as I said, retiring and quiet.
"If you ask the men in the gallery I
guess they'll tell you she makes more
of a hit in woman's clothes than in
man's."
Xow and then he broke the fetters
! of his creed, escaped from his orthodox
j prison and became sublime.
Theodore Parker was an orator. He
preached great sermons. His sermons
: on "Old Age" and "Webster," and his
: address on "Liberty" were filled with
'â¢â  great thoughts, marvelously exprer.s
ed. When he dealt with human events,
i with realities, with things he knew, he
i was superb. When he spoke of free
' dom, of duty, of living to the ideal, of
! mental integrity, he seemed inspired.
W r ebster I never heard. He had
| great qualities; force, "dignity, clf-ar
[ ness, grandeur: but, after all, he wor
| shiped the past. He kept his back
Ito the sunrise. There was no dawn in
! his brain. He was not creative. He
i had no spirit of prophecy. He lighted
'no torch. He was not true to his ideal.
IHe talked sometimes as though his
i head was among the stars, but he stood
in the gutter.
Clay I never heard, but he must have
had a commanding presence, a chival-
I ric bearing, a heroic voice. He cared
i little for the past. He was a natural
! leader, a wonderful talkerâ forcible.
] persuasive, convincing. He was not a
j poet, not a master of metaphor, but he
< was practical. He kept in view the
j end to be accomplished. He was the
! opposite of Webster. Clay was the
â  morning, Webster the evening. Clay
had large views, a wide horizon. He
was ample, vigorous and a little tyran
: nical.
Benton was thoroughly common
place. He never uttered an inspired
word. He was an intense egotist. No
subject was great enough to make him
forget himself. Calhoun was a politi
cal Calvinist â narrow, logical, dog
matic. He was not an orator. He de
livered essays, not orations.
S. S. Prentiss was an orator, but,
with the recklessness of a gamester, he
threw his life away. He said profound
and beautiful things, but he lacked ap
plication. He was dispropor
ticned â saying ordinary things on great
occasions, and now and then, without
the slightest provocation, uttering the
sublimest and most beautiful thoughts.
Lincoln had reason, wonderful humor
and wit. but his presence was not good.
His voice was poor, his gestures awk
ward â but his thr.-ughts were profound.
His speech at Gettysburg is one of the
masterpieces of the world. The word
"here" is used four or five times too
often. Leave the heres out and the
speech is perfect.
Of course I have heard a great many
talkers, but orators are few and far
between. They are produced by vic
torious nationsâ born in the midst of
great events, of marvelous achieve
ments. They utter the thoughts, the
aspirations of their age. They clothe
the children of the people in the
gorgeous robes of genius. They inter
pret the dreams. With the poets, they
prophesy. They fill the future with
heroic forms, with lofty deeds. They
keep their faces toward the dawnâ
toward the ever-coming day.

HOW THE BIG PARIS EXPOSITION OF 1900 WILL LOOK.
IT is not too soon to sÂ«p"ulate
upon just what part the United
States will play in the coming
Paris Exposition of 1900. The Call
is enabled to give a forecast of
tli" plans in so far as they had
been perfected by the special commis
sioner, the late Moses P. Handy, as em
bodied in an advance copy of the Pres
ident's message to < 'ongress.
From this document it is shown that
the prospects for an adequate American
exhibit are ver* bright, considering the
delay in the initial arrangements. The
messauv recommends an appropriation
of 5&7H. 600. In dealing with this the
President says:
"In view of the magnitude and
importance <>f the approaching ex
position and of our standing
among the nations which will be
there represented, and in view also
of our Increased population and ac
knowledged progress in arts, s<-i
ence and manufactures, I earnestly
commend the report of Major Han
dy to your consideration and trust
that a liberal appropriation may be
made. Moreover, the magnificent
exhibit oi ill.' French Uoverntnerit
at Chicago in 1893, on which $1,000,
000 was expended, should be a
strong incentive to reciprocal liber
ality on the part of the Government
of " the United States, and
suggests to our citizens the
necessity as well as the pro
priety of installing at the Paris
Exhibition an exhibit oil a- par with
that of the Government and people
of France at Chicago, and in keep
ing with the scope and extent of
the preparations which are being
made by nearly all the important
nations <<f the earth for theft" pro.
posed exhibits in that exposition."
Major Handy's report is full of meat.
He describes in detail the eventually
successful struggle for appropriate
space, and how the space will be al
lotted. He gives comparisons based
upon past expositions, and throws out
many valuable hints to prospective ex
hibitors. The space originally reserved
for the United States was little more
than that awarded in ISS9.
The following table shows the total
allotment of space:

To form a fair judgment as to the
equity of this allotment it is essential
to recall the superficial areas of the
several universal expositions that have
been held in Paris since 1867. The ex
position of that y< ar occupied L 62 acres;
that of istx, 187 acres, and that of 1889,
240 acres, while the space at present
available for that of 1900 is about 336
acres. The full extent of the allotment
of the United States is not fully set
forth in the above table, there being
no allotment it will be observed, in the
departments of fine arts. Horticulture,
forestry, chase and fisheries, social
economy and hygiene, colonization and
army and navy.
The vexed question of classification
lias been profoundly studied in all its
aspects by M. Picard, the commissary
general,, and by the superior commis
sion. The difficulties, in fact the. utter
impossibility, of devising a scheme of
claasilication absolutely logical and en
tirely free from practical disadvantages
were fully recognized. The commission
examined with great care. the classifi
cations of all the international expo
sitions of the past, both in France and
other countries, and considered fully
the various criticisms to which they
have been subjected in the light of the
actual results achieved.
For the classification at the approach
ing exposition, that of lKh9 i.s taken a.s
a point of departure, and such moditi
cations have been made as were sug
gested by the legitimate criticisms of
which it was the object, and by the
lessons taught by foreign expositions.
The post of honor is occupied by edu
cation, "the channel by which man en
ters into life, the source of all pro
gress." Next come the works of art,
and the third place is assigned to the
lnstru t m t en,ts and^ general processes of
â¢letters, science and arts. Then come
'â¢the great factors of contemporary pro
duction, the most Powerful agents of
industrial achievement at the end or
the nineteenth century"-"* 'ferial
and general processes of mechan cs
electricity civil engineering, methods
of transportation. Next follow the ex
ploitation and the products .superficial
or subterranean, of the earth-agricul
ture, horticulture, forestry, the chase,
fisheries, placer mining, food stuffs
mines and metallurgy.- Next m order
are decorations and furnishing of pub
lic buildings and habitations, threads, -
yarns tissues, textile fabrics, wearing
apparel chemical industries, various
manufactures-. - ."Social .economy, -to.
which have been reserved the develop
ments worthy of its actual role, follows
naturally the various branches of artis
tic agricultural and industrial produc- j
tlon." It will embrace also hygiene and
public or organized charity.
â¢ The interest in the exposition shown
by Americans seems: to be very great.
In his report. Major Handy says: "Ap
plications informally made by individ
ual exhibitors show bona ride demands
for J52,%9 square feet, besides estimat
ed requirements of associated educa
tion, arts and mines to the extent of
125,000 square feet. In other words,
two years before t.ie date fixed for the
opening of the exposition there is a de
mand for more space than was ever
occupied by the United States in any
international exposition on foreign SOIL
These demands emphasize the neces
sity of co-operating with the authori
ties of the exposition in their earnest
determination to make it one of selec
tion. '&*?"'*%Â£
"France sets a good example in re
quiring that all applications for space
shall be passed upon by two juries of
selections, or boards of examiners.
Germany, heartily secondine France's
intentions, proposes also to thoroughly
sift all applications and send to Paris
only those articles which survive the
most careful expert scrutiny. 'Only
products of the first class will be ac-
pted." says Mr. Hichter, the German
Commissioner - General. I strongly
recommend that we follow the same
policy, and would suggest that no
article be shipped to Paris for exhibi
tion until it has passed the most crit
ical scrutiny of the Commissioners or
committees of their appointment.
"My idea would be to have commit
tees for this purpose sit in New York
and Chicago, and perhaps in other
cities, whose duty it shall be not only
to sift exhibits, thoroughly, reiecting
all that are commonplace,. trivial or in
any respect, unworthy, but also to scale
down the space to reasonable dimen
sions in every case. It cannot be tod
thoroughly: understood that in the
coming international exposition the
difficulty will not be to get exhibitors,
i but to moderate the demands of exhib
itors and to- meet in any degree the
requirements, of such exhibits as will
be a credit and honor to thia country."
The propriety of having a special de
partment-for the display of woman's
work, to be installed and managed by
women, has 1 been urged upon the ad
ministrative council of the exposition,
but so far without perceptible effect.
The Midway Plaisance of the World's
Columbian Exposition will have its
counterpart, and the authorities are
busying themselves devising plans or
passing upon those of individuals, for
the amusement of the crowds that will
throng the grounds in 1900. Quaint and
queer customs of the little known na
tions. are to be shown, making it possi
ble for one to See the ends of the earth
without journeying that distance.
Work upon the grounds and buildings
is proceeding rapidly, although with
great care, and there is no doubt that
the exhibits will have been installed
by April 18, 1900, the date set for the
opening of the exposition. The site will
be practically .the same as was occu
pied by the exposition of ISB9, the total
space being 336, acresâ 96 more than
was available for the last exposition.
The area compared with that of the
World's Columbian Exposition of 1593,
which occupied nil of Jackson Park and
the Midway Plaisanee â 740 acres in all
â shows the limitations with which the
officials have to contend. A larger space
might have hi-'-n had in the suburbs,
but the Municipal Council of Paris and
the Council-General of the Seine De
partment strongly opposed all propo
sals to locate any part of the exposition
outside of the city.
The industrial progress of the United
States and the evolution of its material
resources during the hundred years
which the exposition is to crown have
been unequaled by that of any other
Ration. It is not too much to say that
