Morbua Sickness, Nausea, etc. All drajr-LATEST THING
IN FOOTWEAR
THE latest thing
in the. way .of
footwear is the
- orthopedic boot.
Â» Accustomed as any
lady la to me pointed
toed shoe -made on a
curved last, the new
. boot Appears at first
ungainly. But tue
docton declare that
once used to : them
they will prove not
â only a thing of Joy
but beauty forever.
For once Dame
Fashion is not re
sponsible for a new
style. The physl
cians are the spon
sors of this new
i hoe. Tta< cases of
"flat foot" have be
come so numerous
that they say either
the orthopedic boot
must be adopted or
we will be b flat
footed race.
"Flat foot" Is Just
what the name in
dicates. The bones
which form the arch
of the instep sink
from their proper
position, producing
a strain that is ex
tretnely painful, and.
what is worse, trans
forming the shapely
foot iritoan ungainly
member that might
belong to a Held dar-
Ky of the South.
This Kinking of the
bones is produced
because theshoesaro
made on lasts curved on both sldM
whereas th<- line of the foot Is straight
on the Inside. This unnatural curve forces
the great toe out of position.
The grent toe is of more value in walk-
Ing than all the other toea put together
and when it 13 forced into an unnatural
position It is impossible for it to perform
its full duty.
Cases of "llat foot" wore ifbt so numer
ous when the square toe was the vogue
for, although the shoes. were made on a
curved last, the strain on the big toe was
not so great. When the pointed toe be
\camo the rage doctors predicted direful
consequences, and their prophecies have
been n \liz<-d. .
The "orthopedic boots," which arc madÂ»
> by hygienic bootmakers, follow the natu
ral outline of the foot; that is, the boots
follow a straight line on the, inside and
a curved one on the outside.
In one of the largest hospitals in New
York City thero is a stringent rule de
manding that all nurses employed wear
MODEL OF A SHOE
THAT IS GUARAN
TEED TO PREVENT
â FLAT-FOOT." PHY
SICIANS IN EASTERN
HOSPITALS ARE BE
GINNING TO ORDER
THE NURSES TO
WEAR THEM. THE
HOSPITAL AUTHORI
TIES HERE ARE DIS
CUSSING THE MAT
TER.
shoes of this description. The muscles of
the feet are given full play, the great toe
Is allowed to properly fulfill its duties,
and thereby a decided Increase in freedom
and elasticity is gained.
There is a movement on foot to estab
lish the same rule In the Children's Hos
pital in this city. All the; physicians of
that hospital wear the new boots, and are
constantly inducing their patients to fol
low their examples.
One of the leading physicians, when
asked about the new boot, said: "If we
can get people to wear them perhaps in
another generation feet will have re
sumed their natural snape. The distor
tions produced by shoes made on the
fashionable last arc not only hideous but
absolutely incompatible with light, easy
walking and a graceful carriage. There
would be less of that tired feeling' If
properly cat shoes were worn. There Is
a post in the shoe that must bo worn un
til the big toe resumes its natural posi
tion. The post is so placed in the shoe
as to force the great toe to make a
straight line with the foot, and Is placed
between the great tou and the second
one."
The doctors say that we must choose
between properly cut shoes and "llat
foot."
Which shall it be?
PRINCES WHO ARE MONKS.
In the wildest and most desolate part
of the Black Forest is to be found the
most aristocratic monastery in the world.
Almost every monk who has here sought
shelter from the world is of noble or
princely rank, and many are the bearers
of historic names who have done their
part In molding history.
One of the mo-Jt devout and humble of
all its Inmates is Prince Philip of Hohen
lohe at one time one of the chief orna
ments of European courts; and Prince
Edward Schonburg-Hartenstein fulfills
some of the lowliest duties of the mon-
Father John- Is the Baron yon Drais,
who shone so brilliantly for a time at
the court of Baden; afld Father Sebastian
ron yon Ocr, one of the most dash
ing soldiers in the Saxon army. Among
other nobles who nave deserted the
sword for the cowl aw Count de Memp
tlrine and Baron yon Salls-Soglio.
â¢\ll the menial work of the monastery is
done by these titled monks, who are con
tent to exchange their brilliant spheres
for a life of solitude and the most rigid j
discipline. _
Henry de Windt, the famous globe.- 1
trotter, says: "I have roughed it for the ;
past fifteen years in Siberia, Borneo, and '
In Chinese Tartary, but I can safely de- I
scribe my climb over the Chilkoot Pass !
as the severest physical experience of mv j
life."
THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1898.
Pretty Parisian Designs.
Special to The Call from Paris.
THE illustrations represent nearly
all the styles in dress, including
OQtdoor and evening costume, ball
and house dresses, mantles and
garments for morning and even-
ing, cape and cycling costume.
Here is a criticism on them:
If the form of the marone crape dress
is simple, it is stylish and becoming, but
the trimmings are less so. The bits of taf
fetas in marone and white are not pleas-
Ing in effect. I should have preferred a
trimming of taffetas on the cross, a light
passementerie or even a marone guipure
following the movement of the corsage
and of the upper skirt, and also as a
trimming for the skirt.
The shape of the black cloth jacket is
graceful in form, but the collar, which is
very high, swells the appearance at *he
neck. The trimming behind is more be
coming than that in front, and I would
rather not have had the square yoke of
white taffetas.
The mastic cloth cape with four flounces
is quite in the new shap~ which 1 do not
consider graceful, and which should never
be mad* except in light and soft mute
rials. The collar is unbecoming, which Is
the case with all collars as at present
worn.
The cycling costume is exactly what it
should beâ plain, practical and in very
good taste.
The Indoor dress of striped mousseline
de soie is too much of the sacque Bhape,
but the appearance, which is exaggerated
in the sketch. Is minimized by the trans
parent nature of the material. Neverthe
less, it is too much like a chemise, and I
would rather see a waistband round the
iigure.
The white spangled tulle dress is pret
tily composed, and by removing the
gulmpe it can be converted into a de
collete dress with long sleeves. The only
thing I dislike is the rosette on the left
side of the corsage. It appears to me
heavy and useless. I would prefer a
small bunch of pink roses. In a tall
woman the arrangement of the skirt does
very well, but for a short figure 1 would
advise the suppression of the frill of
mousseline de soie around the bottom.
There is no particular feature about the
cut of the green velvet mantle. The
richness of the Japanese embroidery alone
and the harmony of the colors constitute
its beauty. The sleeves, cut in at the
wrists, appear to me rather heavy. I
would have liked them better fuller and
longer over the hands.
The gown by Honnet, 9 Rue de la Paix,
is an outdoor dress in marone crepon. In
the China crape style, with a double
skirt The underskirt is rounded at the
bottom. Hat in front at the top, and very
tight fitting at the sides. The fullness is
thrown behind, and the godets, which be
gin half way down, are behind only.
This skirt is quite plain at the bottom,
and opens in the center of the apron all
the way down, showing a narrow band of
striped and shot ecru marone and white
taffetas the stripes of which run cross
wise This trimming is very narrow at
the waist and widens gradually. The
upper skirt Is set In without fullness at
the waist and widens gradually down to
the bottom. It runs about half way
down each side in front, where it is
rounded, and is prolonged behind to about
forty centimeters from the bottom, giving
the appearance of a tail when seen from
behind. It is ornamented on each side in
front with eight oblong pieces of striped
taffetas like that on the underskirt, one
above another.
The eorsiigo is a blouse of the same
material gathered at the waist, and with
two pleats on each side, which are lost
beneath the waistband. It opens down
the center over a front of striped and
shot taffetas in two bands which appear
to form one with the trimming of the
apron. The front is trimmed on each
side with the same material. The neck
trimming is of orange taffetas covered
with heavy guipure and is very wide: the
collarette Is of guipure. The waistband
is of plain marone taffetas fastened on
the left side with a bow of the same.
The sleeves are made with small puffs
at the shoulders, but are tight fitting all
down the arm. On the outer side are
three small squares of striped taffetas.
The wrists are trimmed with guipure.
The hat which completes this costume is
Of yellowish marone velvet: it Is a toque,
trimmed with a drapery of chiffon, high
est on the left side; a white feather en
circles the crown and there is an aigrette
set in a ntrass buckle. On the brim in
front there is a barrette of strass.
At Red fern' a I have seea an indoor
dress of white mousseline de sole striped
with dead silk. or. wnich arc printed
green and mauve chrysanthemums. This
tight and transparent material is loose
over an independent dress 01 white taf
fetas. The ciress is rather long and mad.>
in ono piece from top to bottom, and
slightly gathered over a â >-oke of spotted
tulle embroidered with violets in Tom
Thumb ribbon. Round tue yoke is a
Greek pattern embroidered in narrow
gathered ribbon.
The skirt Is perfectly straight all down
and Is edged round the bottom with two
rows of embroidery worked in narrow
ribbon. A waistband of mauve taffetas
can, if desired, be tied round the figure,
either over the moussellne de sole, which
would convert the garment into n stylish
Bortie, or over the taffetas dress, which is
very effective, us the moussellne de Bole
dnss falls like a full smock, showing the
taffetas dress confined at the waist. The
neck trimming is of white spotted tulle,
embroidered with bouquets of vloiets,
and the collarette is <â {â  lace, running
round tiie back and sides only, leaving the
neck finite free in front.
The sleeves form small draperies at the
shoulders, over which are epaulets <>f
white moussellne de soie embroider* d
with Greek designs like those round the
yoke, immediately beneath the drapery
Is a circlet of embroidery on each arm.
The Bleeves are quite tight from the
elbow to the waist, very long and em
broidered with Greek designs to the
wrists. â¢
1 also saw a pattern of an evening
mantle in green velvet plush. This gar
ment is made with a yoke, from which
the body falls straight down in front and
at the sides, forming pleats, which widen
gradually all the way. The yoke is
trimmed with braid in undulating ding
onal lines, forming chevrons in front. The
front is ornamented down each sid: j with
broad garlands in Japanese embroidery,
the designs being composed of chrysan
themums and lotus with foliage in their
natural colors. The sides and back are
quite plain.
The mantle is gathered round the. yoke
and is very full, so as to leave plenty of
room for evening dress. The collar is ex
tremely high behind, lower at the sides
and completely sloped away In front. It
is embroidered like the yoke and edged
with a narrow, fluffy ruche of black
mousseline de soie. The sleeves are In
shape like those of children's blouses,
gathered at the inset and full all down.
At Giles", 17 Avenue de I'Opera, I have
seen a dress of large meshed Paris tulle
over a skirt of white poult d soie. The
skirt has a broad apron embroidered with
Sowers in white silk and bright black
spangles, and between the flowers largo
spots of chenille at irregular distances.
The apron is cut into scallops round the
bottom and detached from a flounce of
plain tulle, frilled. The right side and
back breadths of the skirt resemble the
ground of the apron; the left side is com
posed of plain tulle finely pleated. The
skirt is fiat at the top in front and gath
ered behind and at the side. It is rounded
at the bouom ad rather long.
The corsage is a blouse, cut low and
square and gathered at the wast. The
decollete is edged with black velvet,
which is continued into braces both be
fore and behind, and is edged with a
niche 01 white tulle spotted with black
chenille. The body of the corsage matches
the apron. At me fall of the left shoul
der is a large rosette of white tulle. The
neck trimming is a broad piece of black
velvet ribbon simply draped: the waist
band of the samo ribbon, not very wide,
fastened behind with a small straight
bow.
FASHIONS FOR
SMALL PURSES
THE really healthy looking worn:. 1,
man, office or store is so much the
exception that one cannot but won
der if the tired, fagged-out condi
tion may not be due to lack of care
of the oodily health, and particularly to
stiff corsets and heavy skirts hanging
from the waist.
If a woman stands or sits ir-~erly she
will not require, as so many tell me they
do, the support which a corset gives.
A girdle with straps over the shoulders,
ending about ti.ree inches above the
waist, relieves all pressure, which cer
tainly contracts and weakens the vital
organs. Tapes buttoned to the skirts keep
them from slipping down and remove the
weight from t^e waist to the shouiaers.
Try one. and see how cramyed a corset
makes you by the feeling of ease, and
how quickly that dragged-out weariness
will disappear, and you need not look
shapeless, either.*
To keep the skirts and separate waists
together, a contrivance has made its ap
pearance on the coast. Consisting of a
flexible metal belt, about an inch wide,
and hooks sewed to the skirt, it is a puz
zle how, but it does keep that difficulty
well in order, and is perfectly comfort
able.
Leather belts will be worn, but a pret
tier, newer design is two yards of satin
ribbon, four inches wide, to match the
skirt or harmonize With the tie. Pin one
end securely in front and pass the other
twice around the waist, tucking the other
under; hold it in place with a fancy pin.
Hats are literally loaded witn flowers,
some of the smaller ones being made en
tirely of smaller flowers nnd leaves for
the 'crown and brim. Roses wired Into
aigrettes form high trimming on one side.
Purple and white violets use . together
will be very popular, as will also very
natural Scotch heather, tiny forget-me
nots, roses, cornflowers and poppies.
Some of the hats set so far down on the
head as to give the effect at first of being
too big for the wearer, worn down to
shade the face and turned up in the back
over a mass of Â»iowers. Others, how
ever, are worn back over the face; the old
fashioned poke bonnet so becoming to our
grandmothers is among these.
Ties, too, so becoming to some faces, are
to be worn again in big bows at the
throat Bows separate from the bonnet
are very popular, indeed the bigger the
bow the better.
It is distinctly a "one-color season;
that is, the gown and hat and gloves
match instead of harmonize as has been
the fashion so long. Beware, however, of
the chiffon and tulle tucks and folds and
ties which are so soft and becoming. One
good California fog will reduce them to
a thing to be replaced. Although it is so
pretty, chiffon is a thing to be avoided
by an economical woman, for it so quickly
puts on the "soiled dove" air.
In trimming, baby velvet and satin rib
bon are used on every material, in rows
and clusters in different but harmonizing
colors, or all in one color. After a day of
work abroad the great comfort of home
is a wrapper, and its saving in wear on
the street dress will soon make it pay
for itself.
Challie makes a most serviceable and
pretty house dress at a cost of
$2 with perhaps another dollar for lace
and ribbon. A -lainty, pretty gown was
made from challie at six cents a yard,
eight yards being used. Cut with a seam
down the back, the front opened from the
left shoulder to the bottom. The entire
(j reps was lined with five-cent cambric
and bound around the neck, which had no
other collar, and down the front with
white wash silk, a crush belt of the white
ending in a rosette at the under aim
seam belted in the back, leaving the
front' loose, being held in place by tapes
sewed on the inside and tied in front.
Challie Is warm and light in weight and
washes well, coming in beautiful patterns
from fifteen cents to seventy-five cents,
i or dressing sacqiues, too, it is much pret
tier and quite as serviceable as the flan
nelette, which is clumsy and loses its
beauty at the first wash.
ORGAN MUSIC AND BACH.
Organ music reached its climax with
Bach; it may, perhaps, be said that all
music did. At any rate, one thing is cer
tainâviz., if there has been any progress
in music since tne day of Bach it has
been due to him. Bach's music is poly
phonic; and polyphony is true music. To
Its foundation upon this school is due the
fact that there has been no decadence In
music in Germany. â¦ â¢ â¢ There has
been no advance in polyphony since the
days of Bach. Such advance as nas been
made has been in originality and boldness
of modulation.
For pure organ music, Bach still is and
probably will always remain the greatest
of all composers. Even with all the mod
ern mechanical appliances that have been
attached to the organ, his works are still
very difficultâ perhaps the most difficult
of organ compositions. He must have
been as great an organist as he was a
composer. That he should have been
able to play upon the organ of his day
works so exacting in technique as his
own is simply marvelous.
It is one of the phenomena of musical
history that, while orchestral operatic
and other branches oi music were in their
infancy in Bach's day, and have devel
oped since then. Bach brought organ
music t^ Us climax.
SACRIFICED LIFE
For a
LILY WHITE PAGE
SOCIETY women who use the dead- J
lv arsenic wafer for th com
plexlon are increa; ng in numbers, j
According to a prominent phy
sician of this city.
Thougr a: ;enic is known to be harm
ful, "madame of society" forgets this in
her earnest search for something to
take the place >Â£ the legendary Foun
tain of Youth. When the first tiny
crow's feet begin to appear she is sud
denly reminded to take stock of her
charms. L.ate hours, rich food and want i
of proper exercise have done their :
work.
The muddy complexion must be
driven away, but not at the sacrifice of
social dissipations which sum up her
happiness. Somebody in her set sug
gests arsenic.
"But it's poison?"
"Oh, no. Don't take too much of it.
It is large doses you should guard
against."
A few weeks pass before the effects
of the slow poison are visible. The
clouded skin has gradually given place
to whiteness.
No unpleasant symptoms result for a
long time, and the consumer of arsenic
waters is thrown off her guard. When
the evils do cmc she does not for a
moment attribute them to the proper
source.
The first effects of the arsenic wafers
is to gradually destroy the small blood
vessels in the skin; therefore unnatural
whiteness, which a delicate rouge is
called in to relieve. Long continuation
of the use of arsenic brings many ills
in its train. The digestive organs be
come sadly out of order; loss of appe
tite follows, and madame finds her body
is wasting. She sits before her dress
ing-table and gazes sadly at her white,
attenuated countenance, with its fast
increasing defects. Late hours and
imprudent eating all get the blame.
Her physician is not informed of th>
arsenic wafers and other prescribed
drugs therefore increase the disturbed
state of the system. Convulsions, loss
of sleep, headaches, rapid heart action,
delirium and other terrible symptoms
are the result often of a continuation
of the habit.
Worse calamity of all, madame's lily
white skin, like the flower it resembles,
is not lasting in its fairness. If she is
wise enough to guess the cause of her
illness and confesses it to her medical
adviser, she may be relieved. But she
will by that time have destroyed her
appearance to such an extent that she
will never regain what she has lost.
SINCE MAN TURNED COOK-
"Who knows," the new woman cries to
day,
"But 1 was somewhat hasty
When- I forswore the married state?
Some men can turn out tasty
And tempting dishes when they try;
And matrimony's looking
Less prisonlike. I must confess,
. Since men have turned to cooking.
"Should we for single blessednesa,
Beloved sisters, thus band
Against the solid comfort and /â¢'-.â¢â¢
Convenience of a husband - â¢
Who'd -minister to each with cupÂ»
Of timely tea? Nay! Frates,
Come bake and broil for us and watcV
Our lares and penates!
"When from the pulpit or the bar.
Or busy mart or bucket
Shop, weary woman comes at night,
What most uncommon luck it
Would seem to find a man around
Who'd keep the kettle boiling,
And incidentally could keep
Her temper, too, from spoiling!
"Oh, man's improving, there's no doubt.
And soon he'll put a stitch In
Decadent stockings now and then,
As well as mind the kitchen!
To-day I'm more than half inclined
Toward Love, wno's gayly crooking
His finger, beck'ning me to turn
To man, who turns to cooking!"

The average speed of a carrier pigeon
in calm weather is 1210 yards a minute.
With a strong wind in the direction of
flight some pigeons have covered 1960
yards a minute.

TEACHERS AND SCHOOLS.
Some may claim that the old subject of j
the aim of education has been worn
threadbare, and yet It is astonishing what
ever-changing view? on pedagogy and the
ideas on the new education are coming to
the fore in the school world: how fre
quently even now the topic crops up ior
discussion. , . I
In order to ascertain the general trend
Of thought on this subject and also in re- !
gard to school discipline in San Fran- j
cisco, the following questions were-sent
out to a number of our representative
educators, with the annexed results:
1. What is the ultimate aim of educa- ;
tion? . ....
2. What are the objects of school dis- I
cipline? , mâ  . â  i
Miss Jean Parker, principal of the \
Broadway Grammar School, replies as
follows:
1. [appiness; good citizenship.
2. Obedience, Bince perfect freedom can !
come only through obedience to the law.
A. E. Kellogg, president San Francisco
Teachers' Club:
1. Taking education in its broadest
! should >ay that its ultimate end is
grow in the individual a sufficient mo
tive, an efficient will, and the fullest in- :
sight to realize himself in and through
the community of his fellows as It ad- )
vances toward an infinite ideal. School j
education works toward this end by ;
bringing the pupil to assimilate certain j
selected materials of human expei fence.
2. In answering the second question I ;
take "discipline" to mean the whoie op
eratlon of school government an 1 routine.
The end of school discipline is, then, to i
bring the pupil to an intelligent apprecia
tion of the relation of the individual m
ttid community, and to s< ;ure in him a j
willing and habitual co-opeiatior. toward I
the general good.
â¢ â¢ â¢
A. L. Mann, principal Denman School:
1. I should suy that the ultimate aim
of education is the training of thÂ» body, |
mind and soul of the pupil so that he
may be prepared to discharge perfectly I
every duty, private or public, that shall i
be incumbent upon him.
The school alone cannot accomplish al: ,
this. The home and society have each an
Important share In the work; but the !
school should keep this ultimate aim
in view, and so direct its efforts that tl.c
desired end may be attained as nearly is ,
]>"ssible.
2. The obiects of school discipline are j
determined by the work of the school.
That work cannot be efficiently carried
on unless many excellent qualities of '
moral character are well developed. |
Pupils must be obedient, respectful.
St, punctual, diligent, faithful, con- |
siii. rate of the rights of others, self
sacriticing and able and willing to work I
in harmony with others for a common
purpose. A little reflection will convince j
any one that the ordinary exercises of the j
classroom cannot be conducted with the ;
best results unless the moral traits above
named are deeply engraved upon the [
pupils' minds. Thus the discipline of the ;
school even more than the intellectual j
training given therein contributes to the |
attainment of the ultimate aim of educa- !
tion.
Madison Babcock writes:
1. The ultimate aim of education de
- upon the point of view from which
you approach the Question. From the
standpoint of the State it should be to
make an all-around, high-minded, patri
otic citizen. From the standpoint of the
individual the ultimate aim of education
is to make him of most worth to himself

ORDER OF THE AMARANTH.
At the mooting of Crescent Court in
the Red Men's building last Wednesday
nieht the royal matron presented to the
court a specimen of her Jjandiwork in
the shape of a white silk banner with
bullion fringe. On the face of the ban
ner she had placed in oil colors the sev
eral emblems of the order, which are
symbolical, and when grouped together
in the artistic manner they are on this
ullk. produce a fine effect. The gift was
received on behalf of the court by the
royal patron, George W. Drew, who
made a very 'miirf-ssive response and
then placed the banner in the keeping of
Henry M. Owens, the- honored herald.
The banner was very much admired by
all, and was specially commented upon
favorably by visitors from Mistletoe
Court of Minneapolis. These visitors also
f-xprr-ssed themselves as very favorably
impressed with the manner in which the
officers of the court performed their
work. This court ' has br-en placed in
charge of the Sloan booth that will be
one of the features of thi- Masonic Fair.

ANCIENT ORDER WORKMEN.
. L. M. Manzer, having declined the of
fice of Deputy Grand Master Workman

In which they were engaged.
. The appointment. of district deputies
â will not be announced "until "those who
have been recommended have had time to
'respond, to letters at in<iulnr .sent thÂ£S}
In his chosen life-work. Of course in a ,
way each of these Includes the other.
2. Correct school discipline leads to |
correct habits and all-around self-control. â¢
In a broad sense every proper school ex- I
erclse Is discipline.
â¢ â¢ â¢
Waiter X. Bush, principal of the Poly- j
technic High School:
1. There are so many types of educa- i
tion growing out of the needs of Individ- |
uals in our complex society, each type i
having its distinguishing characteristics. '
that it is far easier to say what the ulti
mate aim of education is not than to say
what it is. There is a type for the hew.r
of wood and another for the man whose
wood is hewn for him. The special train-
Ing necessary for the first would be worth
less to the second. When the *-riter was
a boy a good hand and a general knowl- .
edge of figures were sufileient require
ments for office work in any of the largi
factories in the East. To-day boys in the \
same relative position, drawing the same ;
pay, are required to have a broader
knowledge of affairs and special training
in stenography, English and typewriting.
The manufacture ajid Introduction of ma- j
chinery of Intricate and delicate construc
tion has made education in the elemen- I
tary principles of mechanics; heat, light j
and electricity, Indispensable even to the
Journeyman.
While these types are changing to meet
the changing conditions of our civiliza
tion the common aim of tb,em all is to
give man power to battle successfully
with the conditions about him. This power
may carry with It culture and social im
portance or it may not, Its quality de
pending upon the breadth of the type he
has followed, the selection of which is
determined by the power of the will, ca- j
pacity for self-denial, by ambition, by i
the degree of freedom from pressing j
want, and, most important of all per- !
haps, by his inherited tendencies, which !
break down all obstacles and drive htm '
Into broad fields of study and research. !
An education of this type should aim I
to secure not only mental power and
growth, but the ability to discern clearly
the source and significance of moral law
and its application to man in regulating
his conduct toward his fellows. In other
words, the ultimate aim of the highest
education is not only to make a man fit :
to encounter severe conditions of com- '
petitive living, but to assist him in his
approach to the fundamental truths of !
the natural and spiritual world.
2. School discipline changes the char
acter as the school changes its grade
from the primary to the grammar, from
the grammar to the high.
At the tender age of the child, when .
the mental faculty is limited to the work '
of the memory and its perceptions, un
questioning regard for authority is help
ful and necessary to it. As the child
grows older, and its power of comparison
gradually enables it to understand and
appreciate character, the arbitrary dis
cipline of the lower grade becomes less 'â 
essential to its development. Its respect
for the teacher grows out of the latter's
healthy mental and moral attitude
toward the child.
A teacher of negative character, of
weak or odd personality, no matter what
support lies behind and outside him, no
matter how profound his knowledge of
his subject, may mar but cannot fashion
the life of his pupil.
School discipline for students attending
our High Schools should be incidental to
the work of the school. It should serve to
assist the pupil to a better mental devel
opment, but not be emphasized as essen
tial to successful school work. The word
"discipline" is too strong. If a school
as to their inclination and willingness to
devote time to the duties required of
them.

THE NATIONAL UNION.
S. B. Doane. secretary of the Pacific
Council, died March 11, and on the 7th
inst. the widow was paid the amount
of the benefit certificate. $3000. This pay
ment, twenty-seven days after death, was
the promptest ever made on a California
claim, and the first of the nine benefits
the widow is entitled to that was paid.
Last Tuesday night Golden Gate Coun
cil had a good attendance to witness the
initiation of two candidates in the ampli
fied form. The work was performed in
an impressive manner by the officers
During the evening Financial Secretary
Theodore Frollch read some Interesting
figures as to the amount of money that
has passed through his hands since 1892
when he took the office. Received for
the general fund. $6498 50; for the bene
ficiary fund, $23,737 40. making a total of
$30,235 90. Of this amount paid on ac
count of beneficiary, there has been re
paid to beneficiaries of members $21 000
which is within ?2.i73 40 of the sum paid
into the beneficiary fund. This council
has been moving along at a healthy pace
in the past two years, and its growth
under the present president, N. R. Arter
has been remarkable.
El Dorado Council, at its meeting last
Friday night, had a number of candidates
initiated for It by the officers of the Cabi
net under the direction of President Has
tings, the work being done in a very
effective manner. After the work there
was a banquet to the members of the
Cabinet, visitors anu members of the
council.

ELLWOOD P. CUBBERLY.
E'.lwood P. Cubberly. at present City
Superintendent of Schools in San Diego.
but who will assume an important pro
fessorship in the department of education
at Stanford next year, was born in Indi
ana in IS6S. Mr. Cubberly received his
early education in Andrews, his native
town, and In ISS6 he entered the Univer
sity of Indiana as freshman. Two years
later he loft the university, taught a
>vhile, returned and then graduated in
Soon after graduation Mr. Cubberly
was elected to the chair of physical
science in Vincennes University, Indiana,
which boasts of having William Henry
Harrison as h'rst president of its Board
Of Trustees. In 1893 Mr. Cubberly was
chosen president of the same university
New life and spirit began to be mani
fested in the institution. The whole in
stitution was modernized.
In 1596 Mr. Cubberly resigned the presi
dency of Vincennes to become superin
tendent of the San Diego schools. He has
given San Diego a most excellent course
of study which is regarded as a distinct
advance in education.
PROGRESS IN ALAMEDA.
The parents' and teachers" meetings
conducted by Principal Hughes of vie
t.ncinal School, have been productive of
much good to the district. A lively in
terest In educational matters is notice
able. A desire to have the broadest and
most advanced instruction in the gram
mar schools has led many of tae parents
to study the foremost Eastern systems
in order to discover wherein their own is
deficient, and more than all, the close
co-operation of teachers and parents Is
advantageous to both in the highest de
gree.
Several weeks ago, as previously re
ported, the introduction of sewing into
the Eneinal School was discussed at a
meeting, and a committee was appoint
ed to investigate ne system, especially
in the San Francisco schools. So enthu
siastic was the report that at the next
meeting the parents present authorized
the same committee to go before the
Board of Education and request leave
for the experiment to be tried in the
school, all necessary expense beint* borne
by the parents directly interested Per
mission has since been granted, and the
ladies of the committee, together with
Principal Hughes and City Superintend
ent Sullivan, will meet Immediately in
order to arrange the present course of
study, so that it will include sewing in
all the grades.
This is a good start for Alameda in the
right direction. The Alameda Teachers'
Club, which was recently organized, now
numbers 110 names on its roll, which list
includes both active and associate mem
bers. Its present course of lectures is as
follows: "A Walk in Florence." by Pro
fessor E. H. Griggs: "Our Nation's Cap
itol (Illustrated), by Mr. Irwin- a lec
ture on Spain, by Professor Bernard
Moses.
Last week C. C. Hughes read a very in
teresting as well as instructive paper on
"Manual Training in the Elementary
Schools." His points were well taken
and were received with great attention
because he has been the first to introduce
the subject seriously in Alameda. Later
other representatives of manual training
Mr. Kenyon. Mr. Doyle. Mr. Neilson and
others, spoke in favor of the movement.
by the committee of arrangements, con
sisting of C. H. Buck, D. J. Wren. F. E.
Schober, C. J. Ward and H. S. Spauld

ager, led the grand march, In company
with Miss Rose McGovem.

OUR NATIVE DAUGHTERS.
Golden State Parlor at its last held
meeting was visited by District Deputy
Mrs. Genevieve Baker. This usually
active parlor has been for some time
past, as the genial recording secretary
says, "taking a rest."
Alta Parlor last Monday night Rave a
historical entertainment and dance in
Native Sons' Hall. There was a good at
tendance, that was entertained by the
presentation of a number of tableaux, a
fancy dance and vocal selections.
The farmers' social by Buena Vista
Parlor will be given in Nauve Sons' Hall
Mrs. Conrad, grand president, was in
this city last week. She is arranging to
visit the parlors in Mendoclno County
and the one at Crescent City prior to the
meeting of the Grand Parlor.
Mrs. Gunzendorfor of Sans Souei Par
lor is preparing a new ritual to submit to
the Grand Parlor.
Miss Mo. lie Johnson of California Parlor
of Sacramento, one of the past grand
presidents of the order, is preparing a
memorial service for presentation to the
Grand Parlor at itÂ» next session.
Nominations for delegates to the Grand
Parlor are to be made at the last stated
meeting of each parlor this month, and
the elections will be on the first meeting
nitrht in May.
Piedmont Parlor's "poverty party,"
given in aid of a fund to purchase a flag
for the parlor, was a successful affair,
and the members who are alive to the
fact that they should have a flag as well
as other parlors, and by displaying it at
meetings prove their patriotism and love
of "Old Glory." have decided to give other
parties in order to raise a fund that will
enable them to purchase a fine flag. This
parlor has had an increase in member
ship and it has a promise of a number of
new members in the near future.

city. Then followed a fancy dance by

ing's entertainment.

EDUCATIONAL GLEANINGS.
The common sense of the great public
should come to the rescue of the schools
and demand that school officers give to
their selected executive the absolute
power to select and manage his assist
ants.âThe Northwestern Monthly.
It Is a sad comment on educational af
fairs in this country that almost any one
is considered qualified to pive directions
to teachers, providing he has been able
to hoist himself by means of political ma
chinery into some' position of power.â The
Teachers' Institute.
â¢ â¢ â¢
It has been growing unpopular of late
to hold that children must be compelled
to behave properly, both at home and at
school, when they dn not willingly be

E. P. CUBBERLY, NOW OF STANFORD.

ber of thf committee were flauering to
the officers, who showed a proficiency in
the floor work and the memorized work
that is not met with in every circle. This
circle has three candidates for initiation.
Intpr Nos Circle on last Wednesday
was visited by the team that is to exem
plify the work before the Grand Circle
and it gave an . exemplification of the
work in a manner that prognosticates
success before the grand body.

INDEPENDENT FORESTERS.
Since last December there have been
organized and instituted new courts of
the order in this jurisdiction by supreme
organizers at San Die.RO. San Pedro
Berkeley, San Juan, Sulsun. Stockton
Benicia. St. Helena, Livermore, Nevada
<_lty and Alameda. The ones at Stock
ton and Alameda are the second courts
in those cities. Each was organized with
a good charter list. New courts are in
process of organization at Madera, Oak
land, Cloverdale and Grass Valley.

There was an audience that packed St.
George's Hall, on Mason street, on the
occasion of the open meeting of Pickwick
Lodge. As at the open meetings of this
lodge there is always a good programme
of entertainment, there is always a large
attendance. Among those who contribut

were J. H. Coates, W. T. Sobey, H. R.
Carles, T. Longworthy. Joseph Meyer
cough. A. R. Prior, W. C. Parsons. Hugh
Williamson. T. Nowlan and Messrs. Cal
ender, Edminster, Heed and Jones, wtio
favored with songs. T. Longworth. T.
Musgrave and F. D. Brandon gave reci
tations, and there were duets by Messrs.
Longworth and Jones and by Messrs. Cal
ender and Jones. During the evening re
freshments were served to guests and
members.
ORDER OF PEN'DO.
During the past three months this or
der has instituted ten councils which are
located in this State, Washington, Mon
tana and Florida.
C. D. Fowler, deputy for Washington,
will soon organize a ne* council in Cen
tralis. Wash., where one was organized
in March last.
Pomona Council initiated fourteen can
didates at one meeting in April.
Bannock Council of Idaho doubled it*
membership during the last term.
Golden Gate Council of this city, which
has been holding interesting meetings,
will have a number of candidates to ini
tiate at its next meeting.
Two new councils are being organized
in Los Angeles.
The Supreme Council has since last Jan
uary paid sick and pension claims aggre
gating to more than $2000.

â¢ â¢ â¢
The presence of trained specialists in
high schools would help to do away with
Incomplete, brief, sketchy courses. When
teachers have three or four subjects to
cover, they can do little 'more than ex
pound the textbook, and do not feel the
limitation of so doing, but when they are
full of their one subject they are con
stantly demanding and filling a large
place for it in the school curriculum.
The specialist who Is teaching one sub
ject in the high school is apt to know the
tacts of that subject more thoroughly
than the man who is teaching three. He
will also have at the same time more
leisure for recreation, reading and the
general interests of the school.â School
Review.

Score: San Francisco North and South, 9.
Trlst East and West. 4.
South at table No. 1 lost three tricks by
finessing his partner's 8 of diamonds at trick
nine. The ai:o of diamonds marked In East's
hand there was hardly and reason for such a
play. This Is a practical example of how easy
mntches are won and lost. It will pay every
student it the game to spread out the cards
In this deal, play and overplay them. Then ex
amine the play and overplay for comparison.
MR. WORK'S ADVICE TO WHIST PLAYERS,
"Mr. Work, what would you advise our play
ers to do to improve their team work?"
Answerâ To my mind the best method of im
proving team worn is for a team after it has
been selected, to as frequently as possible
practice together. That is, the four men sit
down at a table and play a hand, retaining the
cards in front of them as in duplicate play,
and then as soon as the hand is played re-play
It with the cards all face up exactly as played
originally, but whenever a play occurs the
wisdom of which is doubted by any one of the
four, or in regard to which any one of the
four desires anything said, the replay is stop
ped and the situation and the correct play i
at that time thoroughly discussed. This sys- >
tern of practice has many advantages. It en
fcblea each member of the team to realize how !
the minds of the other three act under certain
situations, and what they are apt to do. It >
brings up points on which there may be any
possible difference of opinion, and if thoroughly
carried out. results almost invariably in the
four men in the end playing a very similar ,
game. I do not believe that there is any other
method of practice that approaches it, or that
a team preparing for an important contest
can do too much of it for its own benefit.
Or course before starting this sort of practice
a system should, be agreed upon which is sat
isfactory to all, but it is not of so great Im
portance what the system may be as that the
members composing the team thoroughly un
derstand It. are satisfied with It. and unite
in the effort to produce the best results from
the use of it. '_
STOP IT! OR HANG OUT THE YELLOW
FLAG.
â  Tbe Evening Post of New York should be
congratulated by ' every ' one who has the best
Interest of whist at heart on the hlKh and
noble : stand It has recently taken In suggest
ing a separation of the chaff from the wheat
In whist circles. â  The article referred to ap
peared in the Post Wednesday, March 9. It
has "already commenced .to bear good fruit In
an. entirely \ different direction . from â¢ the one
really; intended. ;. The subject was "Profession
als vb. Non-profeeelonals." : .
We regret to say that onÂ« of the prominent
whist clubs in ' one of the large cities 'of > the

to take special delight in telling their
friends how - much ,-- money. they made
out of - whist last week. or -last
month. These men are now squirming
under the lash administered by the Evening
Post. - The article was evidently not written
with, the thought of hitting " this particular
class, but when any individual member or any
particularly .any- organization that â¢ is a
member " In * good i standing * of â¢. the ' American

â¢ â¢ *
Dr. E. H. Williams, president of the
Baldwin Locomotive Works, Philadelphia,
recently presented to the Sloyd School at
Santa Barbara several blocks of wood, in
which were mortices of various sizes, cut
with a bit which bores square holes. The
boys were so interested to see the instru
ment that Dr. Williams sent for one from
Philadelphia.
QUALIFICATIONS OF TEACHERS.
President J. H. Todd of the Oakland
Board of Education, in summarizing the
work of the city school department for
the past year, reported that the most
important feature before the board wan
the advance in standard of educational
qualifications required for teachers.
Continuing, he said: "But, in my mind.
that is not so important in selecting a
teacher for a school as that element
which develops the character. It is very
difficult to find just the individual to im
part or develop in the mind and heart
what we call character. That is much
more important than simple instruction
in the several branches of study, and Is
the most difficult to secure."
In these sentiments President Todd has
indicated the tendency of a movement
which is rapidly gaining momentum in
educational circles, and which promises
broader and deeper and higher and in
finitely better things for the children of
our public schools. That education
means merely an Improvement of the
earning capacity has been too much the
dominant idea of those who control
school affairs, and the unsatisfactory re
sults of this have set men to thinking.
After all, are not culture and character
the essential factors in enlarging the ca
pacity for human effort in the direction
of all truly useful as well as worthy and
lofty aims? This movement indicates a
reaction from the painfully practical to
the higher ideal in education.
It means that the child who has been
rightly taught will understand that the
true value of an education is not to en
able him to wear better clothes and :Â«â 
dwell in a finer house and to work 1> ssjÃ
and at easier tasks than his fellows, lo*
teach a child those things which will en
able him to become financially helpful
and self-sustaining is worthy of the best
efforts of the teacher, but the narrowing
down of an education to these mertly
practical ends, without proper ideals of
conduct and without motives which make
possible a higher material and spirtual
life, is fraught with gravest dangers 10
the individual, to the State and to hu-
manlty.
Well-equipped buildings, carefully ai
ranged courses of study and systems of
grading are desirable indeed, but they are
only secondary, while in the fitness, the
fidelity, the efficiency, and, above all. the
wholesome personal influence of the
teacher, is the vital element In the train
ing of the pupils of our public schools.
It is a gratifying indication of the rec
ognition of the value of tti" culture quali
fication in teachers when boards of edu
cation give expression to the thoughts
quoted from President Todd. With the
closer discrimination in the selection of
teachers which such opinions imply there
will surely come more satisfactory and
sympathetic relations between all the
people and our publlo educational sys
tem.
It is well to remember that the puhllo
pchool system is our protection against
greater dangers than those our country
may be exposed to from armored cruisers
of hostile nations, and upon the quality
of the teaching service of these schools
no patriotic citizen can afford to be in*
different. A. MEGAHAN.
Into the mire by using It for euch basÂ« pur- 1
poses and allowing the game to be played In 1
their rooms for a stake, the American Whist
League should say to them, as they did to one
of the clubs of Boston at the Sixth Congress:
"You are without the pale of our Institution.
and you must step down and out." The club
was expelled. When the time comes that we
have to blush with shame for taking our sons
or daughters Into a whist club and be obliged
to say to them, "This Is where we come to
spend our evenings; but it is no place for
you." we say the proper course to pursue Is
to cut the cancer outâ lf not. hang out the
yellow flag.
GOOD ADVICE TO WHIST STUDENTS.
By Lander M. Bouve of Boston.
To beginners, or players of limited expe
rience, the numerous new plays and systems
which have been developed during the past
year or two are undoubtedly confusing, and
tend to discouragÂ« students of whist in their
efforts to learn the game. It is not good
policy for any but the most expert players to
attempt to make use of the various new plays
exploited, as even the originators of many n{
these inventions admit that to a. larye extÂ»r.t
they are experimental. The advocates of the
long-suit game believe that the present more
or less unsettled condition of affairs is but a
forerunner of a return, by many of those now
attempting to demonstrate the value of these
so-called improvements, to the established
game as set forth by our most prominent
writers. If beginners will conscientiously
master the American lead?, and the plays
which are the basis of the long-suit gam'?,
they will find that as their experience grows,
they are able to hold their own against many
of the later ideas. The main factor of success
Is to make one's play easy for partner to
understand, and It Is an oft remarked fact that
many of the most brilliant players work their
partners so hard that it is a relief to the latter
when the game is finished. This is entirely
unnecessary, particularly if players will give
partner the assistance possible by means of
the number-showing leads, uniform plays un
der like conditions, and consistent following of.
the straight long-suit system.
BREACH OF ETIQUETTE.
We have been asked a good many times
"If It was allowable In whist clubs for a per
son to bold his cards and play them from
below the edge of the table."
In answer to this query we will say: There
is no written law to prevent such action; It
is only a breach of whist etiquette. The unwrit
ten law Is that the offender is usually Invited
to hold his cards "above board" so the hackft
of them can be seen by every one at the
ble- if he declines to do so. he has no standing
in respectable society, and he is usually in
vited to tender his resignation to the club.
Two such cases that we know of came up in
one of the Eastern clubs some time ago. and
one of the two was expelled, for he was caught
In doing what the very act suggests.
DOES MR. TRIST LIVE IN THE CITY?
At the Trist Duplicate Whist Club rooms
the other evening one of the most enthusiastlo
members of the club was entertaining as a vis
itor a gentleman and his wife from one of the
across the bay whist clubs.
Among other interesting things he was show
ing them, he called their attention to a very
large circular picture, made in the shape and
form of the emblem of the A. W. L., contain
ing some twenty portraits of the officers and
executive committee of the league. He pointed
out with considerable pride the central photo
graph, the father and founder, Mr. Eugene S
Elliott; also President H. A. Mandell. ex-Pres
trtent Theodore Schwarz, ex-Prealdent Walter
H. Barney, the great C. D. P. Hamilton. Rob
ert H. Weems. Vice President E. Leroy Smith
B. F. Richards, and others. Then he points!
to the one whom every child in the whist world
knows only to love. Mr. Nicholas Browse
Trist, mentioning his name with a sort of rev
erence, when our guest asks, "t>oes Mr. Trist
live in the city?"
WHISTLETS.
The Whist Editor of The Call has just re
ceived a letter from Lieutenant-Colonel Elliott,
Third Bengal Cavalry, Fyzabad. Oudh. Ben
gal, India, asking for a copy of The Call's
"Whist Don'ts" and "Whist Whys." The Call
will be delighted to send every Indian a copy.
We have sent several to Spain, but they don't
seem to have had the desired effect.
One of the oldest rules in whistâ in vogn<
over a hundred years ago â required each player
to place his cards in front of him, just as is
done to-day in duplicate whist.
J. A. Sublette of the Office Men's Whist Club
of St. Louis, Mo., Frank H. Goddard of the
Worcester Whist Club of Worcester, Mass.. and
D. W. Stroud of the Toledo Whist Club of To
ledo. 0.. have been sojourning in San Fran
cisco and making themselves at home in the
rooms of the Irist Duplicate Whist Club, where
every whist visitor to this city is welcome.
The Friday afternoon play of the Ladies'
Whist Annex to the Trist Club, which haÂ«
been so popular all winter, will continue
through the summer months. Mrs. F. Freder
icks, the secretary of this little organization, J
has changed her address to Belvedere. '
We have received an Inquiry from Miss Flor
ence Greene, secretary of the Woman's Whist
League, asking information in regard to the Â»
"Ladies' California Whist Club." if any one '
knows of such an organization in this city or
State a favor will be conferred on us by send
ing a list of its officers and members
The Canadian Whist League will hold Ha
annual congress In July at Toronto, Canada.
Further announcement will be made in TheWHY IT IS WISE
TO PAY SEVEN DOLLARS FOR A
MELBA SEAT.
r?y this time next week every oper
atic and theatrical entrepreneur with a
ivc e;ir to his business will have heard
â )f the thousands <>f Golden Westerners
*ho paid their little $7, $6, $5 and $4
md bo forth to acquaint themselves
with th^ musical personality of Melba.
And this should do us a deal of pood;
strengthen the legend of San Fran-
Jfsco'a appreciation of expensive enter
talnments (especially her practical, pe
runlary appreciation) with a few im
mediate facts, and generally boom our
reputation In the little offices on Broad
way, whore now our past prodigality is
almost forgot and we are held in none
too excellent affection. As one whoso
business and pleasure is considerably
mingled with the theatrical and musi
cal Interests "f San Francisco, I am
hoping heavily on this visit of Melba's.
Not that it, individually, is likely to
give us anything strenuously artistic
Â«n either opera or ensemble â that could
nardly be hoped for in the performance
peras whose attractions are, at this
o'clock In the development of dramatic
music, dependent almost solely on the
magic of a voioe and the glamour of
a name â but its financial success will
advertise- to the world and to ourselves
the possibilities of San Francisco as a
market for high-priced entertainments.
We need the ad.
For a long time now indifferent
shows indifferently patronized at the
higher priced theaters have attracted
attention to the bigger business accom
plished by tlio cheaper ones. These
cheaper theaters, the only ones that
kept up with whatever idea the public
has of their standards are, as a matter
of course, patronized; while the East
ern managers who bring vaudeville
and tenderloin farces, one after an
other, to what many persons still re
member as our one serious theater,
profit but slimly. if at all, and gf away
With the idea that this is "a cheap
Bhow town," never taking V .1 account
the fact that many of the old Baldwin
patrons who care only occasionally for
vaudeville (and never at all when it
has the tenderloin twist to it) have
been compelled to give up playgolng
altogether, because they do not know
where to look for the sort of drama
that pleases them.
I think it rankly unfair that San
Francisco should accumulate an unen
viable reputation for, cheapness merely
because si. persistently ref- :es to ac
cept as steady diet a class of theatri
cal entertainment that bears as little
relationship to sane drama as an un
dergrouAod dancehall does to contempo
rary Bocial commerce.
And while a one-star performance of
Verdi's "Travlata," even with the great
est Boritura singer in the world to as
: irgetfulness of the absurd absence
of 'iramati' allusion, may not be as no
ble a cause for â¢ xtravagance as is, say,
the regular symphony season or th>
single performance at Beethoven's
Ninth Symphony at Fritz Scheel's ben
efit, it certainly is the legitimate oeea
â A of excitement In
a city where opera is preciously loved,
where anything but ordinary singing is
th>i rare exception, and where Melba,
the acknowledged empress of her
sphere, has never sung before. The Cal
ifornia Theater Is practically sold out
fur the three nights, I am told by the
management, and an extra perform
ance, made up of single acts of other
operas, Is under consideration. The re
ceipts for the four nights would be
nothing short of $30,000â a pre!*'- com
fortable showing for a comparatively
small and one-star organization.
Then there is the opera-house ques
tion, which comes up every time opera
is mentioned in San Francisco. Every
body knows that if we had had an au
ditorium sufficiently large to house a
grand-opera audience the best Melba
seats would have Bold for about half
of $7 with equal profit to the promo
ters; that long before now we would
have had not only Melba, but the De
Reszkes, Calve, Eames, Placon, Bish
pam and all the big stars who parti
cipated in the high-salary crime at the
Metropolitan. I used to read those
burning editorials on the evils of high
salaries and the inartisticness of stellar
glorification written by the satiated
opera experts of the New York news
papers and gasp with envy.
At that time New York had th^ pick
of the operatic world. Nothing was too
AMUSEMENTS.

BY ASHTON STEVENS.
! gond for her; in fact hardly anything
I was quite good enough. She could hear
j Wagner, Gounod, Meyerbeer, the old
! operas, the elderly and the youthful,
\\ ith an ideal cast and an ideal leader
i for eachâ and at prices not much great
i er than we "have paid to hear organiza
tions whose very names were unknown
in New York; and yet she protested on
| grounds not only economic, but artistic.
, I used to read all about it and
wonder just what would happen to the
i man who would criticize opera in San
Francisco from a like standard of ex
cellence.
For many years we have been utterly
out of it so far as opera is concerned.
We h;ivÂ«- h;ul the r.gular reasons at the
Tlvoll, the terrible invasions of Mad
ame Tavary, the operatic concerts of
Nordica, the little French company and
the little Italian company, and we have
come to have a very decent acquain
tance with lots of valuable works â but
not since the last farewell of Patti have
we heard the human voice divine such
as is promised in the singing of Melba.
The operas in which Melba will ap
pearâ"Traviata," "The Barber" and
"Lucia"â are anciently familiar; her
company is not the one that offended
the anti-high-salaryites in New York;.,
but the Voice which will sing the meas
ures of Violetta, Roslna ai.d Lucia is
reputed the greatest for those roles that
the world now knows. So let loose the
flower, fashion and treasure of the town
for Melba â and some day perhaps they
will think bettor of us in New York;
and who knrrws but some day some
dare-devil millionaire of our own will
build an opera-house of stone and
brick on solid ground in place of the
gaudy edifices of adjectives and ex
clamation points that are erected every
week or so in the newspapers.

THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1898.
! asking why Clement Scott had been
: permitted to resume his position of dra
j matic critic of the London Telegraph,
the editor. Sir Edward Lawson, wrote in
reply, that while he held the histrionic
1 profession in much honor he could not
j see that its members were especially
i qualified or authorized to edit the Daily
i Telegraph.
Here's a musical story that the musi-
I cal critics of New York are all talking
: about, writes Acteon Davies: "Last
! week at a concert uptown the audience
' was called upon to rise and sing "The
Star Spangled Banner." All the au
dience save one man sprang to their
feet and began to sing. Noticing this
a man seized the sitting one by the
arm and cried: "What's the matter,
old man? Why on earth don't you get
us and sing?"
The sitting man drew himself up
haughtily, and whether there was a
twinkle in his eye or not perhaps will
never be known. However, his reply
was:
"I do not think it would be at all the
proper thing for a member of the Even
ing Post staff to sing 'The Star Span
gled Banner.' "

bert for his recent tirade against the

"A certain actor â we'll mention no

With apologies to an unremembered
poet, the Philadelphia Record rises to
remark:
Slay Irwin, it is true you're stout and in your
teens no longer.
'Tls tru^ your charms are opulent and mel
low;
One can't deny your healthy voice Is Just a
trifle stronger
Than that which charms the average sort of
fellow.
And yet I do protest you win my honest ad
miration â
The cause of which effect's extremely simple-
You make mo think of some plump baby, crow
ing in elation.
That beams jocundity from every dimple.
Your fun is of the wholesome sort that passes
without question;
Your full-niiMin face is halm for any sinner;
Your rogulsn jests, your jolly songs, facilitate
digestion,
And make one feel the better for his dinner.

Opera.
Verdi's "La Traviata" has been se
lected for Melba's opening on Tuesday
night because it not only displays Mel
ba in one of her most famous roles, but
because it is said to find excellent in
terpretation at the hands of her sup
porting company, and of the three
works in the present repertory makes
the best showing as a production. The
story of Dumas' lady of the camellias
is an old one and well known here, both
in its dramatic and operatic forms.
Those who have heard Patti as the
tuberculous heroine cannot but have
happy recollections of the part snd a
natural desire to hear it sung by the
one who now universally is acclaimed
Patti's successor. Salignac, a Parisian
tenor, will appear as the hero. Cam
panari, an Italian barytone of reputa
tion, will be the father. Signor Bim
boni, who directs, is one of the very
foremost of Italian opera leaders.
The following is the "Traviata" cast
in full:
Violetta Mme. Metba
Flore Mme. Van Cauteren
Amrriiia Mme. Matfeld
Alfredo Muns. Salignac
Germoiit Bfg. Campanari
Barone Vivian!
Dottare big. Carhone
Qastone Mr. V;m Hooae
Marchrse Mr. Rains
Conductor, Sig. Blmbonl.
The second performanc tal-es place
on Thursday night with "The Barber
of Seville" as the bill, one of the most
playful and b'jnnrous of the old stand
ard operas. It is said by many that
Melba does her finest work in the part
of Rosina. This is the cast for "The
Barber":
Ropina Mcl ba

Golumbia.
The only dramatic novelty of the
week will be offered at the Columbia to
morrow night in the shape of a farcical
| comedy by Glen Maedonough, who
' wrote "The Prodigal Father," called
i "Delmonlco's at Six," in which Marie
Jansen, who for years was a strong
comic opera favorite in New York is
I the bright particular figure.
Here is the plot of "Delmonico's at
Six":
Dr. Hamilton Clark, a physician, and
his young friend, Captain Holland, who
I is in love with the former's daughter,
i go out on a lark and come home late.
j Clark thinks his life is too tranquil.
j and in order to create a breeze at home
| purchases a photograph of a stage
! celebrity, places it where his wife can
| find it, and then dictates a letter to his
j friend saying that he is to dine at Del
j monico's at 6 with the famous vaude
ville artiste, Trixie Haselmere. The
letter is left where his wife can find
it. Clark sows a mild breeze, but reaps
a cyclone. He repairs to Delmonico's
at the appointed hour and meets Trixie
Haselmere, who has accidentally heard
of his plot and determines to punish
him for using her name by carrying it
! out to the letter. The wife arrives upon
the scene and complications ensue in
quick succession. Other characters are
a dime museum strong man, a French
waiter, who poses as a Count, a sawed
off detective and a maid who is too
smart for anything. Miss Jans^n's
company includes Clarence Montaine,
Harry Beresford, Mack Charles, George
Fell, Frank Caldwell, Mrs. F. A. Tanne
hill. Miss Sylvia .Lyndon, Miss Jessie
Bradbury and Miss Elice Bertram.
BaldWirv.
Hoyt's tenderloin celebration, "A
Stranger in New York," continues all
of this week at the Baldwin. A week
from Monday Ferris Hartman and the
company which he has brought from
New York will give us the first pro
duction in America of "The Purser," a
farce that has been very successful in
the British provinces. The scenes are
on an ocean steamer, bound from Lon
don to Australia, and the characters
are the captain, the ship's doctor, the
purser and other officers of the vessel
and the passengers. Mr. Hartman will
be seen in the title role, a ,part which
it is said suits his peculiarities to a
nicety. The English scene models have
been sent to this country and will be
followed exactly.
Alcazar.
"The Strange Adventures of Miss
Brown" has taken so well with the
Alcazar audiences that it will be con
tinued another week. "The Gay Pari
sians," one of the very cleverest of re
cent farces, arid one that was a big
success at the Baldwin last season
when Charles Frohman sent it out, will
follow. L. R. Stockwell and Howard
Scott have been engaged for the pro
AMUSEMENTS.

Tiv>oli.
The Tirol] continues its Easter bur
lesque, "Sinbad the Sailor," until fur
ther notice. Gay scenery, costumes, ac
cessories, light effects, catchy music
and bright topicals all go to make
up a home production worthy ol
the crowded houses that night
ly attend it. Helen Merrill is
a handsome hero; Carrie Roma a
characteristic and excellent Widow Sin
bad, and her impersonation of Anna
Held one of the comic hits of the sea
son; Georgie Cooper is the stunning
Princess, and Edith Hall the dashing
Fatima. Edwin Stevens finds in Cap
tain Paul Jones O'Scuttle. the Irish pi
rate, one of the most congenial extrav
aganza roles he ever has attempted,
and with Thomas C. Leary as Tinbad
the tailor and Phil Branson and Bob
Mitchell as Hokey and Chokey, the
heavenly twins, the fun is fast and
furious. The ballets, under the direc
tion of Miss Christine Stockmeyer, are
most attractive, especially the dance ol
the precious gems in the second act.
Nearly every night new material ia
introduced and new verses added to
the topical songs and ensembles. This
week Carrie Roma will sing a new
song, "To My Love," the words by her
self and the music by R. F. Tilton.
Morosco's.
The first three acts of "The Diamond
Breaker," which will be Morosco's at
traction for next week, take place in
the Alleghany mountains, the closing
scenes transpiring in New York city.
Squire Alden has incurred the enmity
of the "moonshiners" and is murdered.
The squatters take possession of his
lands. His daughter, Rex, on reaching
womanhood, commences legal action,
for the recovery of her estate and is
seconded in her efforts by her lover,
Walter Warren, a young inventor. Thus
far the "lot has been exciting, but later
developments become simply lurid.
Walter is cast into the gaping jaws of
the diamond breaker, which is an im
mense coal crusher. From almost cer
tain death he is rescued by Rex, who
makes a thrilling slide for life to ac
complish her heroic purpose. She in
turn is spirited away to an insane asy
lum, where the torture of the whipping
post, meted out to her by the villain,
and the hideous vagaries of her insane
companions, drive her almost frantic.
She is rescued by Walter, who enters in
the disguise of an Italian. There la
enough of the intensely thrilling about
the plot to give the ordinary auditor a
nightmare and tickle the "gods "' to
death. Scenes of wild enthusiasm will
doubtless be the order for the week.
Orpheum.
The Hyde company of vaudevillers
have scored a large hit at the Orphe
um, where they remain until after the
Saturday night performance. Although
the list of people stands the same sev
eral of the turns will be changed.
Helen Mora will have new descriptive
snngs, Mclntyre and Heath a new
black-face skit, and Williams and
Walker several new songs and gags to
introduce in their cake-walk. Thorne
and Carlton, Charles R. Sweet, the
piano tramp, the Great Lafayette and
the supple Ajax will continue in their
original specialties. Hyde's is the best
all-round vaudeville show the Orphe
um has offered in many a day.
California.
Edward Harrigan closes a successful
week of "Old Lavender" with to
night's performance. Next Sunday
night a local production of "Trilby"
will be given in the California at cheap
prices. Frederick Paulding will be the
Svengali and Fannie Gillette the Tril
by.
Ghutes.
The open-air and indoor attractions
at the Chutes include Wallace, the
"untamable lion"; Jolly, the docile ele
phant: Chiquita, the condensed Cuban
patriot, and a big variety bill in the
Free Theater.
Olympia.
The Olympia Music Hall, in addition
to the usual string of talent, will have
the Martelles, trick bicyclists, and
Mandola, the master of equipoise, in
an entirely new line of tricks in bal
ancing and juggling while poised on
the revolving globe. Others on the bill
are Chevriel, trick violinist; Harry Ell
wood, female impersonator, and Mac
Tunison, soprario.
Gorvcerts.
The many musical and other friends
of Alfred Wilkie, the well-known tenor,
will tender him a "testimonial benefit
concert" on Friday evening, April 29, at
Sherman & Clay's Hall. 223 Sutter
street. An attractive programme has
been arranged, and the prospects are
for a large attendance.
The suite made up from Grieg's mu
sic to Ibsen's "Peer Gynt," Liszt's first
rhapsody, and a symphony by Fred
Zech Jr., are on the programme of
Thursday's symphony concert at the
Tivoll.

COMMERCIAL WORLD.
SUMMARY OF THE MARKETS.
Bank Clearings show the usual gain.
Silver unchanged.
Wheat and Bar >y Futures advanced.
Corn and Surprise Oats higher.
Rye steady.
Straw and Oat Hay advanced.
Flour and Mlllstuffs unchanged.
White Heans higher.
Flaxseed lower
Potatoes and Onions steady.
Vegetables unchanged.
Putter and Eggs about as before.
Arrivals of Strawberries Increasing.
Navel Oranges lining better.
Fair demand for Dried Fruit.
Several kinds of H.des weaker.
Meats unchanged.
HANK CLEARINGS.
Local bank clearings last week were $17,472.
[>77. against $14,753,418 for the same week last
year.
EXPLANATION.
The arrow files with the wind. The top fig
ures at station Indicate minimum temperature
for the days: those underneath It, if any, the
amount of rainfall or of melted snow In Inches
end hundredths during the , ast twelve hours.
Isobars, or solid lines, connect points of equal
air pressure; isotherms, or dotted lines, equal
temperature. The word "high " means high
barometric pressure and is usually accompanied
by fair weather: "low" refers to low pres
sure and Is usually preceded and accompanied
by cloudy weather and rains. "Lows" usually
first appear on the Washington coast. When
the pressure Is high in the interior and low
along the coast, and the isobars extend north
and south along the coast, rain is probable;
but when the "low" Is Inclosed with isobars of
marked curvature, rain south of Oregon Is Im
probable. With a "high" in the vicinity of
Idaho, and the pressure falling to the Cali
fornia coast, warmer weather may be expected
In summer and colder weather in winter. The
reverse of these conditions will produce an
opposite result.

WEATHER CONDITIONS AND GENERAL
FORECASTS.
Fair weather still continues throughout Cali
fornia anil the region to the eastward. The
pressure Is increasing somewhat In the North
Pacific Coast States and falling in California.
This will result in fair weather In California,
with fresh to brisk northerly wind and slowly
rising temperature.
Forecasts made at San Francisco for thirty
hours ending midnight. April 17, 1898:
Northern Californiaâ Fair Sunday; fresh to
brisk northerly wind.
Southern California â Fair Sunday; fresh
westerly wind.
Nevadaâ Fair Sunday.
I'tahâ Fair, cooler Sunday.
Arizonaâ Fair Sunday.
San Francisco and vicinityâ Fair Sunday;
warmer: fresh northerly wind; high northwest
off shore.
SpecUl report from Mount Tamalpais. taken
at 5 p. m.â Clear; wind west, 36 miles per hour;
temperature, 54: maximum, CO.

EASTERN MARKETS.
NEW YORK STOCK MARKET.
NEW YORK. April 16.â The tone of to-day's
stock dealings, while dull and depressed, gave
no very active Indications of apprehension. Tt
was rather a waiting market, as for some time
past. Thp transactions outlsde of operations
by professionals were insignificant. Selling by !
traders found few seekers, and prices conse- i
quently yielded very readily. On the other j
hand, when the professionals turned buyers |
they found few stocks offering, and prices con- !
sequently equally recovered. Naturally the net j
result* of this kind of Juggling from one hand ;
to the other and then bade again was not
large, though the day's price was pretty wide. |
The opening decline was due to sympathy with I
London, where Americans all showed a heavy j
tone and where Spanish 4's relapsed after yes- I
terday's recovery, closing within % of the low
est price made- last Wednesday in the bear
raid. Eurov>oan operators had apparently lost
their confidence In the efficacy of the reported
project for concerted mediation l>y the powers.
The active preparations being made by the
United States admonished observers that the
Congressional differences over the technicali
ties of the Cuban resolution were not expected
to Interfere with the substance of their action
Involving armed intervention, and some slipht
recoveries In the second hour were due to cov
ering by the aborts, but they were not held,
ami the list showed net declines in nearly all
cases, for the most part confined to fractions.
Tobacco absorbed a large rÂ«art of the deal
ings and suffered a loss of 9 a ii on very heavy
offerings, brought out by the recent jump in
prices. Sugar, the Grangers and I'nlon Pa
cific preferred were the other most active fea
tures, but the market was very narrow.
The decline of gold from I^ondon has raised
the discount rate there and stiffened exchange
on London at Continental centers, but the gold
movement to New York continues Without
signs of abatement. The conditions thus dis
closed, combined with the large liquidation of
Indebtedness known to have occurred In the
country, give confidence in the ability of the
financial fnbrlc to withstand the shock of war.
Transactions, aside from call loans for money
wait on the clearinc of the situation, and
partly also on the expectation of a Govern
ment loan. Hut apprehension of the effect of
war 0(1 money and business Is appreciably less
than three weeks ago. Therefore, while prices
are between 1 and 2 points lower than a week
auo, they are very substantially above the
low point touched just 'previous to the presenta
tion to Concress of the Maine Board of In
quiry report.
The market for railroad bonds has been in
tensely dull and prices lower. Government
bonds are lower, declines In the bid price
reaching 2* In the new 4'h coupon, 2 in the
coupons. I' 4 In the new 4's registered, W. in
the old 4'B registered, 1 In the old 4's coupon
and % In the s's.
Total sales of stocks to-day were 1X3,500
shares, including: Burlington, r>?o2: St. Paul
7590; Union Pacific preferred, r>ss<l; Union Pa
cific D. and G., 6340; American Tobacco 6638-
Sugar. 12,890.

LONDON MARKET.
NEW YORK. April 16â The Evening Posfs
London financial cablegram says: Pending the ;
result of the vote on the Cuban resolution In \
the I'nlted States Senate the markets here are ,
dull and stupid, with lower prices. Consols j
were to-day i^Ui per ctnt lower. Americans j
were from .Vic's sl lower, with no business do- |
ing. with business following Wall street. Span
ish 4s were about 42S-
Cables from New York report an impression
In that market that Americans are chiefly
manipulated now from London. This must not
be confused with operations by English specu- ,
lators. Such manipulation as exists in this
market is on behalf of New York operators.
The money market was easier to-day.
< I-oSING.

cent. .
LONDON. April lfi. 2:30 p. mâ Spanish 4s
closed at 42 V Â«. a net loss of 1\ from yesterday's :
closing quotation.
BERLIN. April 16â During the early part of
the day business on the Bourse was weak.
notably bank shares, Italian securities and i
American stocks, owing to the continued arma
ments.
PARIS. April 16.â The opening of the Bourse |
here to-day reflected London's weakness. Real- I
izations ruled, speculators were anxious to re
duce their open accounts, owing to the uncer
tainty of the outlook, and there was a further
heavy decline in the price of Spanish 4b, a re
sult of the news that the Senate would not
adjourn until the Cuban resolutions were voted
upon. Rentes. Brazilians. Italians and Rus
sians were also materially lower. Rio Tlntos
were largely offered.
4 p. m.â Spanish 4s closed at 42%, l*i lower
than yesterday's final price.
ASSOCIATED BANKS' STATEMENT. .
NEW YORK. April 16.â The Financier says:
Despite the heavy and continued demand for j
funds from the interior and clearing house â 
banks, according to their statement for the
current week, they were able not only to hold I
their own in the way of cash, but added over |
$2,000,000 to surplus reserve, making the latter
Item the largest reported since January 1. In
the light of present events, the statement must
be regarded as favorable, since it reveals the |
wonderfully strong position of the banks. Ordi
narily it would mean lower money rates this
week, but unless a pacific solution of the Span- 'â 
tsh crisis presents itself, no such reduction may
be anticipated. The operations of the week I
brought about a shrinkage of $7. 697. W0 in loans, j
due to continued liquidation and the entire ab- \
sence of new business, the banks confining ;
themselves to the needs of their own cus- :
tomers. Out of town banks, it Is worthy of I
note, are doing some buying in this market, j
tempted by the stringent rates. Deposits were j
reduced $6,637,600. owing largely to withdrawals
of balances. The interior movement is shown :
In the loss of $3,824,200 in legal tender. Specie
imports account for the gain of $4,554,400 gold,
and the net result was an increase of nearly
three-quarters of a million cash.
The loss in deposits lowered the reserve re
quirements $1,579,400. This, added to the caÂ«h
gain, swelled the surplus as above.
The country has now imported or engaged
| over $60,000,000 of gold, but the New York
banks to-day hold only $2,000,000 more cash I
than when the movement started. The specie
received has merely replaced the withdrawals I
1 by interior banks, and It Is a problem whether ,
the futura demand on New York will be aa
! heavy as ftntlelpated.
Domestk- exchange Is at a heavy discount at |
interior cities, and from all that can be learned '
the cash withdrawn is not being employed at
I home. The fact that outside Institutions are
; loaning money here Is not without significance.
' The outlook favors continued imports of gold.
â  and these, with the heavy disbursements made
I by the treasury, may operate to produce an
I easier state of affairs. It would not be sur
: prising if present rates proved to be the maxl
! mum for the year. The country has so much
! money that It Is prepared to meet expenditures
of an extraordinary' magnitude without embar
i rassment. The trouble now Is that this is be
; ing hoarded, rather than put into use.
