V CHICAGO GRAIN MARKET.
CHICAGO, April 16.â Traders In wheat were
treated to a genuine surprise at the opening.
In spite of all the selling done here yesterday,
millions of bushels by the lonK Interests, and
notwithstanding; the drop of 3c a bushel In
July, all foreign markets rami> higher. Liver
pool In particular whs strong, showing ad
vanceH ranging from ' B Â»tu %d. A feature of
the advance at Liverpool was the fact that the
July price there was 25c higher than the pre
vailing price in this market, or considerably
THE SAX FBANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1898.
above the average shipping rates. New York
reported that acceptances of wheat in all po
sitions made by cable from there yesterday
were the heaviest of the season, practically
everything offered being taken. It was evident
from this that the belief In war overshadowed
everything else In the minds of the foreigners.
The opening trades in July were at from 85%@
85%e, against 84%<?84%c at the close yesterday.
For a moment or two the market hesitated.
Then it commenced to advance, and for forty
five minutes the buying demand was simply
enormous. All classes of traders came Into
the market for wheat. It was not a one-man
market ; the demand was general and broad.
Not until the price had advanced to 87% c was
there any marked selling pressure. This price,
however, was well above calls, and selling
against these privileges, coupled with liberal
realizing of a general kind, put a stop to the
advance and caused the market to recede
slowly to 86% c. Apparently by this time the
demand for wheat had been pretty well satis
fied, for although the market reacted to 87Vic.
it was done slowly, the latter point not being
reached until about 11:30 o'clock. During the
last half hour of the short session the mar
ket was comparatively quiet but firm, with
prices keeping within a \c margin. The clos
ing price for July was 86% c.
Corn .was strong from the start. May closed
%<if%e higher. Â
There was an active general trade In oats.
Prices closed rather easy. May closed Vs@Vic
higher.
Provisions were very dull. War talk and the
strength of grain markets caused a small
early advance, which wa.s lost later under sell
ing by local packers. The close was steady.
May pork H%c lower, May lard 24c higher and
May ribs 2' 2 c lower.

EXPORTS AND IMPORTS.
NEW YORK, April 16.â Exports of specie
from this port for the week $819,780 silver bars
and coin and $160,620 gold.
The imports of specie at New York for the
week ending to-day were $5,562,580 in gold and
$46,232 in sliver.
The imports of dry goods and merchandise
for the week were $8,734,101.

the week was very quiet and there were only
a few transactions. The arrivals to date for
the third series of Wool auction sales number
294,497 bales, including 110,500 forwarded direct.

HAY AND FEEDSTUFFS.
The only changes yesterday were an ad
vance In Straw and Oat Hay.
Alfalfa Is on Its way from Arizona, but as
it costs $16 here It will not affect the market
much. It costs the same to lay the same
: grade down here from I'tah, and as the sup
; ply from both these quarters will be limited
i we cannot expect much relief in these direc
| tlons. Nor can Oregon send us much of her
j Hay, so we may have to depend on our own
| crop after all. The outlook, therefore, is for
fancy prices for the next twelve months, as
! far as can be seen at present. The State was
< never so hard up for Hay before.

THE STOCK MARKET.
The close of the week found mining stocks
considerably lower than at the close of the
preceding week. In fact, it was the most de
pressed week these securities have seen for
some time.
Trading on the Bond Exchange also fell off
last week, except yesterday, when business
picked up again. The main features were
lower prices for Hawaiian Commercial and
Oceanic Steamship.
The output of ore from the Consolidated Cali
fornia and Virginia last week was 38 tons, of j
the average assay value of $59 46. The amount
of ore extracted during the previous week
was 57 tons, of the average assay value of
$37 34.
The Sierra Nevada Mining Company has re
ceived $2412 as the net proceeds of 4650 pounds
net weight of concentrates treated at Selby's,
and $101*4 in gold coin and silver of the esti
mated value of $520 from the United States
Mint at Carson, Nev., as the net proceeds of
1096 pounds crude bullion shipped to that Mint
from the Nevada mill.
The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company has
declared a quarterly dividend of $3 per share,
payable this week.
The Alice Mining Company of Montana has
declared a dividend of 5 cents, amounting to
$20,000, payable April 27.
The Sacramento Mining Company of Utah
has declared a dividend of % cent, amounting
to $5000, payable April 30.
The South Swansea Mining Company of Utah
has declared a dividend of 5 cents, amounting
to $7500, payable April 21.
The Bullion-Beck Mining Company of Utah
paid a dividend of 10 cents, amounting to
$10.0i)0. April 12.
The Portland Mining Company of Colorado
paid a dividend of IV4 cents, amounting to
$45,000, April 15.
The Vallejo Quicksilver Mining Company of
Napa County has levied an assessment of 1
cent, delinquent May 12.
The delinquent assessment sales of the Ophir
and Crown Point will be held to-morrow.
The annual meeting of the California Beet i
Sugar Estate and Land Company, limited, has j
been called for April 21.

WANTS COMMON SENSE.
French literature wants the saving
element of common sense. Nothing
could be more brilliant than Victor
Hugo in 1830. His verse flashes like
the white plume of Navarre. His was
the most famous charge in literature.
The courage and brilliancy of "Her- j
nani" and "Ruy Bias" are prodigious, '<
but they lack common sense. They j
conquer, win deafening applause, be
wilder men with excitement, but, vie- j
tory won, they have not the aptitude
for settling down. The great French
literature of the romantic period did
not dig foundation, slap on mortar or
lay arches in the cellars of its house
after the English fashion.
Next to Victor Hugo, not counting
Goethe, the greatest man of letters in
Europe of this century is Sir Walter
Scott. Mark the difference between
him and Hugo. Scott's poetry and no
vels have a vigorous vitality from his
common sense, and therefore they are
ingrained in the trunk of English lit
erature; the fresh sap of their romance
quickens every root and adds greenery
to every bough. Victor Hugo is pas
sionate, imaginative, majestic, power
ful, eloquent, demagogical, but he does
not stand the hard test of squaring
with the experience of common men. â
March Atlantic.
"Well, James, how are you feeling to
day?" said the minister to one or his
parishioners, an old man suffering from
chronic rheumatism. "You are not look
ing as brisk as usual."
"Na, sir," replied the old fellow sadly,
"I've been gey unfortinit the day."
"How, James?"
"Weel, sir, I got a letter fra a Glasco
lawyer body this mornln' tellin' me tha
ma cousin Jock was died, an' that he had
left me twa hunner poun'."
"Two hundred pounds," repeated the
minister. "And do you call that hard
luck? Why, it is quite a fortune for you,
James."
"Ay," said the old man sorrowfully,
"but the stipid lawyer body dinna pit
eneuch stamps on his letter, an' I had a
hale saxpence to pey for extra postage."
â Lewiston (Me.) journal.

NOTICE TO MARI-.ER3.
A branch of the United States Hydrographlo
Office, located in the Merchants' Exchange. Is
maintained In San Francisco for the benefit of
mariners without regard to nationality and
free of expense.
Navigators are coi lally Invited to visit the
office, where complete sets of charts and sail
ing directions of the world are- kept on hand
for comparison and reference, and the latest
Information can always be obtained regarding
lights, dangers to navigation and all matters
of Interest to ocean coir.merce.
The time ball on top of the building on Tele
eraph Hill Is hoisted about ten minutes teforo
noon and Is dropped at noon, 120 th meridian,
by telegraphic signal received each day from
the United States Naval Observatory at Mar*
Island Cal.
A notice stating whether the time ball was
dropped on time i-â¢ giving the error. If any. Is
published the Fame day by the afternoon
papers, and by the mornlncr papers th<Â» follow
ing day. W. R HUGHES.
Lieutenant. T7. S. N.. In charge.
SUN. MOON AND TIDE.
United States Coast and Geodetic Survey.
Times and lielghts of High and Ixiw
Waters at Fort Point, Entrance to San
Francisco Bay. Published by Official Au
thority of the Superintendent.
NOTEâ The high and low waters occur at
the city front (Mission-street what*) about
twenty-five minutes later than at Fort Point:
the height of tide Is the same at both places.

NOT3 â In the above exposition of the tides
the early morning tides are given In the left
hand column and the successive tides of thÂ»
day In the orcer of occurrence as to time. The
second time column gives the second tide of
the (lay, the third time column the third tide,
and the last or light hand column gives the
last tide of the day, except when there are but
three tides, as sometimes occurs. The heights
riven are additions to the soundings on thÂ»
United States Coast Survey charts, except
when a minus sign (â)( â ) precedes the height
â¢nd th*n the number given Is subtractlve from
the depth given by the charts. The plane of
reference la the mean of ti lower low water*.

MEMORANDUM.
The schr Lottie Carson from Newport bound
for Eureka put in on account of carrying away
forestay April 14, 50 miles SW of the Farallon
Islands in a strong NW gale.
MISCELLANEOUS. .
Per schr Webfoot â While coming to an an
chor off Black Point lost both anchors, and in
drifting up the bay collided with the Br bark
Invercoe off Vallejo-street wharf and had rail
and rigging on starboard side damaged. Was
towrd clear by tug Sea Witch.

of cargo discharged: no hope of floating her un
til completely discharged.

TOM'S RIDE
UPON A
BALLOON.
BY FRANK HARROLD.
SAN FRANCSCO.
THJSRE was great excitement in
the little country town of Vernon.
Everybody was all in a llutter to
the great balloon that had come
that day. Boat up into the air with a
load of human freight. The balloonist
had set his tent In a field, and was go-
Ing to make ascensions on the follow
lay. The next morning, bright and
early, there had â¢â  sembled around

THE BOY ON THE FARM.
JAMES WHITCOMB RILEY.

cord In Bight By this time he was far
from the people and was Rearing along
in the air over fields far away from
the dear ones at home.
At Umee the wind would bear down
nn the balloon, and at other times the
balloon would start up as if to pierce
the heavens. At last Tom's grasp was
laid "ii a thin cord which was flapping
about wildly and he pulled it. A
strong hissing sound followed which
Beared Tom and then the thought came
t.> him that he had discovered the valve
cord! He uttered a thanksgiving as he
again pulled it. The balloon at last
: .1 its loss of gas and stopped ris
intr, but did not lower any. except from
the "md. He pave another pull and
felt the balloon descending. A cry of
joy escaped his lips, and he pulled stili
harder. The balloon, of course, losing
bo much gas, 1 iscended rapidly, fright
ening Tom so much as to make him
o of the cord.
When the balloon got within a hun-
dred feet of the ground it fe.l no more,
but swept rapidly along through the
air. Tom dared not pull the cord any
more for fear of the balloon collapsing
on top of some tree. On swept the bal
loon. Xearing a great poplar tree Tom
thought his end had come.
As the balloon neared the tree it rose
gradually and the basket brushed
among the uppermost br: "ches only.
Hut as the balloon was drawing
away a retnnant of the cable hanging
below caught in the- branches and held
the balloon fast. The balloon being too
weak now to do much -â¢â¢lllng floated
around the tree with the wind and at
last Tom was safe on the solid
ground. But then his strength was all
gone and he fainted.
He was aoon found by a party of
"HE BURNED THE BRIDGE."
men who had followed the balloon.
They took him home. He learned by
his trouble to always get his mother's
consent before he did any hazardous
action.

THE SAN FRAXCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1898.
THE WRECK
OF A TRAIN
BY FLOYD SMITH
SAN FRANCISCO*
IN the spring of 1882 a special freight
train started from Casa Grande to
Yuma. There were twenty-four
empty boxcars, one car of merchan
dise and one of cartridges and powder
for Fort Yuma. After passing Mohawk
Summit for a few miles the road is
nearly level to Yuma. The crew had
been out eighteen hours and were near
ly all tired out. They had left Yuma
in the morning and were returning
with the special train. The train was
running very fast after leaving the
summit and the fireman, being worn
out, asked the head brakeman to fire
for him, after which â¢ the exhausted
man fell asleep on the seat.
The speed across the fiat was about
twenty miles an hour. This part of
the road was raised three or four feet
by banks of sand. The brakeman was
shoveling coal into the fire very fast,
when suddenly the engineer called,
"The bridge is burnt," and jumped out
of the window. The brakeman, drop
ping his shovel, shouted to the fire-
THE CRITICAL MOMENT ARRIVES AND FRANK KIMBALL STANDS BEFORE A FIRING SQUAD.
man, "EJ. Ed," as he jumped from the
gangway.
Many thoughts passed through the
brakeman's head as he turned over
and over. He could see and hear cars
mashing, jamming and piling on top of
each other and he wondered what had
become of the fireman. When he
stopped rolling he thought he was
killed. The engine and twenty-four
cars had piled up in the creek and he
was under the whole mass of burning,
creaking cars. He managed to crawl
out without help, getting nothing but a
slight scratch. He thought of the fire
man again, and with the help of the
other hands "Ed" was extricated from
under the burning mass. When taken
out the fireman's clothing was all on
fire and he was burned so badly that
he died shortly after.
The engineer had got out through
the window and was slightly scalded.
The two brakemen and the conduc
tor who were in the caboose were bad
ly shaken up, but not seriously in
jured.
The bridge was a thirty-two-foot
trestle, and in some manner the tim
bers had all been burned from under
neath. When the engine struck the
bed it was going very fast. The pilot
hit the bank on the other side so hard
that the engine turned right over on
its back.
After the fireman had been taken out
the men uncoupled the caboose and
ran it away from the other cars, which
were on fire. They tried to get the car
with the cartridges and powder away,
but could not, as it was on the edge of
the creek and pulled tight by the cou
pling of the other cars. The men,
never thinking of the danger of the
powder getting lighted by a spark,
opened the car and put the powder and
cartridges into the end farthest from
the fire. Then they worked very hard
until they had covered the car with
sand. Of course this was slow work,
and one end of it was badly burned.
Not until the work was over did they
realize that at any moment they might
have all been blown up.
A man was then dispatched toYuma,
about eight miles away. At 6 o'clock
in the morning the wrecking train ar
rived. The Yuma Indians came to get
what booty they could, but they were
peaceable and disturbed no one.
The tired men had to lay another
track around the wreck so that the
regular trains could pass.
It was an experience none wanted to
repeat, and r . connected therewith
were so frightened that they never re
called the accident without a shudder.
This is a true story-
The war spirit has evidently taken
strong hold upon the boys. The stories
by the girls deal with much milder
themes. They are varied and pleasing.
The names of the judges will be an
nounced next Sunday.
BOSE SAVED
HIS
MASTER.
BY FRANK McCARTHY,
LOS. ANGELES.
GOOD-BY, Bose; God bless you;
now go!" .
The speaker was an American
boy in Cuba. He was born of
Spanish parents in California. He
had reached Cuba as a stowaway. His
skin was dark. He sp. ke Spanish flu
ently. The Spaniards in Havana took
him for a Cuban. He was brought be
fore a man In uniform, who asked him
some questions and then ordered that
he should be sent to one of the camps
of reconcentradoÃ. Frank Kimball was
not the boy to be downcast even there,
surrounded by starving men, women
and children. To repay his courage
Base, a dog that had voyaged with him
also as a stowaway from Key West to
Havana, found his way to the recon
centrado camp.
Frank Kimball's friends did not know
what had become of him. The captain
of the American steamer Starlight
would help him, he knew, if possible.
Frank had already seen enough of
Cuba to satisfy his curiosity. Here was
Bose! Frank threw his arms around
the dog's neck whsn his canine friend
came to him in his trouble. Quick
witted, the lad hastily penciled a note
and fastened it beneath the dog's col
lar. "Good-by, Bose; God bless you;
now go!"
The dog seemed to understand the
boy. It was dusk and no sentinel no
ticed what had happened. Hardly had
Frank ceased to speak when the dog
disappeared in the gathering shades of
night. Straightway Bose found his
way to Havana; as promptly he plung
ed overboard, and under the frowning
guns of Morro Castle swam to the
Starlight as she lay in the stream.
Luckily the dog was seen and was
taken on board.
Bose would not be kept out of the
captain's cabin. Hs scratched at the
door until Captain Newcomb heard
him. The dog acted so strangely and
was so much excited that Captain
Newcomb knew that something was
the matter.
"Bose, where is Frank?" asked the
captain.
The dog knew- the name of Frank
and barked. Captain Newcomb, who
had worried because Frank, to whom
he had taken a strong fancy, had not
returned to the Starlight, watched
Bose carefully. He saw a piece of pa
per under the dog's collar.
"This is bad," he said as he read
what Frank had written. "There is
no time to be lost. I have heard that
the Spaniards will shoot suspects to
morrow. Perhaps he is threatened."
An hour later the bell of the 'Ameri
can Consular Office in Havana was
rung. Consul General Lee came to the
door. Captain Newcomb told what he
wanted. General Lee went with Cap
tain Newcomb to the office of General
â  â , the Spanish commander in
chief. There a pass was procured for
Captain Newcomb and an order to the
commandant at the camp.
"Speed," said General Lee, "for the
boy will be shot at daybreak, unless
you get there in time."
At daybreak Frank Kimball was
marched, with several others, to a wall
to be shot.
"Hurrah for the American flag,"
shouted Frank in the presence of im
pending death.
The Spanish officer scowled.
"Ready!" he commant! jd, and the
rifles of the guard came to a deadly
aim.
My country, 'tis of thee,
Sweet land of liberty.
Clear and strong the words and mel
ody rang on the damp morning air.
The Spanish commandant raised his
sword.
"Fire!" he said. -But at that moment
Captain Newcomb came upon \ the
scene. He shouted, when at some dis
tance, and the soldiers, hesitated. That
pause saved Frank's life. : : ... -. â¢.
Captain Newcomb, breathless, hand
ed the "general's order Â. to the com
mandant. Scowling, that officer or
dered ; that Frank should be set free.
As Frank went away a volley told him
that his late comrades in : misery had
fallen. \ ' â ". '.':.:. â ' V '.~ t ';f~ ; ,
Bose received more hugs and I his
. head was , patted . v more " times \ than
could be counted., when Frank saw him
once more. He had saved â¢ his . young
master's life. â¢ â  . . .
â â â¢>^;-. â¢â -â¢'.--â â¢; Â-.". -... â â¢.-â¢ - â â â - -..'-,
The boy writers who have their
stories published m competition with;
the . stories written rby the girls - t this
morning r make their collective; bow to
the readers of The Call and there' is no ,
doubt that the gicls will read every
word the boys I have ; penned and : will ,
wonder , how â¢ their ?., page will compare '

THE CHRISTMAS BOY.
EUGENE FIELD.
Father calls me William, sister calls me Will,
Mother calls 'me Willie, but the fellers call me Bill.
Mighty glad I ain't a girl â rather be a boy
Without them sashes, curls and thingsthat's worn by Fauntleroy.
Love to chaw green apples and go swimmin' in the lake;
Hate to take the castor-ile they give for belly-ache.
'Most all the time, the whole year round, there ain't no flies on me;
But just 'fore Christmas I'm as good as I kin be.
PALE FACE
WAS BRAVE.
BY ALFRED LAWSON,
SEATTLE.
WHITE boy no good. Indian boy
brave. Pale face boy weak like
girl.
I will own that this stung my pride.
I was passing the summer on an In
dian reservation in the Northwest,
and, being a good shot, a fast runner,
a deep diver and a passably good
horseman, I thought that I had the re
spect of the Indians. But here was an
Indian boy, younger than myself,
taunting me with being weak and also
a coward!
"Have a care, Buffalo!" I said. "Per
haps you will know more soon!"
"Ugh!" that was all the answer the
Indian boy would make. I did not say
any more then, but held my temper
and waited.
Huffalo and I went out hunting to
gether not many days after this con
versation. Both had fine horses, and
we \*ere well armed with the best re
peating 1 rifles. We soon struck the
trail of a deer and rode after it hot and
fast. Soon the track of another deer
joined in with those of the first one,
and it was clear hat they were going
toward water or a halt lick, and that
there would be a herd of deer there.
The horses scented the game, and,
with wide nostrils, took in the spirit of
the chase.
I was on my mettle. The words of
Buffalo had not ceased to rankle. I
pushed on and soon had the satisfac
tion of seeing the Indian boy losing
ground. Now my horse was a nose
ahead; now a length: then I lost ';ight
of Buffalo. I knew that I had a better
mount than he had â but not much bet
ter. He quickened his pace, and the
sound of his horse's hoofs came nearer.
Suddenly I realized that I was alone.
Turning in my saddle I saw that Buf
falo's horse had fallen and that he was
down.
Buffalo was smiling when I rode back
to where he was. He could not move.
He had broken some bones. His horse
had a broken leg, having s ppec! into
a prairie do-g's hole while going at full
speed. Twenty long miles to the Indian
camp and only one horse to carry us!
Not one! As I leaped from the saddle
and went to Buffalo to help him a
low, moaning sound came across the
country lying between us and the
buttes beyond. My horse pricked up his
ears, sniffed the air sharply and turn
ed and ran off, homeward bound, and
we two were alone on the plain; one
of us hopelessly disabled and some sort
of wild beast or wild beasts co-ming.
"Wolves! White boy save himself!"
Buffalo smiled even as he told me to
go away and leave him to his fate,
which would be to be torn to pieces by
wolves while still alive.
"Can you use your arms, Buffalo?"
"Yes, I will do very well. Follow
your horse and be safe."
I made no reply. The time had come
to satisfy the Indian concerning my
courage. Half an hour passed before
the wolves were up on us; but it seem
ed an age. I was standing and Buf
falo was sitting when the brutes began
to circle around us, looking for a safe
place to make their attack. They were
hungry, half-famished brutes and as
fierce as one can imagine them to have
been. There were at least fifty of them.
They howled and snapped, their teeth
horribly.
Although Buffalo was in great pain
with his broken bones, his aim was per
fect. He smiled as wolf after wolf fell
before his bullets. But the continual
banging did not scare the wolves. They
were after Buffalo's dead horse, which
might be better to eat than their fallen
comrades.
Before our bullets were all gone two
wolves attacked Buffalo. With a shout
I leaped to his side and rained blows
about me with the butt < f Buffalo's
rilie upon their skulls. They tore my
face and hands and stripped my cloth
ing. My strength was failing as my
Edited By
DAVID H. WALKER
blood flowed fro-m many a wound. Buf
falo was growing weak.
Crack! Crack! Crack!
Help had come. Indian braves rode
up, firing as they came. The wolves
were at last frightened and ran. That
night we were once more in camp.
Had I proved my courage enough to
please Buffalo? "White boy just as
good as Indian boy," he said, as we re
clined by the campflre a fortnight later.
A BOY'S PLAN
BY GUSSIE TAYLOR,
BERKELEY.
IF there is going to be any war in
Cuba count me and Spot in. Spot is
my big dog and when I "sick" him
on he is a terror to evil doers. That
CHARLIE IS PULLED UP AFTER A FALL OVER THE PRECIPICE
is what my papa says. I am 6 years
old. I live in Berkeley ai.d have often
seen the university boys parade. When
they fire off their cannon, my! don't it
make a loud bang? I can't fire a can
non, or march very far, but I can ride
a pony and carry an American flag
and set Spot on the Spanish general.
He'd be a brave man who wouldn't be
afraid of Spot when he is mad â Spot
I mean! Then when the general runs
away his men will run away, too, and
then it will be easy to win the fight.
Hurrah for Uncle Sam!
THESE ARE THE QUESTIONS.
Is the boys' page or the girls' page
the better?
Do the two pages show that there
is any literary superiority in sex in
children?
The opinions of the judges will be
"BUFFALO" WITH HIS WAR PAINT ON.
printed in full. The request is here
made that the opinions may be briefly
written on account of space. The com
petition has begun. Will the victory
go to the boys or to the girls?
LITTLE BOW-LEG BOY.
If ever the doctor-man comes my way
With his wonderful box in his two-wheel shay,
I'll ask for the treasure I'd fain possess;
Now, honest Injun! Can't you guess?
Why, a cute little boy â
A funny little boy â
A dear little bow-leg boy.
THE PERIL
OF A
MOUNTAIN.
BY HOWARD BLACKMAR,
BERKELEY.
i*"^ HARLIE and I were tramping In
the Sierras two years ago. We
Uwere just out of the â - High
School, and we thought that we
were bi" 1 enough to look uut for
ourselves. We went up on the -cars to
Inyo County and there unloaded our
traps and started on foot with a pack
mule to carry our tent and camp outfit
and provisions over to Mount Whitney,
which loomed up immensely in the dis
tance.
Charlie knew a manat Independence,
and he agreed to be our guide just for
friendship's sake. He had known
Charlie's father and mine also. "So,"
he said, "it seemed as if he was to go
along with his own, some way. "
Of course we were glad enough to
have him with us, for when we really
saw Mount Whitney, it seemed easy to
get lost there, notwithstanding the well
beaten .trails.
We never got to the top of Whitney.
We went up the mountain some dis
tance and camped. The very night we
made camp Bill disappeared. He left
his gun and some other belongings. We
followed down the trail some distance
the next morning to look for Bill. Two
miles from camp we came to fresh
tracks made by a bear. After going
another mile down the mountain we
saw blood. Then a little farther on
were signs of a struggle. The bushes
were broken and there were rags of
cloth and tufts of hair.
"Man arid bear fight," said Charlie.
That was my idea of it. There was
n<> difficulty in following the course of
the battle. The bushes and grass
looked as if some heavy body or bodies
had rolled down the steep grade. We
followed on until we came to a high
precipice. There was no doubt that
something had fallen over here into a
deep ravine below. A rag fluttered "on
a twig hanging over the precipice. The
rag was brown, the color of Bill's
hunting coat! And Bill? We looked at
each other with dread. Had- Bill fallen
over the precipice? If not, where was
he?
Charlie was game all through.
"I am going over the cliff and search
for Bill!" That was all he said. We
went back to the camp and got a rope.
Charlie tied one end around his waist,
and when he had passed the rope
around a tree I took hold of the other
end. Charlie swung boldly off and
dangled in midair, while I let out the
rope slowly.
Fifty feet or so down there was a
shelf of rock. Charlie rested there an
instant. Then he sent up a great
shout: "Pull up, Jack, for your life."
I pulled with all my might and none
too soon. A bear ran out along the
shelf of rock, and, half famish.'d. tried
to seize Charlie. My brave chum did
not forget even then the use of a pis
tol. Hardly had he swung out pendu
lum fashion from the precipice wall
when he had his pistol ready. Back
he came on the swinging line toward
the bear. It was a beautiful sight.
Charlie did not fire until he was close
in, and when he pulled the trigger he
had such good aim that the bullet
pierced some vital part of the bear, and
the monster foil into the canyon below
with a final roar.
I pulled Charlie up. We were just
shaking hands when we heard a voice:
"Purty good stuff, you two; and
I thought so from the first. Just like
your fathers."
It was Bill!
"I wandered away last ni^ht," he
said, "and fell in with a wildcat, and
we had a little brush, and I killed him
and threw him over the bluff."
The next day we got a longer rope
and I went down and found the bear
that Charlie had shot. It was dead.
Bill and Charlie pulled it up with a
rope after a hard tug; but Charlie
strained himself and we did not make
the big climb after all.
EUGENE FIELD.
3132
HOW SUPPORT
HIGH SCHOOLS?
Professor Brown on the
Problem of State
Assistance.
Condemns Caminetti's Pro
posed Constitutional
Amendment.
Superintendent McClymonds of the
Oakland Schools Speaks on
â 'Number Work."
In an address to a teachers' class at the
University of California. Professor Elmer
E. Brown gave a historical review of the
progress of secondary education in San
Francisco, relating the facts of the de
â¢ the boys' and Kirls" high
school and the normal class. He sai.i:
The history of these schools exhibits .1 marked
tendency toward rentlation, especially in
the (iirection of vocational training-.
The true tendency is. I think, to make th*
commercial liigrh schix^l training e<iual in ritrcr
to that of the peneral culture echt^jls. if thla
can be done, and technical training 1 "an bo
made thorough and efficient, its importance as
a part of secondary education cannot be over
tstimat?d.
The first hiph school was established in San
Francisco in 1<56. The Hoys* Hisrh School; now
the Lowell High, was established In IS6S. The
Girls' High was established in I^4 and is the
only hi| school in tho city that has not be
come co- educational, the Boys' High &hcol
ha vine been for years, even before" its nanv
was changed, open to students of both sexes.
The otaie constitution makes scant pruvis
ion for the support of high schools. N".. Stale
funds .-an be used for any school not â¢ Dtiir.lv
managed by the State, nd the only _>u-.h
schools now existing ire the normal schools.
In a word, under existing conditions the sup
port of high schools comes entirely from ltxai
taxat; >n. This means, of course, that in any
community there must be a sufficiently strong
sentiment in favor of higher education to ob
tain funds for its support. Various attempts,
among them the CaniiiiPtti act of ISS3. to evade
tiie constitution by establishing "Rrammar
school course schools," have been made and
these Utempts accompli the good -ult of
awakening interest in secondary education.
In 1891 the law providing for the hybrid
formed and unsatisfactory "grammar school
course schools" was repealed and a law was
passed providing for three kinds of high school:
Firstâ That any dlsti of more than 1000
population which would furnish the entire
amount necessary ciuld establish a high school.
Secondâ That â â -â nil districts might unite to
form a "union high school."
Thirdâ That the county may provide for the
establishment of one or more high schools
There is a feeling that the present law does
not sufficiently provide for secondary educa
tion. At the last session of the Legislature a
constitutional amendment was ; r iposed by Mr
Camineui providing State aid for grammar
schools teaching high school subjects and pre
paring students for the university While I
believe Mr. Caminetti is one of the best friends
of >ndary education in thi State I do not
regard the proposed amendment as desirable
It would prevent the establishment of true
high schools and would cause the continua
tion of grammar school methods into second
ary institutions. The methods of each of the>=e
group of schools shrtuld be entirely distinct
Again, under this law holders of grammar
school certificates could teach in the real hieh
school courses and a werlng in the standard
would follow necessarily.
rintendent J. w. McClymonds of
the Oakland rbllc schools spoke briefly
on "Primary Number Work." He said:
t'nfortunately. the first thins we have to
teach the child in number work fs that part
of the subject of arithmetic that is most dif
ficult to understandâ addition. It has been
figured out ih.y B8 per cent of the mistakes
made in computation are mistakes in addi
tion, this difficult part of arithmetic this
development of the "number sense," is the first
thing that has to be taught In our primary
schools.
Number work is mechanical work, pure and
simple. nrill the child long enough In this
mechanical work and he will add with abso
lute accuracy. Train the child on the various
combinations of numbers until they become
absolutely familiar. It is a slow process but
it pays. The teaoher has to show Interest in
the w.irk in order to Interest the pupils aad
when the pupils become interested they will
do pood work.
Subtraction can be best taught by a method
different from that â rnmonly in use. The
method of "borrowing" from one column foj
another should be done away with Suppose
you are teaching the beginner to BUbtri 3S
from 52. Instead of borrowing 1 from the 5
and adding it to the 2. add 1 to the 1 and add
1 also to the 3 of the 3v In other words, the
process instead of being â â¢â¢ from 12 is 4. 3 from
4 is 1. therefore 3> from 52 is 14," should be "S
from 12 is 4. 4 from 5 is 1. therefore SS from 5*
is 14."
Next Saturday morning will conclude
the sories of pedagogical lectures for the
present term.
ODD FELLOWS' DAY.
Seventy-Ninth Anniversary of the
Foundation of American Odd
Fellowship.
The Odd Fellows of this city, including
the subordinate l.^i^es. the Rebekah
lodg>~> mpments. have been
busy for w m< time jm.-u making arrange
menu I proper observance of the
of American
. which falls on the 26th
There will be two celebrations, one by
tiay and one by night. The one by day
will be in the nature of a grand picnic
at Shell Mound Park, under the auspices
of the Patriarchs Militant, Canton No. 5
of this city and the Rebekah lodges. The
executive committee, composed of Colonel
W. Potter. Captains A. J. Duncan. C. H.
Weaver. G. S. Naismith, E. H. Harris, J.
Pyc and Lieutenant N. i-;. Flint, acting
in conjunction with the committee of ar
rangements of vhich Mrs. F p Dulev
ls president and Frederick W. Jaeger is
secretary, has arranged an interesting
programme of races, games and dancin"
There will be a large number of gate
prizes, and the entire proceeds, over and
above expenses, will be donated to the
Orphans' Home at Gilroy. The Patriarchs
Militant will appear in uniform. All the
subordinates, Rebekah lodges and en
campments of San Francisco. Alameda
Oakland and of San Mateo and Santa
lara counties have been asked to lend
their aid in this charitable work
In the evening, under the auspices of a
different committee, there will be in cele
bration of the day. an entertainment and
ball m the mbly Hall of the Odd Fel
lows building. District Deputy Grand
Master Karl Brueck of Stockton will pre
side, and there will be presented a pro
gramme that will Include an address by
rank McGowan. selections by a ladies'
quartet, bell-ringing by Miss Nellie
Waters, a cornet solo, selections by P-o
fessor Qraeber** mandolin club, a vocal
solo by a member of the quartet and a

DIED IN A HACK.
Mrs. Kate Biarini. an Invalid Widow,
Expired While on Her Way to
Meet Her Children.
Mrs. Kate Biagini. a widow, residing at
411 Pacific street, died suddenly yester
day afternoon while about to be taken In
a liack to the residence of her Fiste"
Mrs. Julia Cole, in Oakland. The de
rrased had been very pick for some time
but had had no physician attending her'
Her niece, Mrs. Louise Tagllaferro.came
ever from Oakland yesterday to accom
pany her. .';â¢
No boob r had Mrs. Biagini taken her
Feat in the vehicle than she fell back in
the scat and expired.
The remains were conveyed to the
Morgue. The deceased left two small
children, a boy and a girl. . They are in
Keeping Their Stocks Low.
The Manufacturers* and Wholesalers'
Leagw a side issue of the Manufacmr
ers* and Producers' Association, jis not
meeting with the success this year that It
did last. E W. Keeler. who has the busi
ness in hand, attributes this condition to
the lack of rain in the interior of the
State. Last season many of the country
merchants. were only too glad to avail
thÂ»-n-.- of the opportunity of free
transportation to their homes, when the
omy conditions were that they should
rome to this city and purchase their goods
instead of. buying from drummers Â£rgm_
other State?. Mr. Kapler pays that aY
who have taken advantage of the reduce*",
rates tell thp same story, that poor crops
have so scared the farmers that they will
not spend any more money than they art
obliged to. and thus it Is not advisable
to lay in vry larpo stocks of goods.
HE WILL WED A
BANKER'S DAUGHTER
Betrothal Announced of
Miss Delia Davidson and
Harrison Dibblee.
The first notable engagement of the
season was made public yesterdayâ
of Miss Delia Davidson and Harrison
Dibblee. For some time the friends of
the contracting parties have suspected
that such an engagement existed, but the
young people managed to keep their In
teresting secret. Finally, however, the
story got too good to keep and the influ
ence of Easter week induced them to ac
knowledge their betrothal. ..
Miss Davidson is the daughter of David
B. Davidson of the Nevada Bank, and
made her debut early in the season. She
was educated in the Eastern schools and
is as charming as she is accomplished. In
appearance she is petite and slender, and
her greatest attraction Is her delicate
and exquisite coloring. Her hair is 01 a
rich golden hue, her eyes a clear <:â  â¢ p
blue, and In her soft fair cheeks the roses
play at hide and seek. 1 TV, . ,
Mr Dibblee is the son of Mrs. A. J.
Dibblee. He is well known and popular
in social circles and a prominent member
of the University Club. No date for the
wedding has as yet been arranged.
BUSY WEEK FOR
HIGH MASONS
Three or the Grand Bodies Will
Convene in the Masonic
Temple.
Programme of the Parade on Satur
day Next by the Knights
Templar.
The coming week will he one of activ
ity in the higher Masonic bodies of this
jurisdiction. To-morrow there will be a
meeting of the Grand Council of the
Royal and Select Masons in the Temple,
at which then- will be representatives
from eleven councils. This body, of
which Henry Ascroft is the most Illus
trious master, will be in session but one I |
day. In the afternoon the officers will
be elected and installed.
On Tuesday and Wednesday the Grand
Chapter of the Royal Arch Masons of I
â¢rnia will be in session In the Tern
pie. This body, of which W. h rank
Pierce Is the jfiost excellent grand high
â¢ will have representatives from â 
sixty-seven chapters. The officers for the
ensuing term will be chosen and installed j
on the last day of t!>- s.ssion.
on Thursday, Friday and Saturday the
Grand Commandery. Knights Templar of
81 ite, representing thirty-seven eom
manderies, will be in session. Of this
grand body R. E. Sir George D. MÂ»>tealf
of Oakland is the prand commander. Two
days will be devoted to the transaction
of "the business that will come up !â¢â¢
the grand body, and on the third day
there is to be a conclave of department 1. i
In orders No. 2 is the following: "In j
order that there may be a proper annre- i
ciation of the importance of a depart
ment conclave it is proposed to request
thp Grand Commandery of California to
parade during the Templar parade. Such
example will be of great benefit to the i
rank and file of our ordt-r and aid in 11- .
lustrating those knightly qualities which
tend to build up and strengthen loyal
and disciplined commanderies."
Order No. 3 gives tho following as the
list of officers for the grand parade that
will move at 2:30 on Van Ness avenue on
the afternoon of Saturday: In command.
Eminent Sir John F. Merrill, grand gen
eralissimo. R. E. ; Sir Frank W. Sumner. |
past grand commander, chief of staff; ,
Sir Knight Curtis G. Kenyon. surgeon; j
Sir Knights William McDonald. Edward
R. S. Swain, A. W. Burrell and George ; â¢
S. Andres, staff; Sir Knights H. West
phal. W. R. Jost, R. S. PaJashi, J. D. t
Maxwell. Edward J. Vogel and M. Ryan,
signal officers.
The first battalion will consist of Cal
ifornia Commandery No. 1. which will
turn out about 100 strong under command
of Sir J. P. Fraser.
Then will follow the Grand Command
ery of California as one company, under
command of E. S. F. W. Miller, grand
captain -general.
Second battalion composed of the fol
lowing commanderies; San Jose No. W,
Oakland No. 11. Santa R.>sa No. 14. Naval
No. 19, Mount Olivet No. 20. WatsonviUe
No. 22. San Luis Oblspo No. 27. I'kiah No.
N ; pa No. 34 and Eureka No. 35. under ]
command of R. E.. Sir Trowbridge H.
Ward, P. G. C.
Third battalion, Golden Gate Com
mander}', four companies, under com
mand of E. S., Jonathan M. Peel.
The parade will close with carriages
only for aged and veteran past grand
officers.
The right of the parade will form on
Van Ness avenue, between Turk and Mc-
Allister streets, and extend southward to
It is expected that between 700
and SOO Knights Templar will take part
in the proceedings of the Grand Com
mandery and that between 500 and 600
will appear in the parade.
The companies will be formed of one
captain-general, two wardens and from
twenty-four to thirty-six knights.
At the close of the parade there will
be a review to Grand Commander, R. E.,
Sir George D. Metcalf.
THE OLD PEBALTA GRANT.
It Does Not Include Alameda Coun
ty's Two Big Creeks.
Surveyor J. M. Gleaves has denied the
application of M. F. Truett Jr. for an i
extension of the lines of "survey of the
Rancho San Antonio, the purpose of J
which was to Include within the bound
aries of the ranch the waters of the San '
Antonio and San Leandro creeks. The j
decision is of some importance to many â 
people living in Alameda County on |
property adjoining the old Peralta grant j
from the United States. In his decision, J
the Surveyor-General says: I
"To Induce the summary action of this
office under section 8 of the act of July
23, 1556, petitioner relies upon proceedings
which, as has been shown, have culmin
ated in a patent to his remote grantor.
Upon such a showing, for this office to ,
assume jurisdiction over the lands in
question for the purpose of survey, under .
the section mentioned, it must necessar
ily, in effect, deny the solemn declarations
of the Government, evidenced by its pat- |
ent, as construed by the highest court in
the land. That so grave a responsibility |
devolves urvon an officer whose duties are '
so largely ministerial as are those of the
United States Surveyor-General, and in â¢
a proceeding entirely collateral and ex 1
parte, as is this, is an assumption to i
which this office, with a due sense of Its !
proper sphere of duty, cannot assent. The '<
application of petitioner for an extension
of the - lines of the public surveys over
the Rancho San Antonio, in townships 1 j
and 2 south, range 4 west, and township 'â¢
2 south, range 3 west. Mount Diablo base j
and meridian, is. therefore, denied." j

Horses Overcrowded.
J. W. Walton and M. McCurrie. of the
Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to
Animals, were sent to the water front
yesterday to investigate the charges that ',
the horses being sent to Dyea on the'
Morgan City were being placed In un
suitable quarters and likely to suffer be
fore the trip was over. They found sixty
nne horses between decks and in de
cidedly unsuitable quarters. The officers
said that they would not let the animals
be shipped in such a manner. Although
it caused some delay, the captain hail
twenty carpenters go to work a"nd within
a few hours stalls were constructed so
that the horses could make the journey
in safety and comr r;.
Against the Tiger.
United States District Judge de Haven
yesterday returned a decision in favor of
Michael Ryan in his suit against the.
steam tug Tiger for $169. alleged to be due
as wages, together with the costs of. the

Curtain and Draperr Adv't in To-Day's Examiner.
NEWS OF THE MINES.
The Government's Defi
nition of Hydraulic
Mining at Last.
Large Prospects for the Inter
national Mining Congress.
Mining Progress.
The formal decision by the California
Debris Commission that the definition of
"hydraulic mining." to which it will ad
here in carrying out the Caminetti law,
shall be â¢â¢mining by means of water un
der pressure through a nozzle," Is the
most important ruling that mining af
fairs have brought forth for .1 long time.
It practically settles a vexed question,
over which the last California Miners'
Convention debated long and about
which authorities disagreed much. It is
now settled that the Federal engineers,
whf-n acting as the California Debris
<'ommission under the Caminetti law.
will regulate drift mining, ground sluic
ing, the washing of tailings, dumps and
all placer mining on the water sheds of
the navigable streams when water is
used through a nozzle under pressure, as
well as when it is used "against a nat
ural bank."
This decision probably settles the ques
tion, because the miners axe not apt to
appeal from the decision. This makes
of practical non-effect the definition
adopted by the State Legislature, which
technically limited the term "hydraulic
mining" to hydraulic operations against
a "natural bank." The definition with its
implied declaration of jurisdiction will
undoubtedly be accepted with fairly good
grace by the hydraulic mining interests,
who are especially and wearily anxious
that some move be made toward the con
struction of the restraining dams. The
spirit in which the decision will be re
ceived by the majority of miners is prob
ably well reflected by the Mining and
Scientific Press, which observes in its
current issue:
â "It is fair to assume that the future of
the great industry of hydraulic mining in
California rests in a liberal administra
tion and interpretation of the existing
law, or some law framed upon the same
! general lines. Insistence upon narrow
rules of interpretation, which do violence
to the spirit of the law, will impede rath
er than advance the interests of the in
dustry."
During the week Ju ian Sonntag. secre
tary of the California Miners' Associa
tion, received from D. Johnson of Den
ver, chairman of the executive commit
tee of the International Mining Congress
a letter urging active interest nere in the
coming meeting of the congress in Den
ver. July 7. and 9. The writer predicts
an exceedingly large attendance and be
lieves that the meeting will be one of the
most Important events in the history of
mining. ,
Mr. bonntag's reply reflected the cordial
interest taken in the congress here and
the expectation of a large California dele
gation being in attendance. He offered
the wise suggestion that Governors and
others who are to I appoint the ' delegates
be specially asked by letter to name only
men practically identified with mining
Interests. ; '-..>â 
The initial convention of last year was
called the "International Gold Mining
Convention." The name has been bâ>ad
ened with, the scope and purposes of it to
the "International Mining Congress." and i
this year all phases of- mining will be
within its range. The i. coming session
promises to be a great and important one
that will Influence: legislation as | well as
tne practical Drogress of the industry '
The Grass Valley Union called atten
tion to a disregarded State law passed in
1872 . which makes it i unlawful . to work a
mine bfilose a uepih oX 300 1Â«t,,1X twelve*

I men are employed daily, without provid
j ing a second tunnel or snaft connecting
with the main shaft at a uepth of not
i less than 100 feet.
The only pei.alty. however, for disre
â  garding the lav/ is a provision that if any
miner working in the mine shall sustain
â  injuries or death which might have been
avoided had the second means of egress
j existed, the owner snail be naole for full
I damages for such injuries to the person
sustaining t..em or to the relatives of the
i deceased in case of death. There are
1 other regulations for the protection of
' working miners in the code, but Califor
nia has no mine inspector or other official
supervision *i see that any regulations
are observed.
ahe electric power company which is

As the long distance lines of the Sunset
Telephone Company are being rapidly ex
tended among the towns of the mining
regions many large mines are putting in
private connecting lines at their own ex
pense. In these times it is a daily inci
dent for a mine superintendent to ring
up the office of the company or owner
whose office is in San Francisco, or to ring
! up a business firm in the city, make re
ports, get directions or order machinery
or supplies. Mining men celebrate the
, end of a long, hard ride into the moun
; tains with a draught of the superintend
j ent's best reserve stock and a cheerful
â  report to the wife in the city.
! The dry season will work much hard
j ship upon many of the miners. The Trin
i ity Deep Gravel Mining Company has
constructed at great expense over a half
mile of ditch and has laid about 1300 feet
of pipe to bring water from Boulder
Creek to its Morrison Gulch claims on
the Trinity River. This done the useless
ness of the work at the present time is
discovered, as there is little water for '
any purpose.â Searchlight.
The Drown mine near Albany Flat has
been closed down for a short time, pend
ing further improvements.
It Is reported that owing to the . great
flow of water in the Keystone mine oper
j ations have been suspended for the pres-
I ent.
! The Pennsylvania in Nevada County is
i said to have'eome into a new ore body on '
I the 700 level while making an upraise
! from the Â£00 level. â ; â¢ â 
The river miners on the Kiamath j are
i now rushing operations to commence
hoisting pay gravel, and a few have al
ready started their derricks. The river
! being down to the low water mark so
j much earlier than usual, the - work of
; wing damming will soon be completed In
all the claims ' for pumping out and
hosting. The yield from river claims
during the coming summer and fall is ex
pected to be better than for several years
I past.â Yreka Journal.
R. R. Christy of Tacoma is managing
owner of a new and promising property ;
| near French Gulch. Shasta County, the
: Highland Mountain mine, consisting of
': five claims on the summit of the moun
tain. Two tunnels have been driven with
1 in thirty , days, and enough ore has al
; ready been taken out to pay expenses. ;

which are calling increasing attention to
Siskiyou County is thus described by the

their new find â at the â  head *of Humbug

at place of disco very, the only place ex- ;

I per ton. This was found last month. The

only development so far on -this find is a
cut eighteen feet long to a depth of ten

the walls is about eighteen inches â¢ in .
width. The direction of the vein. is north
and south. Two I parallel veins I run with
; the find for a distance of 175 feet.

Dead wood continues to improve its prop

Thirteen mining claims were recorded
at Redding on April 6.
Frank Rossi has started up the mill on
the . Brunswick mine and has a large
quantity of ore ready for crushing. It
is estimated that sufficient values are out
to more than pay for recent development
and addition of new machinery. The
Brunswick gives promise of being one of
the best producers in the French Oulch
district.â Redding Searchlight.
Charles Butters is expected home from
South Africa this month.
Mrs. Elmira Clark, who owns the Car
lisle mine in Butte County, has started
on a visit to cyanide plants, with the idea
of putting up one at the Carlisle.
It Is reported that Melville Attwood.
the widely known pioneer mining engi
neer of California, is fatally ill.
Major Heuer. with Engineers Randall
and Nourse. last week visited Elkhorn.
on the Sacramento River, where the pro
posed jetties are to be constructed.
The T'nion Electric Power and Light
Company, capital stock $1,000,000. has in
corporated at Copperopolis. Cal.. to divert
power from the Stanislaus River and to
furnish power and light for mines and .
towns. Stockholders and trusteesâ O.
Ames. S. Carr. Boston; G. McM. Ross. B.
Johnson. Copperopolis; F. D. Nical.
Stockton. The incorporation is under
stood to mean the resumption of the
Copperopolis copper mines.
New gushers at Coallnga, Fresno Coun- ;
ty. Cal.. now give that district a daily
petroleum product of WO barrels.
The recent discoveries of ore at Jacum
ba, on the edge of the desert, are report- ,
ed to be showing up well. In the claim
of Sam Hayden free gold can be seen
in much of the quartz. Lorenzo M. Wil
liamson and others have a good claim,
and altogether there are about twenty
five claims located and about fifteen men
at work.â San Diego Union.
The Amador Ledger says that the com
pletion of the new shaft on the Wildman-
Mahoney mine will necessitate more
stamps, and the p!an Is to add 120 to the
eighty, increasing the capacity of the
mines to about 750 tons daily. The next
work at the Oneida after the ledge is en
countered in the new drift will be the un
watering of the old shaft.
The company operating a dredger near
<~>roville contemplates buying several
thousand acres of gravel.
W. T. Robinson of Mokelumne Hill has
secured the right to mine the Mokelumne
River for a distance of five miles. He
Intends to use a dredger, and the outfit â 
will cost in the neighborhood of $35,000.â
Calaveras Chronicle.
A discovery of good ore in a strong
ledge was made in' the Flagstaff, near
Grizzly Flat. El Dorado County. The :
renewal of activity in taking up aban
doned mines in the vicinity of Grizzly is
rewarding the operators in several mines
below the 700 level. This is notably me .
case In the Mt. Pleasant. Good Hope and ,
Flagstaff. This resumption of work on |
old properties is giving an impetus to de
veJopment of other properties in the
neighborhood. In the northern portion of ;
the county from the American River to
Kelsey and Georgetown, new life is man
ifest, as is evident from the reopening
of the Summit and Rising Sun properties
and the shafts being sunk on new prop- :
erties. In the neighborhood of Garden
Valley and the Taylor mine prospectors
are meeting with some success in the
discovery' of ledges. The Boulder mine, :
In the vicinity of Shingle borings, with
its systematic development work, is rap- '
Idly proving itself a paying investment.â j
Mining and Scientific Press.

the Mammoth mine. Kern County.

the Dardanelles mine, near Forest Hill, !

The great demand for copper is ren
dered still greater by the present hostile
complications. The United States and
Spain are the greatest copper producers, I
and war possibilities make copper prop
erties to-day more valuable than ever.
There is probably no business of more
present profit than copper mining. Every
department of mining, the basic Industry
of peace or war. receive? increased stim
ulus from the present warlike outlo-.k.
The receipts at the Denver mint dur
ing March were $1,617,896, the largest in
the history- of that mint.
â¢ 'ripple Creek is not keeping up the
phenomenal record made by Its output j
during the closing months of 1897.
A party of San Francisco capitalists
are on Evans Creek this week examining
the Howell & Borden placer proposition
en Saxes Creek. This enterprise contem
plates the construction of a 13-mile ditch
carrying the waters of Evans Creek on
to several hundred acres of rich gravel
land on Saxes Creek, and later it is pro
pnso'l to extend the ditch on to the Rogue
River Valley.â Oregon Mining Journal.
The very numerous parties of prospect
ors and explorers now headed for the sec
tions to the westward, particularly the
Copper River and KotzÂ»bue Bound dis
tricts, will doubtless gather a vast amount
of valuable information concerning those
portions of Alaska, whereof so little is
now known. That the work of these par
ties will eventually find its reward in the
discovery of valuable mineral deposits is .
beyond question, though it is quite proba
ble that the present season will not be
productive of any great results. The Ter
ritory at large, however, is bound to reap
substantial benefit from the information I
gained.â Alaska Mining Record.
KNIGHTS AND LADIES.
The Grand Lodge of the K. and L. of ,
H. Will Meet Here Next
Week.
The eleventh annual session of the
Grand Lodge of California of the Knights
and Ladies of Honor will be held in :
Pythian Castle, in this city, commencing â 
on Tuesday next.
The present grand officers are: T. A. '
Lauder of Sacramento', past protector; i
Mrs. Belle WÂ« Conrad of Sonora. protec- j
tr>r: S. Conradi of Los Angeles, vice-pro
tector; S. B. Carleton of San Francisco. '
secretary: Mrs. Lizzie J. Wheelock of San j
Francisco, treasurer: Mrs. P. Danzweilerof :
San Francisco, chaplain: Mrs. B. Oppen
heimc-r of San Francisco, guide; Mrs. L. â¢
A. Bigler of Alameda. guardian: Mrs. Ida j
J. Kidder of Sacramento, sentinel; H. W.
Quitzow. Mrs. L. B. Holcomb and A.
Gompertz. trustees.
lac following are the ' names of those
Who will represent .ac several lodges of
the order in the grand body: Martha
Lodge, Emma Pease. Kate Hachmeister
â nd Antoinette Graff; Aurora Lodge.
Mary B. Price; Laurel Lodge, Mrs. E. E.
Hall: Harmony Lodge, Annie E. Smith;
Bay City Lodge. E. Quitzow; Golden Rule
Lodge. Sarah Krueger; Pacific Lodge.
Jennie Dinklage; Empire Lodge, Frank
Shibeley; Star Lodge, Mrs. M. A. Guer
ana; Oakland Lodge, J. A. Colquohon:
West End Lodge, Marie P. Blum; Equity
Lodge. Silas Orr; Magnolia Lodge, Ellen .
Fitzgerald; Excelsior Lodge. Sarah Brad
street; Angel City Lodge, S. Conradi:
Yerba Buena Lodge. M. J. Graham; Pal
metto Lodge, Frank Hoffman.
The reports will show that while the
order on this coast did not make any
great increase in membership, that there
has not been any decrease. The death
loss was but ten. seven less than the pre
vious year. The finances are in better
condition. There are no debts and there
is money on hand.
Mrs. Conrad will become the past pro
tector, and for the office she now fills
there will be two candidatesâ Z. T. Whit
ten of San Francisco and H. C. Trap
hagen of San Jose. Both are well known
In fraternal circles, and as both have
many friends in the order it is possible
that there will be quite a contest for the
place.
S. B. Carieton. for eleven years the ac
tive and energetic grand secretary, will
retire from the office he has so satisfac
torily filled. He has declared that his
business affairs are such that he can
not accept a renomination. Should he
do bo he would have to either neglect

Selling Liquor to Indians.
Lyons Lockhardt. a half-breed Indian
indicted last month by the United States
Grand Jury for selling liquor to Indiana
on the Hoopa Valley Indian Reservation,
in Humboldt County, was arrested yes
terday by the United States Marshal and
taken before United States District Judge
de Haven, who fixed his bonds at $500. In
default of bail the prisoner was commit
ted to jail.

ARTICLE I.
Boundaries, Eights and Liabilities.
SECTION' 1. The municipal corpora
tion known as the City and County of
Fan Francisco sha!l remain and con
tinue a body politic and corporate. In
name and In fact, by the name of the
City and County of San Francisco, and
by that name shall have perpetual suc
cession; may sue md defend in all
courts and places and In all matters
and proceedings; may have an 1 use a
common Beal and alter the same at
pleasure; may purchase, receive, hold
end enjoy real -uml personal property;
receive bequests, gifts and donations of
all kinds of property, '.n fee simple, or
in trust for charitable and other pur
poses, and do all acts .necessary to
carry out tlv purposes of -.uch gifts.
bequests and donation?. Aith power to
manage, sell, lease or otherwise dispose
of tho same in accordance with thj
of the gift, bequest or trust.
Sec. 2. The boundaries of the City
and County of Can Francisco are here
by declared to be those set forth in
Fectlon Thirty-nine Hundred and Fifty
of the Political Code nf California.
Sec. 3. The City and County of Pan
Francisco shall continue, under this
Charter, to have, hold and enjoy all
property, rights of property, rights of
action of every nature and description
of the existing municipality and is
hereby declared to be the successor of
the r amc.
Sec. 4. Suits, actions and proceedings
may be brought in the name of the City |
and County for the recover; of any <
property, money or , thinr belong- !
ing thereto, in law or equit;-, or dedi- ]
cated to public use therein, or for the
enforcement of any rights of, or con
tracts with, the City and County,
whether made or arising or accruing
before or after the adoption of this
Charter. All existing suits, actions and
proceedings in the courts or elsewhere,
to which the City and County is a party,
phnll continue to be carried on by or
against the City and County.
Sec. 5. No recoursi shall bÂ« had
ngainst the City and County for dam
nge or loss to person or property suf
fered or sustained by reason of the de
fective condition of any sidewalk
street, avenue, lane, alley, court or
place, or by reason of the defective
condition of any sewer, or by reason of
nny defective drainage, whether any of
paid defects originally existed, or
whether they were occasioned by con
struction, excavation or embankment,
nor Fhall there be any recourse against
the City and County for want of ie
palr of any sidewalk, street, avenue,
lane, alley, court or place or by want
of repair of any sewer; ror shall there
be any recourse against the City and
County for damage to person or prop
erty suffered or sustained by reason of
accidenton any sidewalk.street, avenue.
lane, alley, court or place, or by falling
from any embankment thereon or into
any excavation therein; but in anysuch
case the person or persons on whom
the Jaw may have imposed the obli
gation to repair such defect in the
sidewalk, street' or public highway, or
In the sewer, and also the officer or
officers through whose official negll
gence such defect remains unrepaired
phall be jointly and severally liable to
the party injured for the damage sus
tained.

LEGISLATIVE DEPARTMENT.
CHAPTEK I.
The Board of Supervisors.
SECTION 1. The legislative power
of the City and County or San Francis
co ehall be vested In a legislative body,
which ehall be designated the Board of

sioners.

LIC UTILITIES.

SCHEDULE.
Supervisors. Such body is also desig
nated in" this Charter, the Supervisors.
Bee. -. The Board of Supervisors
ehiill consist of eighteen members, all
of whom shall hold office for two years,
and shall be elected from the City and
County at large. Ea:h one must be at
the time of his election an elector of
the City and County, and must have
been such for at least five years next
preceding his election. Each Supervis
or shall receive an annual salary of
twelv > hundred doll s.
Every person who has served as
Mayor of the City and County, so long
as he remains a resident thereof, shall
be entitled to a seat in the Board of
Supervisors and to participate in its
fites, but shall not be entitled to a
nor to any compensation,
c. 3. A majority of all the members
le Board shall constitute a quorum,
a less number may adjourn from
to day and compel the attendance
of absent members in such manner and
under such penalties as the Board may
Sec. 4. The Board shall:
1. Appoint a clerk, sergeant-at-arms
and, when authorized to do so by ordi
nance, such additional clerks and other
assistants as may be deemed neceseary.
2. Establish rules for its proceedings.
3. Keep a Journal of its proceedings,
and allow the same to be published.
The ayes and noes shall on demand of
any member be taken and entered
therein.
4. Have authority to punish its mem
bers for disorderly or contemptuous
behavior in its presence.
Sec. 6. The Mayor shall be the pre
siding officer of the Board of Supervis
ors. In the absence of the Mayor the
Board shall appoint a presiding officer
pro tempore from its own members,
who shall have the same right to vote
as other members.
Sec. 6. The Beard shall meet on
Monday of each week, or if that day be a
' legal h )liriay, then on the next day.
The Board shall not adjourn to any
| other place than to its r ar place of
meeting, except in case of great neces
i sity or emergency. The meetings of
I the Board shall be public.
Sec. 7. The clerk of the Board.
\ when requested to do so, shall admin
ister oaths and affirmations, without
; charge, in all matters pertaining to
the affairs of his office, and shall per
i form such services as may be pre
scribed by the Board. He shall have
i the custody of the seal, and of all
; leases, grants and other documents,
records and papers of the City and
County. His signature shall be neces
sary to all leases, grants and convey
\ anoes of the City and County.
Sec. 8. Every legislative act of the
City and County shall be by ordinance.
The enacting clause of every ordinance
shall be in these words: "Be it or
dained by the People of the City and
County of San Francisco us follows."
No ordinance shall be passed except by
bill, and no bill shall be so amended as
to change Its original purpose.
Sec. 9. No bill si all become an ordi
nance, nor resolution be adopted, un
less finally passed by a majority of all
the members of the Board and the vote
be taken by ayes and noes and the
names of the members voting for and
against the same be entered in the
Journal.
Sec. 10. No ordinance shall be re
vised, re-enacted or amended by refer
ence to it? titte but the ordinance to
be revised or re-enacted, or the section
thereof amended, shall be re-enacted j
at length as revised and amended.
Sec. 11. An ordinance shall embrace
but one subject, which subject shall be
expressed in its title. If any subject
be embraced in an ordinance and not
expressed in its title, such ordinance
shall be void only as to so much there
of as is not expressed in its title.
Sec. 12. When a bill is put upon Its
THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SUNDAY, APRIL 17, IS9B.
final passage in the Board md fails to
pass, and a motion is made to recon- !
sider, ihe vote upon such motion shall i
not be acted upon before the expira
tion of twenty-four hours after ad- ;
Journment. No bill for the grant of i
any franchise shall be put upon its
final passage within ninety days after I
its introduction, and no franchise shall
be renewed before one year prior to its j
expiration. Every ordinance shall, af- j
ter amendment, be laid over for one
week before its final passage.
Sec. 13. Every bill or resolution pro
viding for any specific improvement,
or the granting of any franchise or
privilege, or involving the lease, ap- |
propriation or disposition of public (
property or the expenditure of public I
money, except sums less than two \
h ndred dollars, or levying any tax !
or assessment, and every ordinance j
providing for the imposition of a new I
duty or penalty, shall, after its intro- j
duction, be published â¢ in the official j
newspaper, with the ayes and noes, j
for at least five BUucesslve days (Sun- j
days and legal holidays excepted) be- \
fore final action upon the same. If
such bill be amended, the bill as
amended shall be advertised for a like ;
period before final action thereon. But !
in cases of great necessity the officers j
and heads of departments may, with j
the consent of the Mayor, expend such
sums of money, not to exceed two hun
dred dollars, as shall be necessary to
meet the requirements of such neces
sity.
Sec. 14. If any bill be presented to
the Mayor containing several items ap
propriating money or fixing a tax levy,
he may object to one or more items
separately, while approving other por
tions of the bill. In such case he shall j
append to the bill at the time of sign-
Ing it a statement of the item or item* j
to which he objects and the reasons |
therefor, and the item or items so ob
jected to shall not take effect unless [
passed notwithstanding the Mayor's j
objection. Ez.ch item so objected to
shall be separately reconsidered by the
Board in the same manner as bills ;
which have been disapproved by the ,
Mayor.
Sec. 15. No ordinance shall take ef
fect until ten days after its passage
unless otherwise provided in such or
dinance.
Sec. 16. Every bill and every resolu
tion as hereinbefore provided, which
shall have passed the Board and shall
have been duly authenticated, shall be
presented to the Mayor for his appro
val. The Mayor shall return such bill
or resolution to the Board within ten
days after receiving: it. Tf he approve
it he shall sicn it and it shall then be
come an ordinance. If he disapprove
It he shall specify his objections there
to in writing-. If he dnes not return
it with such disapproval within the
time above specified, it shall take ef
fect as if he had approved it. The ob
jections of the Mayor shall be entered
at laree in the Journal of the Board,
and the Board shall, after five and
within thirty days after such bill or
resolution shall have been so returned,
reconsider and vote upon the same. If
the same shall, upon reconsideration,
be ae:ain passed by the affirmative voto
of not less than fourteen members of
the Board, the presiding officer shall
certify that fact on the bill or resolu
tion, and when so certified, the bill
shall become an ordinance with like ef
fect as if it hnd been approved by th<Â»
Mayor. If the bill or resolution shall fail
to receive the vote <">f fourteen members
of the Board it shall be deemed finally
lr.st. The vote on such reconsideration
shall be taken by ay^s and noes and
the names of the members voting: for
and apainst the same shall be entered
in the Journal.
Sec. 17. All ordinances and resolu
tions shall be deposited with the Clerk
of the Board who shall record the same
at lensrth in n suitable book.
Sec. 18. No ordinance shall be re
pealed except by ordinance adopted In
the manner hereinbefore set out. and
such ordinance shall be presented to
the Mayor for his approval as herein
before nrovided.
Sec. 19. Except as provided In Chap
ter 111 of Article 111 of this Charter, all
demands payable out of the Treasury
must, before they can be approved by
the Auditor or paid by the Treasurer,
be first approved by the Board of Sup
ervisors. All demands for more than two
hundred dollarsshall be presented to the
Mnvor for '.s approval, in the manner
hereinbefore provide", for th~ pr.s=.isrÂ»
of bills or resolutions. All resolutions
directing the payment of money other
than salaries or . wages, when the
amount exceeds five hundred dollars,
shall be published for five successive
days f Sundays- and legal holidays ex
cented> in the official neTvsna-nor.
